For further details on DCI scheduling, see Downlink control information (DCI), page 302.

1.2.5.5 Antenna ports, precoding and quasi co-located Â­antennas

Like LTE, 5G NR also uses the terms antenna port and precoding in addition to the concept of co-location of antennas. This chapter provides a brief introduction to the abstract definition of antenna ports. It also outlines some of the general aspects of precoding and how this is applied on the 5G downlink and uplink as well as issues related to antenna co-location.

Antenna ports

At first glance, the term antenna port seems like an abstract concept. Moreover, the official definition for the term antenna port is not easy to understand: An antenna port is defined such that the channel over which a symbol on the antenna port is conveyed can be inferred from the channel over which another symbol on the same antenna port is conveyed (TS 38.211). To understand this sentence, we must recall certain aspects related to channel estimation based on reference signals. 5G NR contains different types of reference signals, e.g. DMRS for demodulation purposes and CSI-RS for channel status reporting. By way of explanation, we can understand an antenna port as an indication of the type of reference signal that is conveyed over the radio channel. Accordingly an antenna port is defined by its reference signal. This means that each antenna port refers to a specific channel model, this in turn helps in channel estimation and equalization at the receiver. In the downlink direction, the following antenna ports are defined [Ref. 34]:

Antenna ports for the downlink:

  • Antenna ports starting with 1000 for PDSCH. Total of up to 8 ports for SU-MIMO and up to 12 ports for MU-MIMO
  • Antenna ports starting with 2000 for PDCCH
  • Antenna ports starting with 3000 for channel-state information reference Â­signals
  • Antenna ports starting with 4000 for SS/PBCH block transmission

The following antenna ports are defined for the uplink:

  • Antenna ports starting with 0 for PUSCH and associated demodulation Â­reference signals
  • Antenna ports starting with 1000 for SRS
  • Antenna ports starting with 2000 for PUCCH
  • Antenna port 4000 for PRACH

From a higher level perspective, the term antenna port has to be considered as a more abstract definition. In a hardware configuration, the virtual antenna port has to be mapped onto a physical antenna that can be either a single dipole or a set of dipoles known as an antenna array. Note that the mapping procedure from virtual antenna ports to physical antennas is not standardized and can be implemented in a flexible and vendor-specific manner. As an example of an antenna port mapping, we will consider a single-panel antenna array. Typically, such an antenna array consists of N1ÃN2 cross polarized antenna elements. Now, it would be possible for each antenna element to send an individual CSI-RS for each polarization, leading to a maximum number of N1 multiplied by N2 times two possible antenna ports.

QCL antenna ports

In addition to the definition of antenna ports, 5G NR introduces a definition for the co-location of antennas using the term quasi co-location (QCL), defined as: Two antenna ports are said to be quasi co-located if properties of the channel over which a symbol on one antenna port is conveyed can be inferred from the channel over which a symbol on the other antenna port is conveyed. Since the term antenna port is linked to the type of reference signal that is sent and thus refers to a correlation between different reference signals, the definition of QCL is related to the correlation of different antenna ports. Since in 5G NR different physical signals may be sent in different frequency ranges and may be differently precoded and modulated, the network may configure, via higher layers, a transmission configuration indicator (TCI). As an example for the data channel, the network can configure the UE with TCI state parameters via PDSCH-config to describe a quasi co-location relationship between one or two downlink reference signals and the DMRS ports of the PDSCH.

There are four different QCL types defined in TS 38.214:

  • âQCL-TypeAâ: {Doppler shift, Doppler spread, average delay, delay spread}
  • âQCL-TypeBâ: {Doppler shift, Doppler spread}
  • âQCL-TypeCâ: {Doppler shift, average delay}
  • âQCL-TypeDâ: {Spatial RX parameter}

For channel estimation and measurement reporting, the network provides reference signals such as CSI-RS and the structure of these signals can be configured by higher layers. One of these configuration parameters is the quasi co-location of different antenna ports; it affects how the UE may evaluate the results obtained from CSI monitoring. Based on the received configuration parameters and an activation command via the MAC layer, the UE maps up to eight TCI states to a DCI scheduling parameter. The motivation for the QCL definition is related to beam management where a UE may use the quasi co-location information to support beam mobility procedures such as beam switching, frequency and time offset estimation due to Doppler shift and delay. QCL-TypeA, B and C are more related to general propagation conditions on a non-directive approach and QCL-TypeD refers to beamforming scenarios by including the spatial domain.

Precoding

Similar to LTE, 5G NR also uses the concept of precoding for physical channels, e.g. the PUSCH shown in Fig. 1-62, but it offers more ways to exploit the various aspects of precoding. In general, precoding can be interpreted as the modification of physical parameters of the radio signal before it is conveyed over the radio channel in order to help the receiver to achieve better reception. This leads to different kinds of precoding applications or variants, e.g. precoding for mitigation of radio channel impact, precoding for applying a type of directivity as a generalization of beamforming, and precoding for spatial multiplexing aspects to compensate for cross-talk between multiple data streams in SU-MIMO. In a further enhancement, precoding is used in the background with MU-MIMO to exploit the spatial domain with enhanced beamforming methods such as 3D beamforming. This section should serve as the basis for understanding that there are multiple ways to implement precoding. Thus, only certain aspects are presented. The evolution of precoding techniques can be seen through the various transmission modes over the history of LTE, starting from closed-loop codebook-based precoding and non-codebook-based precoding for single and dual layer beamforming through non-codebook-based precoding for up to eight layers. Furthermore, using sophisticated techniques such as certain aspects of CoMP, precoding can be a technique to mitigate interference between users by applying the ordinary inverse of the channel matrix to generate weighting coefficients such that interference between users is completely zeroed. This principle is known as zero forcing (ZF) and, just for completeness, it is worth mentioning that there are other techniques to mitigate cross-interferences between users like e.g. multiple feedback successive interference cancellation or non-linear approaches. By examining a radio channel in a multipath propagation scenario as shown in Fig. 1-122, page 155, we see that a mathematical interpretation leads to a formula characterizing the received signal depending on the path attenuation, path delay and a path phase for each individual multipath component. Thus, the basic idea of precoding involves the modification of one or more of these three parameters (time, phase and amplitude) before the signal is transmitted. More precisely, the term precoding can be based on the definition of different precoding matrices containing antenna weights, representing a phase shift and amplitude weighting.

Precoding as a generalization of beamforming

As mentioned above, the term precoding does not embody only a single aspect. Instead, one common application of precoding uses precoding matrices to perform antenna weighting consisting of a phase shift and amplitude weighting for the physical signal prior to transmission. One consequence of antenna weighting when using multiple antennas is the introduction of directivity or a generalization of beamforming. To explain this idea, let us consider the simplified example in Fig. 1-78.

This simplified example illustrates the basic principle of precoding. We have a TX setup consisting of two physical antennas transmitting the exact same RF signal that is separated by Î»/2. A first UE is positioned directly in front of the setup. Assuming no multipath, LOS condition, the precoding vector [1, 1] results in phase coherent transmission and thus the receiver can benefit from coherent overlapping of the two propagation paths. Now, we consider a second UE that is perpendicular to the transmitter setup. If the transmitter maintains the precoding scheme of [1, 1] such that each signal is sent with the same phase, the result would be that one propagation path is extended by the longer distance of Î»/2 and the two radio signals would more or less cancel each other. When changing the precoding scheme into a matrix [1, â1], the effect would be that one RF signal is shifted in phase by 180 degrees (or one Ï), which compensates the phase shift of the channel. Continuing with our simplified approach, we may understand precoding as a type of directivity that is applied to the transmit signal. Fig. 1-79 shows an example of these precoding weights using two antenna ports with single-layer transmission [Ref. 22].

Codebook indexMatrixWeightsPhase
00Â°
1180Â°
290Â°
3270Â°

Fig. 1-79 Precoding/weighting for a single-layer scenario using the codebook index (the phase column indicates the phase difference between the two antenna port signals).

This precoding matrix illustrates the principle of quantized phase shifts applied to the signal, e.g. the factor 1 or â1 represents coherent transmission or a phase offset of Ï and the term +j or âj represents a phase shift of Â±Ï/2. 5G NR introduces more sophisticated techniques for beamforming as discussed in 1.3 Beamforming fundamentals, page 169. Beamforming is based on the utilization of an antenna array consisting of multiple antenna elements. To obtain a certain directivity, a weighting function is applied to each antenna element signal. In general, a linear multi-antenna transmission scheme can be modeled as an input vector xL of NL layers that is mapped to a certain number yT of transmit antennas by multiplying the input vector xL by the precoding matrix W (Fig. 1-80). Additionally, multi-antenna processing can be performed in the analog part of the transmitter chain (analog beamforming) or it can be performed in the digital part of the transmitter chain (digital beamforming), depending on the implementation.

Precoding in SU-MIMO spatial multiplexing

Single-user MIMO was used in LTE Rel. 8 to increase the data rate. Different transmission modes supported open-loop and closed-loop MIMO operation. The difference between closed-loop and open-loop MIMO is related to knowledge about the channel at the transmitter based on channel status feedback. Closed-loop MIMO introduced codebook-based precoding. The general idea is to apply precoding to the PDSCH in order to increase the received SINR by setting different transmit antenna weights for each transmission layer using the obtained CSI feedback information. The ideal transmit antenna weights for precoding are generated from eigenvectors of the covariance matrix of the channel matrix, H, given by HH Ã H, where HH denotes the Hermetian transpose of the channel matrix [Ref. 19]. However, algorithms that evaluate and directly feed back estimated channel state information or precoding weights are not practical regarding the required data rate on the reverse control channel and the time variance of the channel itself.

This lead to the introduction of codebook-based precoding. Such a codebook contains predetermined precoding matrix candidates and the selection of the precoding matrix is based on precoding matrix indicator (PMI) feedback. For a better understanding of codebook-based precoding, we will consider some general aspects of SU-MIMO. To increase capacity and exploit the spatial domain, MIMO takes advantage of multiple transmit antennas and multiple receive antennas (and thus multiple path channels). By way of example, the Fig. 1-81 illustrates the channel matrix condition in a 2Ã2 MIMO scenario. A receiver with two receive antennas, assuming the transmitter sends two different code words using two layers, would then have to solve two equations including the channel matrix H. These two equations can be solved when the channel matrix is known. This can be supported by sending orthogonal reference signals on each of the streams; see also Fig. 1-89. One idea, that is based on the singular value decomposition (SVD) method known from linear algebra, is to decompose the channel matrix into its factors. In general terms, the SVD method allows factorization of a given matrix H into its decomposition matrices. Such a matrix H is then replaced by the product of a unitary matrix with a diagonal matrix and another unitary matrix (H = U Î£ (VH)T).

The relevant aspect here is that the diagonal matrix consists of diagonal entries only and these entries are called singular values. In other words, SVD transforms the channel matrix H into a number of parallel AWGN channels only. The capacity of each of the resulting parallel AWGN channels is given by its singular value. This is used in reports such as the rank indicator (RI) by sending the number of non-zero singular values as a rank or condition number to the transmitter.

Through factorization with SVD, the single-channel matrix is transformed into a product of three matrices where the central matrix is the desired diagonal matrix of singular values. As the other two matrices of the factorization product, we have a unitary matrix derived from the eigenvalues of the channel matrix as well as a matrix which is the conjugate transpose of another unitary matrix derived from eigenvalues of the channel matrix. Equalization of the radio channel is the principle by which the receiver multiplies the inverse of the estimated channel response with the received signal. Now, however, after SVD the channel matrix H is decomposed into three matrices of which there are two matrices that require signal processing or equalization. A simple idea is to tackle this from both ends, i.e. at the transmitter and the receiver. The concept of precoding is illustrated in the next figure:

For TDD systems, due to the reciprocity of the channel impulse response the precoding matrix can be generated using singular value decomposition (SVD) at NodeB, making self-based precoding a promising case in the context of the non-codebook-based approach.

The lower equation in the Fig. 1-82 explains the mathematics behind precoding. The transmitter sends a modified or precoded version of the signal s as given by s multiplied with the unitary matrix V and the receiver performs signal processing by multiplying the received signal with the conjugate transpose of the other unitary matrix U. A major drawback of this approach is that knowledge of the channel matrix H at the transmitter is required. Assuming the feedback link has sufficient capacity to provide a full description of the channel matrix H, due to the time variance nature of the channel itself, such knowledge would be delayed and thus not useful any longer in certain situations. Academic research on the topic of limited feedback has shown that it is almost as good as ideal channel knowledge. This is based on the equation showing that the transmitter does not need to know the full channel matrix H, but only the unitary matrix V is required. This leads to the idea of predefining a set of unitary matrices in a codebook and selecting one matrix in that codebook in order to maximize the capacity of the current channel H. These unitary matrices from the codebook approximate the singular vector structure of the channel. CoMP introduces various sophisticated signal processing techniques applied at NodeB to reduce interference between transmission layers, including adaptive beam transmission such as null steering, adaptive transmission power control and simultaneous multipoint coherent transmissions. When these sophisticated transmission techniques are applied, the NodeB multiplexes the UE-specific CSI-RS and DMRS with the PDSCH. This allows the UE to demodulate the PDSCH without information about the used transmission technology. This increases the flexibility in terms of applying sophisticated transmission techniques on the downlink (e.g. dual connectivity, DC).

Precoding in MU-MIMO and for a higher number of layers

While performance maximization has a clear interpretation in SU-MIMO, in MU-MIMO a multi-antenna transmitter communicates simultaneously with multiple receivers. This is known as space division multiple access (SDMA). In theory, the precoding algorithms can be subdivided into capacity-generating non-linear precoding algorithms and linear algorithms that generate reasonable performance with much lower complexity. In addition, SU-MIMO has to support a higher number of layers, e.g. in 5G NR there are eight SU-MIMO layers possible in 3GPP Release 15. This leads to a new approach in reference signal design. The idea of a cell-specific RS like in LTE Release 8 was left behind and use of UE-specific reference signals were specified. 5G NR applies a similar approach: UE-specific DMRS multiplexed within the data and control channels for demodulation and UE-specific CSI-RS signals for channel estimation. The channel estimation accuracy for CQI is low compared to that for demodulation, thus the CSI-RS may have a lower appearance in the time domain. To obtain a certain orthogonality, a specific code division multiplexing scheme is used. This general idea (transmission of UE-specific CSI-RS for CQI reporting only together with the data channel) also allows for the support of beamforming methods.

As shown in Fig. 1-91, CSI-RS can be mapped in a beam-specific procedure and based on beam-specific reports, the NodeB can select the most appropriate beam precoding method (random beamforming precoding). A second impact of MU-MIMO and the higher number of layers is the transition into non-codebook-based precoding such as transmission mode 9 in LTE; see also [Ref. 22].

Precoding configuration aspects in 5G NR

5G NR supports precoding in both directions (uplink and downlink) and precoding is applied to data and control channels as well as to CSI-RS. Due to the complexity, the exact implementation of precoding differs between the uplink and downlink directions and also depends on the signal types and related feedback. The 5G NR uplink is based primarily on codebook precoding, similar to LTE. The precoding in the uplink direction is based on a codebook containing precoding matrices depending on the transmission rank. The precoding matrix to be used is assigned via DCI scheduling of TPMI and the higher layer parameter txconfig. Note that non-codebook-based precoding is also possible in the uplink PUSCH. The uplink sounding reference signals (SRS) may support the network receiver with precoding estimation in case non-codebook precoding is used. In the 5G NR downlink direction, precoding is very flexible and allows usage of various precoding methods depending on the channel and signal types. The network can apply precoding aiming at beamforming on certain signals and the UE will provide support with channel status feedback information.

Generally in 5G NR, we must distinguish between the number of transmission layers NL and the number of antenna ports Np. A certain number of layers are mapped on a certain number of antennas with the aid of a mapping matrix W. This precoding matrix W can be codebook-based, non-codebook-based or more generally, any kind of signal processing method such as analog beamforming. The number of antenna ports is determined by the antenna panel in use, i.e. the parameters N1 and N2 in an array like the one in Fig. 1-77. Only certain configurations are supported in TS 38.214. The uplink channel PUSCH uses a codebook-based precoding mechanism, similar to LTE downlink precoding, by default. As mentioned above, non-codebook-based precoding is also possible but is not considered in further detail in this section. The exact definition of PUSCH precoding is given with the aid of precoding matrices defined for different layer scenarios in TS 38.211. One example is the precoding matrix for PUSCH for single-layer transmission with two antenna ports shown in the following figure:

TPMI index  W (ordered from left to right in increasing order of TPMI index)
0 to 5 â â

Fig. 1-83 Precoding for PUSCH â single-layer transmission with two antenna ports.

Selection of the precoding matrix W is based on the DCI scheduling information TPMI, the higher layer parameter txconfig for codebook configuration and the number of layers. In addition, it is possible to restrict the codebook entries to a certain subset of precoding matrices (TS 38.212). As was already mentioned, in the 5G NR downlink direction precoding is very flexible and allows usage of various precoding methods depending on the channel and signal types. The Fig. 1-84 illustrates the precoding scenarios in 5G NR in a generalized manner:

In the downlink direction, precoding is much more flexible, but unfortunately it is also more complex since more sophisticated techniques such as 3-dimensional beamforming can be applied. To allow various antenna configuration deployments, the network configures the UE with additional parameters about the antenna configuration such as single panel or multi panel and whether MU-MIMO is the main target in comparison to SU-MIMO. Recall that downlink channels such as PDSCH or PDCCH are multiplexed with DM-RS. Thus, any optional precoding scheme is also applied to these reference signals, meaning they do not need to be scheduled to the UE directly. The UE sees the product of the precoding, beamforming matrix and channel matrix at its receiver and provides feedback about the channel status to the network. In addition, the network can send multiple reference signals CSI-RS. The main idea is that beamforming should be applied to the CSI-RS and the UE should select the CSI-RS beam corresponding to the best beam. The network can configure the UE with CSI-RS resources where it has to perform measurements and the UE will provide channel status feedback to the gNB.

This feedback is known as CRI. Basically, the UE sees a product of the beamforming matrix and the channel matrix for the CSI-RS. The reported best Â­CSI-RS beam can then be used for other channels such as the PDSCH. On the selected beam, the UE calculates RI and PMI and in case of a closed loop condition, the network can use the reported RI and PMI for the downlink PDSCH. Reporting of the PMI is based on a precoding matrix concept, introducing three different types of codebook. The UE reports the PMI based on the assumption of a codebook definition to reduce the signaling overhead in the uplink direction. It is then a network decision whether to use the uplink PMI feedback when applying any kind of precoding technique to downlink channels such as PDSCH or PDCCH. Precoding can be performed based on a resource block bundle granularity, where the bundle size is configurable by higher layers. The UE assumes the precoding is constant over a certain number of consecutive RBs; the number of RBs can be one of the values [2, 4 or wideband] and is indicated by the higher layer parameter bundlesize in the PRB-bundleType of PDSCH-config. The bundle type can be either static or dynamic. If the static bundle type is applied, the resource block granularity for precoding is a constant value signaled via bundlesize. If the bundle type is dynamic, the network can configure two different sets of RB precoding granularity, each set allowing the values [2, 4 or wideband]. In this case the DCI scheduling parameter PRB bundling size indicator can switch between set 1 or 2 of the precoding granularity sets (TS 38.214). At first glance, there is no direct precoding codebook matrix indicated for PDSCH, but the principle follows the MU-MIMO precoding aspect which is based on UE-specific reference signals. The downlink PDSCH is multiplexed with DMRS that are precoded in the same manner as the data symbols and accompanied by UE-specific CSI-RS that are beamformed. The PDSCH precoding is transparent since the UE will perform CQI evaluation based on the received reference signals DMRS and CSI-RS. The reported value PMI may help with the selection of the precoding matrix. In addition, the CSI-RS allow a very flexible beamforming or precoding scheme that can either be codebook-based with the possibility to steer in the azimuth and elevation direction or can be based on reciprocity of the channel using eigenvector calculations. The higher layer parameter CodebookType can set the PMI reporting based on the used antenna configuration at the gNB. The following types are allowed: Type 1 single panel codebook, Type 1 multi panel codebook or Type 2 codebook.

Type 1 single panel codebook is the base station antenna configuration for a single antenna panel from the UE perspective, thus assuming a UE considers the situation where only one beam may be sent to this UE at any one time and the precoding targets a SU-MIMO scenario of possible high-order spatial multiplexing. Type 1 multi panel codebook allows dynamic configuration or dismantling of the panels to suit practical applications. It can be seen as a sophisticated evolution of dynamic multipoint transmission or joint transmission derived from CoMP techniques. Type 2 CSI primarily targets MU-MIMO scenarios where multiple UEs are scheduled simultaneously within the same time and frequency resources to exploit the spatial dimensions, but typically in such a scenario, the number of layers for spatial multiplexing is of a lower number. The report for type 2 is much more extensive and requires a higher data rate on the feedback channel. Thus, it is considered primarily for scenarios with low user mobility such as indoor or pedestrian scenarios. TS 38.214 defines certain CSI-RS precoding matrices for up to 32 antenna ports and up to 8 layers. The case with two antenna ports and one or two layers is the same as for LTE (see Fig. 1-85). For a higher number of antenna ports and a higher number of layers, the entries of these matrices contain various values for the amplitude and phase offsets in the azimuth and elevation direction. Thus, sophisticated techniques like MU-MIMO or 3D beamforming can be applied.

Codebook indexNumber of layers Ï  
12
0
1
2 â
3 â

Fig. 1-85 Precoding codebook for CSI-RS, two antenna ports and one or two layers.

1.2.5.6 Physical signals in 5G NR

In addition to the physical channels, that provide services to higher layers, a number of additional physical signals are defined in 5G NR. They are used by the physical layer, but they do not carry information originating from the higher layers. The main purpose of the physical signals is related to synchronization aspects, channel estimation, tracking and beam identification for beamforming optimization, and channel status reporting. The following UL physical signals are defined in TS 38.211, section 6.1.2:

  • Demodulation reference signals (DMRS) for PUSCH and PUCCH
  • Phase-tracking reference signals (PTRS) for PUSCH
  • Sounding reference signal (SRS)

For the DL, the following downlink physical signals are defined:

  • Demodulation reference signals (DMRS) for PDSCH, PDCCH and PBCH
  • Phase-tracking reference signals (PTRS) for PDSCH
  • Channel-state information reference signal (CSI-RS)
  • Tracking reference signals (TRS)
  • Primary synchronization signal (PSS)
  • Secondary synchronization signal (SSS)

Demodulation reference signals (DMRS)

The demodulation reference signals are included in the downlink channels PDCCH, PDSCH and PBCH and the uplink channels PUCCH and PUSCH. They are used for channel estimation and equalization at the receiver for better decoding. The DMRS also play an important role in power allocation, i.e. the network may set the DMRS power as a reference value and indicate its level to the UE via signaling procedures to enable the UE receiver to estimate the path attenuation. See section Power allocation for the downlink, page 121, for further details on power control. The main characteristic of 5G NR is that the DMRS is configured individually for each physical channel, i.e the PDCCH uses a different DMRS compared to the PDSCH, even if the generation principle is similar. Like many other aspects of 5G NR, the DMRS signals also provide great flexibility, e.g. the number of reference signals per slot is configurable. Thus, the network can respond to different propagation situations and provide a flexible degree of robustness concerning the equalization. Generation of the DMRS is based on pseudorandom signal generation that results in QPSK constellation symbols that are then mapped on to certain resource elements in time and frequency. The downlink DMRS for PDSCH is initialized by a pseudorandom sequence generator set with either the higher layer values scramblingID in the IE DMRS-DownlinkConfig or if absent, it is set with the physical cell ID (PCI). Note that 5G NR does not contain cell-specific reference signals (CRS) like in EUTRAN; demodulation and decoding must rely on the DMRS signals only. Like in the downlink case, the uplink DMRS is initialized either by a higher layer scrambling indication or by the physical cell ID. For the PBCH, the DMRS sequence generation is dependent only on the physical cell ID (see 1.3.2.1 SS/PBCH block details, page 174). The generation algorithm for DMRS on the uplink and downlink is illustrated in Fig. 1-86. Note that for the uplink control channel PUCCH, various formats exist, and various DMRS sequences are thus also defined in TS 38.211.

DMRS for PDSCH

The main configuration parameters for the PDSCH DMRS are given by the higher layers via the IE DMRS-DownlinkConfig. Important parameters are the mapping type A or B, the configuration type 1 or 2, and the length of the DMRS within a slot. They can be configured by higher layer control information. Mapping type A indicates that the time reference for the symbols is the start of the slot and the DMRS is then either mapped on the second or third symbol depending on the higher layer parameter dmrs-TypeA-Position given via the MIB; otherwise, mapping type B indicates a DMRS position relative to the start of the scheduled PDSCH resources. The length of the front loaded DMRS can either be one or two consecutive symbols, indicated by the parameter maxLength. If channel conditions such as the SNR or Doppler frequency shift are getting worse, one mechanism that can provide additional protection is to place a larger number of DMRS symbols (up to four), indicated by the higher layer parameter dmrs-AdditionalPosition. Thus, the PDSCH sacrifices data throughput in favor of robustness. The parameter dmrs-Type in the downlink DM-RS configuration IE indicates whether type 1 or 2 is used. Here, the main difference is that in type 1, the DMRS is mapped onto subcarriers in non-contiguous manners while in type 2, the DMRS may use two adjacent subcarriers in a contiguous manner. There is a subcarrier start position â to obtain some type of orthogonality between DMRS signals mapped to different antenna ports. Overall for these signaling parameters, we can say that 5G NR provides a highly flexible mechanism for the mapping of demodulation reference signals onto the physical channel PDSCH in order to respond to various propagation scenarios. The Fig. 1-87 provides an overview of these important higher layer configuration parameters.

The detailed mapping of the PDSCH DMRS to physical resources is determined by the formula in TS 38.211:

As was already mentioned, 5G NR does not support cell-specific reference signals. One aspect of channel estimation involves the situation with SU-MIMO or spatial multiplexing where the receiver has to estimate the cross-correlation or condition number in order to provide feedback in the form of a rank indicator. In LTE, this was solved by mapping the cell-specific reference signals onto a physical resource element such that only one antenna is active per time and subcarrier regarding the reference signal position. This is not possible in 5G NR since CRS symbols are not available and it would somehow violate the idea of directivity due to beamforming and the bandwidth part operation. The method that is applied in 5G NR is shown in the Fig. 1-89, using an example of 2 Ã2 SU-MIMO with two transmit and two receive antennas. The pseudo-noise sequence DMRS is additionally spread with an orthogonal sequence. Thus in the case of spatial multiplexing, multiple antenna ports (which have to be mapped onto different physical antennas) may send the DMRS simultaneously on the same frequency, but each antenna port then uses a different orthogonal code to enable the estimation of the condition number for rank indicator reporting.

DMRS for PUSCH

The uplink channel PUSCH also contains DMRS reference signals that are highly flexible. The main configuration parameters for the PUSCH DMRS are given by higher layers via the IE DMRS-UplinkConfig. If uplink transform precoding is enabled, the sequence for DMRS is not generated as shown in Fig. 1-86 (see TS 38.211 for further details). The important parameters, that can be signaled by higher layer control information, are the mapping type A or B, the configuration type 1 or 2, and the length of the DMRS within a slot. Many of the PUSCH parameters are similar to the DMRS for PDSCH, except in the case where two sequences and mapping schemes are defined depending on whether transform precoding is activated or not. Some minor mapping details are also different in case frequency hopping is enabled (see TS 38.211 for further details).

DMRS for PBCH, PDCCH and PUCCH

5G NR also defines DMRS for the physical control channels PUCCH, PDCCH and PBCH. There are fewer configuration parameters given by higher layers compared to PDSCH and PUSCH. The DMRS for the PDCCH is based on a pseudonoise sequence initialized with either the higher layer value pdcch-DMRS-ScramblingID or the physical cell ID. The PDCCH DMRS symbols are mapped in the time domain only onto resource elements that belong to an OFDM symbol within a slot that is used for the PDCCH. In the frequency domain, the DMRS are mapped onto three subcarriers within one resource block (more precisely, onto subcarriers 1, 5 and 9 of one resource block, with a distance of four subcarriers between them). The DMRS for the PBCH is based on a pseudo-noise sequence initialized with the physical cell ID and an SSB index (see 1.3.2.1 SS/PBCH block details, page 174 for further details). Like with the DMRS for PUSCH, the uplink PUCCH also has two cases for DMRS sequence generation depending on whether transform precoding is activated or not. In addition, the mapping of the DMRS to physical resource elements differs depending on the PUCCH format (see TS 38.211 for further details).

Phase-tracking reference signals (PTRS) for PDSCH and PUSCH

As shown in Fig. 1-31, phase noise represents a challenge, especially when using up- or down-conversion methods in higher frequency ranges. To tackle phase noise effects, 3GPP introduced a dedicated reference signal PTRS that can be used optionally in the 5G NR downlink and uplink signal. This signal enables suppression of phase noise and common phase error at the receiver end, which is needed especially in higher frequency ranges (FR2). Phase error is a common problem due to phase noise which results mainly from mismatching of transmitter and receiver local oscillators. If the PTRS is active, it is generated based on the principle of DMRS sequence generation with a slight exception if transform precoding is active, but scaled with an individual power value. The PTRS is included in the data channels PDSCH and PUSCH only. Due to the fact that phase noise is a more permanent disturbance, the PTRS signal may have a lower density in the frequency domain but a higher density in the time domain. The exact mapping to the time and frequency resources is flexible and configured by the higher layers. The main idea here is to adapt the PTRS to the actual SNR and frequency range in the background. See TS 38.214 for details on when the PTRS is active and TS 38.211 for further details on how the phase tracking reference signal is generated. The higher layer parameters PTRS-DownlinkConfig and PTRS-UplinkConfig indicate configuration details for PTRS signals such as the resource element offset, frequency density [2, 4 or not present] and time density [1, 2, 4 or not present] depending on the scheduled MCS. In addition, the transmit power of the PTRS may be signaled as an offset EPRE to the transmit power of the PDSCH via PTRS EPRE to PDSCH EPRE.

Sounding reference signals (SRS) for the uplink

The concept of sounding reference signals in 5G NR is similar to the sounding reference signal in LTE. Both technologies are based on a flexible scheduling concept by using only a segment of the overall channel bandwidth or aperiodic time scheduling. To enable the base station for channel estimation, the UE can be configured to send the SRS in the uplink direction. In 3GPP Release 15, the UE does not transmit the SRS outside of the active BWP in the uplink direction. Based on channel estimation with the SRS, the network can make a decision on link adaptation (e.g. MCS selection, UE scheduling). Assuming a certain channel reciprocity, especially in TDD, the SRS supports downlink precoding selection functions, beamforming adaptation and scheduling selection for MU-MIMO. Additionally, for possible non-codebook-based uplink precoding, the SRS reference signals can be used together with the DMRS signals inside the PUSCH to estimate the precoding mechanism at the base station receiver. The higher layer IE SRS-Config defines a list of SRS resource sets where each SRS resource set contains a list of SRS resources.

SRS resource may be aperiodic, periodic or semi-persistent, i.e. it is triggered by DCI commands (see Downlink control information (DCI), page 302 for further details). The sounding reference signal is configured by parameters such as a frequency domain position as a start value in the frequency domain, a frequency domain shift as a density indication in the frequency domain, or a start position and a number of symbols plus a repetition factor as time domain behavior. The transmit power of the SRS is controlled by the network. (see Sounding reference signals (SRS) â power control, page 129). The SRS resource spans 1, 2 or 4 consecutive symbols in the time domain that can be repeated up to four times to improve the uplink coverage. Furthermore, techniques such as frequency hopping and transmission comb to switch between TX antennas within a slot are also possible. Transmission comb describes a technique of interleaved mapping of SRS symbols onto subcarriers within one symbol, e.g. mapping onto even or uneven subcarriers during one transmission period. TS 38.214 contains further details about the configuration option for the sounding reference signals. Generation is based on a pseudorandom sequence known as Zhadoff-Chu sequence with the characteristic of a low-PAPR. The symbols are spread over a certain sounding signal bandwidth with possible application of frequency hopping and the option for periodic behavior. Further details on sequence generation and SRS configuration can be found in TS 38.211, TS 38.331 and TS 38.214.

Channel-state information reference signal (CSI-RS)

The CSI is a specific type of reference signal enabling the UE to report channel state information to the network. Unlike the first release of LTE which had cell-specific reference signals (CRS) permanently on the air, 5G NR does not have such a reference signal concept. For decoding purposes, the DMRS signals are defined. Recall that these signals are specific to the physical channel and are thus received only when the UE has to receive this particular physical channel. As a result, the DMRS could only be used to report channel status over a certain bandwidth and valid for a certain time only. For situations such as idle mode or for neighbor cell or neighbor beam detection, the concept of DMRS would not be sufficient. The gNB thus sends CSI reference signals which are used to report channel status information such as CSI-RSRP, CSI-RSRQ and CSI-SINR especially for mobility procedures (see 2.3 Overall Mobility, page 386 for more details).

The CSI-RS are used for beamforming support. They are mapped onto certain resources in the frequency and time domain. In terms of the content, they can be configured by layer 3 to be either beam-specific or UE-specific. One idea could be to have a beam-specific CSI-RS and configure the UE for measuring and reporting the beam-specific CSI-RS status. Thus, these CSI-RS signals play an essential role in performing tasks such as beam acquisition and evaluation, adaption of the beam (beam refinement), beam switching decision-making and UE tracking with steerable beams. As a first option, the network could schedule the CSI-RS as a specific reference signal per beam to allow them to be distinguished from one another. As a second option, the resource element(s) carrying the CSI-RS can be configured to be either zero power (ZP-CSI-RS) or non zero power (NZP-CSI-RS). One objective could be to provide a configuration that contains transmission gaps so that the UE can perform interference measurements and provide feedback. In addition, it may be used for optional beamforming implementations where the zero and non-zero power concept can be used to distinguish between beams. The Fig. 1-91 shows a possible usage example for such a mapping of zero and non-zero power signals. Assuming a beam mobility condition, the gNB here uses two beams with identical physical layer settings such as the bandwidth part and CORESET definition as well as the CSI-RS resources.

For more details on beam mobility, see 2.3.1 Beam mobility procedure, page 387. In the example below, the UE must decide which beam is best. Technically speaking, we can define âbestâ as the highest received power level Â­CSI-RSRP per beam. In the example given in Fig. 1-91, the gNB has configured the Â­CSI-RS resources in an alternating mapping such that for each CSI-RS instance in the time domain, only one of the two beams would have a non-zero power CSI-RS.The gNB can then decide, based on the CQI reports on the uplink which beam to use and whether to apply a beam switching procedure.

Sequence generation for the CSI-RS is based on a pseudo-noise reference signal initialized with the higher layer parameter scramblingID that is signaled to the UE via the serving cell together with additional configuration parameters in the CSI-RS-ResourceMappingIE. Using these parameters, it is possible to configure the position and quantity of CSI-RS in the frequency and time domain based on the resource block and slot definition, density in time and frequency, and CDM scheme for orthogonal code division multiplexing. Density means repetition of the CSI-RS in multiples of slots and resource blocks. For inter-cell mobility procedures, the measurements are either based on the SSB or if known, based on the CSI-RS (see 2.3.3 Mobility measurement, page 401 for further details on mobility measurements). Measurement reports based on the CSI are configured by a higher layer and can be periodic, aperiodic or semi-persistent (see 2.2.9 Uplink control information (UCI), page 340 for further details).

Tracking reference signal (TRS)

The tracking reference signal (TRS) is used for fine timing and frequency tracking in 5G NR. It replaces the cell reference signal (CRS) known from LTE that was originally designed for this purpose. When work began on 5G NR in 3GPP, there were several goals in mind to ensure compatibility both for the future releases and the features. One of the goals was to minimize transmission of always-on signals such as the CRS that was used in LTE. In LTE, the CRS provides important information such as fine time and frequency tracking and QCL assumptions. In 5G NR, that information is still needed and therefore must be distributed in other reference signals [Ref. 27]. Several design options were considered during the development of 5G NR and each has its own drawbacks:

  • Usage of a common reference signal (RS) would result in the same drawback as LTEâs CRS. It is rather inefficient and has the additional problem (especially in high mobility scenarios) that it is difficult to support a flexible QCL with a reference signal that is common to all users
  • Usage of PSS and SSS synchronization signals makes it clear that the density of PSS transmissions is too low in both the time and the frequency domain for fine time and frequency tracking
  • Usage of the DMRS reveals the problem that the DMRS is only transmitted in scheduled resources and may not be scheduled in short enough intervals for fine tracking. In addition, the DMRS also relies on other QCL reference signals to demodulate the data
  • Usage of CSI-RS: The CSI-RS is used for beam management and is configurable, making it suitable for supporting a flexible QCL assumption. The LTE CSI-RS density is also too low, meaning 5G NR requires a new configuration

Ultimately, the group decided that the TRS should be configured as a Â­CSI-RS resource set and signaled by a higher layer. An RRC parameter is included in the CSI-RS set to indicate that it can be used for time/frequency tracking. The TRS can be periodic (also known as âBasic TRSâ) or aperiodic (also known as âÂ­CSI-RS for trackingâ). The UE must support periodic transmission, while aperiodic transmission is optional. The burst structure for periodic TRS is shown in the Fig. 1-93 [Ref. 26], where Y is the periodicity and can be 10 ms, 20 ms, 40 ms or 80 ms. X is the number of slots and currently, X = 2 for FR1 and X = 1 or 2 for FR2.

To fully characterize the reference signal design which is required for fine time and frequency tracking, several parameters need to be considered:

  • Enabling time tracking possibilities
    • Resolvable tracking range, determined by the reference signal spacing in terms of the RE number in the frequency domain
    • Tracking granularity, determined by the reference signal bandwidth
  • Enabling frequency tracking possibilities
    • Resolvable tracking range, determined by the reference signal spacing in terms of the OFDM symbol number in the time domain
  • Number of OFDM symbols containing the TRS within a TRS burst, e.g. as shown in the Fig. 1-93
  • Periodicity of the TRS burst
  • Number of ports

The parameters for the TRS structure inside a burst are, for example, the TRS subcarrier spacing, the TRS symbol spacing within a slot, the number of OFDM symbols per TRS within a slot and the TRS bandwidth in the PRB. For periodic TRS, the transmission parameters involve a minimum bandwidth of 52 RBs, a TRS subcarrier spacing of 4 and the number 2 + 2 OFDM symbols containing the TRS within a slot. The position of these symbols could be (with symbol index starting at 0): symbol 4 and 8, symbol 5 and 9, or symbol 6 and 10. For FR2, there is additional support for TRS symbol positions of {0, 4}, {1, 5}, {2, 6}, {3, 7}, {7, 11}, {8, 12} and {9, 13}. One of the main motivations behind adding support for these additional symbol positions is to support multi-beam operation in FR2. During the 3GPP RAN1 meeting in April 2018, an optional aperiodic TRS was also approved by the group for 3GPP Release 15. Further details on aperiodic TRS parameters can be found in [Ref. 28].

Primary and secondary synchronization signals (PSS and SSS)

For cell acquisition (see 1.3.2.1 SS/PBCH block details, page 174 and 2.1.2.1 Other fundamental properties of synchronization signal blocks (SSBs), page 237), the UE uses two reference signals. They are named primary (PSS) and secondary synchronization signals (SSS). Both, PSS and SSS are contained in the SSB using a bandwidth of 127 subcarriers. They are intended for synchronization in time and frequency to a cell and provision of information about the physical cell ID (PCI). The main purpose of the PSS and SSS is related to initial cell acquisition to determine if system information is transmitted (see 2.1.2.1 Other fundamental properties of synchronization signal blocks (SSBs), page 237). The SSB contains the PSS and SSS and can be considered as the only âalways on airâ signal that 5G NR provides and can therefore be detected even when no radio connection has been established such as in UE idle mode. In other words, the SSBs can be used for initial channel estimation or cell-specific channel status measurements such as SS-RSRP or SS-SINR. Note that the 3GPP standard allows multiple SSB transmissions per carrier bandwidth and the frequency position of the SSB in the carrier bandwidth is up to the network operator. The primary synchronization signal is based on a so-called m-sequence with a length of 127 symbols (unlike LTE where the PSS was based on a Zadoff-Chu sequence). The secondary synchronization signal (SSS) is also based on an m-sequence with a length of 127 symbols. The length 127 allows the usage of a 128 FFT size, representing a compromise between the acquisition speed and implementation complexity. For faster cell acquisition, the physical cell ID ranging up to 1008 values is subdivided into a first part N_ID1 with 3 possible values and used to generate the PSS and a second part N_ID2  with 336 possible values. Unlike LTE, both sub-values N_ID1 and N_ID2 for the PCI are used to generate the m-sequence used by the SSS. In summary, the PSS can be one of 3 possible sequences and the SSS can be one of 335 possible sequences, which together results in a maximum of 1008 possible values indicating the physical cell ID. This is exactly twice the number of possible physical cell IDs compared to LTE. Due to the higher propagation attenuation of the carrier frequencies most likely to be used, it is assumed that 5G NR will deploy a much higher number of cells with smaller coverage areas. Thus, dense network deployments are not averted. For interference reduction across neighbor cells (like in LTE), the network operator should avoid neighbor cells using the same PCI value. Both sequences PSS and SSS use a BPSK modulation scheme.

1.2.5.7 Transmit power allocation

Like other mobile communications technologies, 5G NR also considers aspects related to transmit power allocation in the downlink and uplink directions. Power allocation in the two directions uplink and downlink differs in terms of how the transmit power can be controlled, i.e. the possibility as well as the speed of adapting the transmit power allocation and the signaling of those values. In general, power allocation exhibits certain similarities with EUTRAN, but marginal differences are present. Transmit power allocation in 5G NR is implemented based on an amplitude scaling factor Ã that can be configured either per physical channel or per physical signal. There are differences in the signaling of such values: Some amplitude scaling factors are under direct control while others represent a relationship with respect to other physical signals. The following section provides a concise discussion of power allocation in both directions (downlink and uplink).

Power allocation for the downlink

Downlink power allocation in 5G NR is based on physical signals and physical resource elements. It is typically given as a relative ratio between physical elements or signals whose values are signaled by a higher layer. The downlink power is generally indicated as the energy per resource element (EPRE) for each physical channel or signal and described by an amplitude scaling factor Ã. For example, the higher layer information element ss-PBCH-BlockPower contains a power indication ranging from â60 dBm to 50 dBm and indicates the transmit power of the SSB EPRE. It is obviously used for SS-RSRP, SS-RSRQ and SS-SINR calculation within the UE. This downlink SSB block power is signaled via system information SIB type 1 containing the IE Â­ServingCellConfigCommonSIB and can be additionally signaled to the UE in DC situations, for example, when a secondary cell is activated via ServingCellConfigCommon.

Why is this parameter important in 5G NR? One reason is that the signaled ss-PBCH-BlockPower has a major impact on the initial uplink signal PRACH power that the UE transmits at in the initial access procedure (see 2.1.4 Random access procedure in 5G NR, page 250). The signaled ss-PBCH-BlockPower also affects the uplink transmit power that the UE uses for the PUSCH/PUCCH physical channels and SRS signals. Such power allocation is controlled via the network, and one mechanism in this power allocation control involves the influence of the path loss (PL) in the calculation formula for the uplink transmit power on PUSCH, PUCCH or SRS. The general idea behind the path loss calculation is depicted in Fig. 1-94:

TS 38.214 defines further rules for power allocation such as linear averaging of the power contribution over a certain frequency or time allocation. Like in EUTRAN, 5G also offers the possibility of a power ratio for the downlink PDSCH vs. reference symbols DMRS. This ratio is given as the ratio of PDSCH EPRE to DMRS EPRE ÃDMRS and depends on the configuration of the DMRS signals such as the number of CDM groups and DMRS_type 1 or 2. If the UE is configured with phase tracking reference signals (PTRS), there is another power ratio defined as the ratio of PTRS signal power ÃPTRS vs. PDSCH power. This value is signaled via higher layers as epre-Ratio in the PTRS-config information element. For further details on downlink power allocation, see TS 38.214. and The figure Fig. 1-95 provides an example of a downlink allocation where PDSCH is scheduled together with DMRS using a certain DMRS configuration and PTRS are also scheduled to that particular UE. The example shows the option for a power boost on the control signals DMRS and PTRS (shown in an exemplary manner in this figure).

Power allocation for the uplink

The 5G network controls the uplink transmit power on the physical channels PUSCH, PUCCH and PRACH as well as on the physical signal SRS. The power control mechanism has to find a balance between the need for a sufficient SNR at the gNB receiver vs. UE aspects related to battery consumption and mitigation of inter-device or inter-cell interference. The mechanisms for uplink power control are similar to the mechanism used in LTE. TS 38.213 provides further details on uplink power control for these channels. The following section will focus mainly on power control aspects on the PUSCH physical channel, other channels are discussed briefly. Generally, uplink power control can be divided into two areas. The first is known as open loop power control and applies to the random access procedure. A brief description of the PRACH power control aspects is given below. The second is known as closed loop power control and applies to the uplink transmit power when a radio connection is activated. Open loop describes the situation where a radio link has not yet been established, and thus the decision on the applied initial power must be made by the UE solely based on indirect signaling. Closed loop is used when a radio link connection is activated, i.e. the gNB receives uplink signals from the UE and can measure power values such as the SNR and execute a power control command to either decrease or increase the future uplink power.

PUSCH power control

In 5G, the PUSCH transmit power is influenced by the general configuration settings, the bandwidth and transport format, the optional path loss adaptation and the direct power control commands sent to the UE. Fig. 1-96 provides an overview of the power control mechanism in 5G NR that applies to the PUSCH. The PUSCH transmission power depends on the carrier frequency f, the transmission occasion i in the time domain, the serving cell c in case dual connectivity or UL CA is activated, and a bandwidth part b. The formula shows the calculation rule for PUSCH transmission based on a parameter set configuration with index j, a path loss estimation based on a reference signal index qd, and a power control adjustment state l.

The next section will further examine the PUSCH power calculation formula (see TS 38.213 for details).

PCMAX is a transmit power limiting factor that sets the upper boundary as the maximum possible transmit power given by the UE power class defined in TS 38.101 or permitted in the current cell. Typical values are, e.g. +23 dBm also known as power class 3 Note that in the current release the UE power class is defined per frequency band and some bands allow a second power class 2 corresponding to +26 dBm.

The parameter PO_PUSCH is built on two components: a nominal cell-specific parameter PO_NOMINAL_PUSCH and a UE-specific component PO_UE_PUSCH. Note that the parameter PO_PUSCH is specific to a parameter configuration set with index j. What is the purpose of such a parameter configuration set? It allows definition of open loop base starting points for various allocation scenarios. Some possible allocation scenarios are, for example, the transmission of message 3 in an initial setup procedure or the semi-persistent or grant-free scheduling case (see 2.2.11 Dynamic, semi-persistent and grant-free scheduling, page 382). These differences are referred to as âwith grantâ or âwithout grantâ in certain higher layer signaling messages, i.e. the PO_NOMINAL can either be signaled as the p0-NominalWithGrant element within PUSCH-ConfigCommon or signaled as p0-NominalWithoutGrant within a UE-specific control element PUSCH-PowerControl. The value P0_UE_PUSCH can be provided as a parameter set with the information element P0-PUSCH-AlphaSet. In addition, 5G NR supports beamforming technology. Thus, it would be possible, assuming uplink beamforming is enabled, for the network to configure a parameter set in a beam-specific manner.

MRBPUSCH represents a bandwidth factor for physical resource assignment and is expressed in the number of resource blocks for the corresponding PUSCH transmission occasion i. Note that this scaling factor takes into account the flexible numerologies and resulting subcarrier spacings.

As an option, the uplink transmit power may be influenced by the prevailing path loss condition. Why is this optional? The term Î±(j) can be considered as a scaling factor that may assume values in the range from 0 to 1 in steps of 0.1. It is signaled via the higher layer parameter alpha via a parameter set P0-PUSCH-AlphaSet within the UE-specific control message PUSCH-PowerControl and is specific to the configuration parameter set j that allows allocation grant or beamforming specific power allocation settings. In other words, the weighting or scaling factor alpha prohibits, permits or partially permits the influence of the current path loss described as PL(qd). The path loss is calculated based on a configurable path loss reference PUSCH-PathlossReferenceRS that indicates either the SSB block index or the CSI-RS resource index to be used for path loss calculations by the UE (see TS 38.331, TS 38.213 and Fig. 1-94 for details).

âTF may be considered as a transport format adaptation parameter that can be activated by the higher layer signaling value deltaMCS in the PUSCH-PowerControl information element. It can either be enabled or disabled and refers to an adaptation formula that is influenced by channel coding parameters such as the number of code blocks, code rate, size of CRC and number of resource elements. If deltaMCS is disabled or the PUSCH extends over more than one layer, i.e. uplink MIMO is activated, the value of âTF is set to 0. The formula to calculate it in case it is enabled is given in TS 38.213.

The function f(i,l) represents the dynamic or closed loop part of the PUSCH transmission power control mechanism. As an initial difference compared to LTE, the network can configure two power control adjustment states indexed with l and configured via twoPUSCH-PC-AdjustmentStates in PUSCH-PowerControl. The idea here is to configure two different power adjustment states within the UE for various situations, i.e. QoS flow dependent, or when considering SPS or grant-free scheduling, it can be a method to react to fast-changing radio conditions associated with propagation loss due to fast fading. The power control loop or adjustment state that has to be used is signaled via powerControlLoopToUse in ConfiguredGrantConfig, which provides further control information about non-dynamic grant scheduling. Another important higher layer control information that may distinguish or switch between two distinct power control loops accumulative or absolute power control is the tpc-Accumulation element that indicates whether the received power control commands are to be accumulated or not. The network sends via DCI scheduling (see 2.2.7 UL grant reception or UL assignment, page 329) a transmit power control command (TPC), which is referenced in the above function f(i,l) as Î´PUSCH. Values for these TPC commands are given in Fig. 1-97. The accumulative inner loop power control in 5G NR has progressed from the simple âupâ or âdownâ TPC commands to a more complex scenario. The received TPC command is considered as a power control adjustment command, that is derived as the sum of a received TPC command value set with a certain cardinality within the last period, that occurred before the corresponding PUSCH transmission occasion. Accumulative power control means that the TPC command comes on top of the actual PUSCH transmit power for this particular time incidence. The period in the time domain, that is relevant for the accumulation of power commands, is given by the specification in terms of two sets of symbols, valid for the active UL BWP. First a number of symbols KPUSCH(i â i0) â1 before PUSCH transmission occasion i â i0 and second a number of symbols KPUSCH(i) before PUSCH transmission occasion i.

TPC command fieldAccumulated power control activatedAbsolute power control activated
0â1â4
10â1
211
334

Fig. 1-97 Mapping of the TPC command received via DCI scheduling to TPC command values.

See TS 38.213 for further details on how this accumulation sum has to be calculated. It is necessary to handle different timing aspects of UE reaction times to execute the received power command. In case of accumulated power control commands, the range of reachable power values is determined at both ends by either the maximum UE power Pcmax or the minimum allowed power Pcmin. If the dynamic power control component is set to absolute power control, the value of the function f(i, l) is directly given as one value from the Fig. 1-97 within a range of [â4, +4]. Note that in such cases typically the UE transmit power cannot be controlled over the full dynamic range. Thus, it represents a state where the UE transmit power can be kept somewhat constant over a longer period of time, i.e. the channel condition does not exhibit fast fading effects.

PUCCH power control

The UE may have physical resources to transmit an uplink control channel PUCCH and as previously described for the case of PUSCH transmission, PUCCH transmission must also apply some rules for power control. These parameters are valid for a PUCCH transmission occasion i within a certain cell in case of dual connectivity, a certain bandwidth part b and for a certain frequency f. Most of the uplink power control settings for PUCCH are similar to the principles that were described above for PUSCH. For the sake of brevity, only some differences compared to PUSCH power control are mentioned here. Additional information can be found in TS 38.213. Fig. 1-100 describes the formula for PUCCH transmit power calculation. There are similar values like in the PUSCH case such as cell- and UE-specific nominal power settings, bandwidth adaptation, transport format adaptation and direct power control commands.

PO_PUCCH is a parameter composed of a cell-specific higher layer component PO_NOMI- NAL_PUCCH and if provided, a UE-specific parameter PO_UE_PUCCH.

MRBPUCCH is the bandwidth of the PUCCH resource assignment expressed in the number of resource blocks.

PL is the path loss calculated by the UE based on the indicated reference signal resource, typically given as the SSB block EPRE power. Unlike PUSCH, the path loss always influences the PUCCH transmit power. Thus, there is no weighting factor alpha.

The parameter âF_PUCCH is provided by the higher layer parameters deltaF-PUCCH-f0 for PUCCH format 0, deltaF-PUCCH-f1 for PUCCH format 1, Â­deltaF-PUCCH-f2 for PUCCH format 2, deltaF-PUCCH-f3 for PUCCH format 3 and deltaF-PUCCH-f4 for PUCCH format 4.

Similar to the PUSCH, there is a format adaptation parameter given as âTF, which defines a power adjustment depending on the various PUCCH formats that are applied. It is influenced by e.g. the number of UCI bits, the HARQ feedback size, the SR and CSI bits plus additionally the CRC size of the corresponding PUCCH format.

The dynamic closed loop power control mechanism in the case of PUCCH only uses the accumulative TPC principle, i.e. one of two possible power adjustment states given by index l in function g(i, l) is updated with a relative TPC command Î´PUCCH(i, l) with values in the range [â1, +3].

Sounding reference signals (SRS) â power control

As described, the UE may send uplink sounding reference signals to allow the gNB to perform channel status estimation. Such SRS signals may occur in conjunction with simultaneous transmission of the PUSCH or may be standalone. Similar to PUSCH and PUCCH power control, the SRS transmit power is also calculated based on a formula that is influenced by factors such as the bandwidth, higher layer parameters, path loss estimation and directly received TPC commands. Unlike the PUCCH or PUSCH, the SRS uplink power is not adapted via a certain transport format. The higher layer IE SRS-Config from TS 38.331 provides certain configuration parameters for the SRS and some of them are used for power control mechanisms.

P0_SRS is provided by the higher layer parameter p0 signaled via SRS-config and can take even values in the range â202 dBm to +24 dBm.

MSRS is the bandwidth of the sounding reference signal expressed as the number of resource blocks.

Alpha or Î±SRS is a path loss adaptation scaling factor like in the case of PUSCH transmit power and its value is signaled via SRS-config to the UE.

Similar to the case of the PUCCH and PUSCH, the UE performs a path loss estimate PL(qd) valid for a reference signal resource set indicated by higher layers.

Last but not least, there is a dynamic closed loop transmit power command (TPC) mechanism, defining a power adjustment state given as h(i. l) from the definition of up to two power level adjustments and its value is updated via the DCI scheduling of TPC command Î´SRS. As a side note, recall that the SRS power adjustment state may be linked via higher layer signaling to the power level adjustment of the PUSCH and will thus not be represented as an independent power control loop. Depending on the setting for tpc-Accumulation within SRS-config, the received power level commands Î´SRS have to be recognized as either an absolute value or accumulative.

Physical random access channel (PRACH) â power control

The physical random access channel used for channel access uses an open loop power control method, similar to the one used in LTE networks. Based on the expected power level, path loss situation and higher layer configuration, the UE calculates an initial transmit power to be applied for the PRACH preamble transmission. Further details on the PRACH transmit power and PRACH configuration are found in 2.1.4 Random access procedure in 5G NR, page 250, as well as in the specifications TS 38.213, TS 38.211 and TS 38.331. The transmit power on the PRACH is based on a minimum function given as:

PCMAX corresponds to the maximum UE transmit power, given by the UE power class as defined individually for certain frequency bands.

The second aspect of the minimum function depends on the preamble initial target power and the path loss. The path loss is determined based on the SS-RSRP measurement as illustrated with an example in Fig. 1-94. The preamble initial target power is signaled as the information element preambleReceivedTargetPower as part of the generic parameters for random access. It can assume values between â202 dBm and â60 dBm.

If the UE does not receive a random access response (RAR) from the network in adequate time (ra-ResponseWindow), the UE will retransmit the preamble a maximum of preambleTransMaxtimes. The power for the preamble retransmission is increased by a Î-power value that is dependent on the preamble format and subcarrier spacing and a higher layer signaled parameter powerRampingStep. Fig. 2-32, page 262 shows the settings for DELTA_PREAMBLE for each preamble format. Depending on the transmission counter for the preamble, the power is even further increased as the current counter setting is multiplied by the signaled power ramping step (powerRampingStep) which can be 0 dB, 2 dB, 4 dB or 6 dB. The maximum number of preamble transmissions preambleTransMax can assume the following values: 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 10, 20, 50, 100, 200 transmissions. The appropriate response time for the RAR, given as the higher layer parameter ra-Response-Window, can have the following values: 11, 12, 14, 18, 110, 120, 140 or 180 slots. Fig. 1-102 summarizes the PRACH power control configuration for initial transmission of PRACH preambles:

Dual connectivity â power control aspects

The UE may be configured for dual connectivity, corresponding to multiple simultaneous radio links being either 5G-DC or EN-DC. The specification document TS 38.101 defines a maximum total transmit power the UE must be capable of. For dual connectivity situations, this maximum transmit power is divided and shared among the various radio access technologies. For example, for EN-DC if a UE is configured with a MCG using E-UTRA radio access and with a SCG using NR radio access, the UE is configured to maximum power for transmissions on the LTE MCG by the higher layer parameter p-MaxEUTRA and maximum power for transmissions on the SCG by the higher layer parameter p-NR. For further information on power sharing among various RAT and cells, see TS 38.213.

1.2.5.8 Channel coding

In comparison with LTE, 5G NR uses two different channel coding methods: Low density parity check (LDPC) codes for data channels instead of turbo codes and polar codes for control data. LDPC codes meet the requirements for higher data rates and provide a good balance between implementation complexity and coding efficiency. Polar codes provide high coding efficiency and were thus selected for the control channels in 5G NR. The following chapter provides an introduction to the technical aspects behind these 5G NR channel coding methods. It is structured to include an initial brief digression into general channel coding aspects before introducing the 5G NR relevant coding aspects.

Brief digression into channel coding, LDPC and polar codes

Since channel coding is a substantial feature of mobile communications systems, a brief digression into the general aspects of channel coding is included here to help the reader understand the procedures used in 5G NR. It is not the intention of this book to discuss channel coding in detail. Interested readers can seek out relevant literature on this topic, e.g. [Ref. 1], [Ref. 2], [Ref. 3] and [Ref. 4].

5G NR channel coding comprises block coding with CRC for error detection, LDPC or polar coding for error correction, and interleaving to mitigate error bursts. Channel coding is performed in this order at the data source and in the reverse order at the data sink. The Fig. 1-103 provides an overview of channel coding and its components on a general basis.

Channel coding distinguishes between error detection and error correction mechanisms. Error detection is also known as outer loop error correction. This step involves attachment of error detection mechanisms to the data block by the transmitter to enable the receiver to detect errors. Common examples include parity bit attachment and cyclic redundancy checking (CRC) using the block coding principle. Block coding involves calculating a certain number of parity bits for a block of data bits and then appending them to the data block. At the data sink, i.e. the receiving end, errors in the received code word can be detected with the aid of these redundancy bits. We would like to present a simple single parity check coding example. Here, the assumption is that we have a 7-bit data sequence d1â¦7 that is augmented by one parity bit p1 to fulfill the requirement that the number of ones in the 8-bit code word is an even number. More formally using the modulo 2 or XOR operation, we can express this concept as follows:

Using such a parity check, the receiver can easily determine if a code word that is sent over a noisy channel has been properly received. Based on the above example, the received code word [1 0 0 1 0 0 1 0] does not contain an even number of ones and is therefore not accepted as a valid code word. This code is not sufficiently powerful to indicate which bit was inverted, nor can it detect a greater number of bit errors. More sophisticated codes are based on multiple parity-check equations, all of which must be satisfied and which thus can be used for error correction as well.

With forward error correction (FEC), a total code word of n bits is generated. This consists of (nâk) redundancy bits that are added to a number k of data bits at the transmitting end to enable the receiving end to implement a correction mechanism.

The code rate is defined as the ratio of the input bits into the encoder to the output bits from the encoder. For example, a coder with a code rate of Â½ generates for each input bit a code word with two output bits. Based on the above example with a code word that must fulfill the parity-check equation, one possible concept known as maximum-likelihood detection involves the idea of replacing the received code word with a valid code word that has the lowest Hamming distance. The Hamming distance is defined as the number of bit positions that differ. One problem here is the increased computational power that can be required since for a large code word, there is an exponential increase in the number of potential data words compared to valid code words. Numerous ingenious solutions have been devised to make this task less complex, such as algebraic codes and LDPC iterative decoding.

Low-density parity-check (LDPC) codes â a brief introduction

Low-density parity-check (LDPC) codes were first described by Gallager in 1963 [Ref. 5]. They represent a very efficient method for error correction. They were largely neglected for over 35 years due to the high computational power needed to implement them. In the meantime, the field of forward error correction was dominated by highly structured algebraic block and convolutional codes. A relative state of inactivity in the coding field was utterly transformed by the introduction of turbo codes [Ref. 3] in the 1990s. It was soon recognized that the newly introduced principle of block codes represented a sort of rediscovery of the LDPC codes developed years earlier. The concept of iterative decoding, meaning the output of one decoder can be the input to a subsequent decoder, provides an efficient method for correcting a certain number of transmission errors that is close to attaining the Shannon limit for channel capacity while providing reduced complexity regarding the required computational power. LDPC codes for the data channels enable high data rates with low complexity. Especially in comparison to turbo codes, they provide manageable decoding complexity with relatively good performance. A parallel decoding implementation is possible with LDPC codes, especially at higher coding rates. The complexity of the decoding algorithm is much lower compared to the turbo codes used in LTE. LDPC supports a wide range of adaptable code rates and transport block sizes. In addition, it supports the incremental redundancy HARQ operation, also known as soft combining, in case of retransmission of erroneous packets with changed redundancy versions. These were the major arguments within the standardization bodies for selection of LDPC codes instead of turbo codes for 5G NR [Ref. 35]. How do LDPC codes work in general? This concise digression only describes the functional principle of LDPC. Readers should consult the relevant literature for further details (e.g. [Ref. 6], [Ref. 7]).

As our basis, we will consider the principle of block coding. We imagine a group of six data bits arranged in a 2 Ã 3 block structure (i.e. two lines with three bits each). These data bits are protected by parity bits in the horizontal and vertical structure. The parity bits are defined based on an XOR or modulo 2 operation which can be characterized with equations or in a tabular format.

The data bits (d1 d2 d3 d4 d5 d6) are augmented with parity bits (p1 p2 p3 p4 p5) to produce a code word (d1 d2 d3 d4 d5 d6 p1 p2 p3 p4 p5). This kind of code is said to be systematic since the data bits are fully contained in the code word itself. Thus, a fixed number of data bits are augmented by a fixed number of parity bits, producing a linear block code that can also be characterized with the aid of a parity check matrix H:

Each row of the parity check matrix H represents a parity check equation. Each column left of the vertical line represents data bit(s) of the code word and each column right of the vertical line represents a parity bit. The structure of the parity check matrix H is given as a combination of a (nâk)Â·k binary matrix CT and an identity matrix I with rank (nâk). The characteristic of the parity check matrix H is that the number of ones is small in relation to the total size. Thus, we can call it a sparse matrix or say that it has low density. In a matrix, a received string y = (c1â¦cn) is a valid code word for the code with the parity-check matrix H if and only if it satisfies the matrix equation HyT = 0.

Encoding can now be performed based on the mathematical principle of Gauss-Jordan elimination on H. From the parity-check matrix H, we can resolve a generator matrix G. Given the above example of parity-check equations and thus the resolving parity-check matrix H, a generator matrix G is obtained as follows.

A channel encoder code word c that is sent over the channel can now be obtained by combining the data word d with the generator matrix G using the matrix XOR or modulo 2 operation as c = dXORG. For a binary code with k data bits and length n code words, the generator matrix G becomes a kÂ·n matrix and the ratio k/n is designated as the code rate. A code with k data bits will result in 2k possible code words.
