(i.e. encapsulated NAS message)

Uplink information transfer
(i.e., encapsulated NAS message)		   

Fig. 2-4 Overview of signaling radio bearer (SRB) types in LTE.

An LTE device can handle these three SRBs and a maximum of eight data radio bearers (DRBs) since it can be connected to different gateways and access point names (APNs). The DRB carries the user plane data (IP packets) over the air interface. Typically, there are four major attributes related to a data radio bearer: guaranteed or non-guaranteed bit rate, priority, acceptable delay budget and a maximum acceptable packet loss rate. Depending on the type of service (i.e. voice, video streaming, etc.), a quality of service (QoS) class identifier (QCI) is assigned to the DRB by the network. Today, there are 17 different QCIs defined for LTE (TS 23.203, Table 6.1.7-A). Quality of service (flow) plays an important role in 5G NR and is thus discussed in more detail in 1.1.5 Quality of service, page 40 and 2.2.2 End to end quality of service, page 285.

After the UE has sent the RRCConnectionRequest to the network, it starts two timers: T300 and the contention resolution timer. T300 starts at the transmission of RRCConnectionRequest and ends at the receiption of RRCConnectionSetup. The contention resolution timer defines the subframes, the UE is required to monitor the PDCCH after Msg3 is transmitted. The value for T300 is broadcast in SIB2 and can assume values of 100 ms, 200 ms, 300 ms, 400 ms, 600 ms, 1000 ms, 1500 ms and 2000 ms. If the timer expires, the UE would reset the MAC, collect several important pieces of information such as how many preambles were sent, location information and so on, inform the higher layers about the failure of the RRC connection setup procedure, and then restart the PRACH procedure until the maximum number of attempts has been reached.

From a physical layer point of view, the eNB would acknowledge the reception of the PRB that ultimately carries the RRCConnectionRequest message with an ACKnowledgement sent on the physical hybrid ARQ indicator channel (PHICH). The contention resolution timer is broadcast with SIB2 and is set in number of subframes up to a maximum of 64 corresponding to 64 ms. If the UE does not receive contention resolution (Msg4), it goes back to step one and retransmits the random access preamble. If the UE receives a HARQ NACK on PHICH for Msg3 transmission, it resets the contention resolution timer and restarts the transmission of the preamble.

In the last step of the random access procedure, the UE waits for the RRCConnectionSetup message (Msg4 with contention resolution; see Fig. 2-2), transferred from the eNB to the end-user device using SRB0. The UE monitors the PDCCH for the C-RNTI that was assigned by the network in the random access response message. By successfully decoding the DCI format 1 scrambled with C-RNTI, the UE knows the allocated PRBs on the PDSCH that carries the message. The message itself contains information on the SRB1 configuration that is then used to exchange any RRC/NAS signaling information until SRB2 is established. With the aid of this message, the eNB can instruct the UE to either use the default configuration for SRB1 (defined in TS 36.331) or a specific configuration.

Applying a default configuration significantly reduces the initial amount of signaling information to be exchanged. Along with the SRB1 configuration, the eNB could provide additional information on configuration for physical channels (PDSCH, PUSCH, PUCCH), channel quality indicator (CQI) reports, sounding reference signal (SRS) configuration, antenna configuration and how to submit scheduling requests through the physical uplink control channel (PUCCH) as well.

After receiving the RRCConnectionSetup message, the UE stops the T300 timer and changes from RRC_IDLE to RRC_CONNECTED state. From a physical layer perspective, the UE sends an acknowledgment (ACK) for Msg4 including a scheduling request via PUCCH to the eNB to secure resources on the PUSCH to transmit another RRC message to the network and initiate the initial evolved packet system (EPS) attach procedure.

Through transmission of RRCConnectionSetup by the eNB and reception of that message by the UE, including successfully changing to the connected state, the four-step random access procedure is completed and the UE continues the initial attach procedure to fully register with the LTE network. Similar to LTE, 5G NR takes advantage of the two types of random access procedures: contention-based and contention-free. The differences are mainly due to the required support for beamforming, in particular for mm-wave frequencies and therefore in the used PRACH formats and the preamble sequence generation.

2.1.1.3 LTE attach procedure and UE capability transfer

The UE acknowledges the reception of message 4 and successful application of the provided configuration by sending the RRCConnectionSetupCompletemessage using SRB1. The resources to send this message were requested previously via a scheduling request sent on the PUCCH. What now follows can be summarized as the LTE initial attach procedure. This procedure contains some critical updates in relation to 5G NR non-standalone mode. Until this point, only the UE knows by having decoded SIB2 that the network it is trying to connect to is EN-DC capable. Upon successful execution of the attach procedure, the network will also know that a UE in its serving area supports 5G and what its capabilities are.

The entire content of the RRCConnectionSetupComplete message is shown in Fig. 2-5. Throughout the standardization process for LTE (from Release 8 to Release 15), this message has been extended with additional information elements. To provide a complete picture of the importance of this message, these are all listed in Fig. 2-5. The basic structure and mandatory part of the message are based on 3GPP Release 8.

Besides a transaction identifier and the selected public land mobile network (PLMN) identity in case the radio cell belongs to more than one PLMN (PLMN identities are broadcast in SIB1), the message contains, among other things, an information element known as dedicatedInfo-NAS. With this information element, the UE informs the network about its request to attach or detach from the network, perform a tracking area update or send a service request or extended service request. For initial access, this field is set to attach and the (NAS) attach request message is included.

As shown in Fig. 2-5, the attach request message contains mandatory and optional information elements. For details on the optional information elements, see TS 24.301. With the UE network capability information element, the UE informs the network about the features and functions it supports. The information provided here is independent of frequency band and thus represents general information about what the UE is capable of. As a minimum, four octets (32 bits) are used. However, up to 15 octets (120 bits) are reserved, even though at this point in time not all are used. Therefore, the second octet indicates the length of the UE network capability information element.

With regards to 5G, bit 5 of octet 9 (highlighted in blue in Fig. 2-5) of the UE network capability information element plays an important role. If this bit is set to â1â, it indicates that the UE supports dual connectivity with 5G New Radio(NR-DC). In other words, the UE supports the EN-DC non-standalone mode. Further details however, such as the UE supported 5G NR frequency bands are still unknown to the network. This information, along with other important 5G-related parameters, is provided to the network at a later stage of the initial attach procedure.

After the network has received the attach request message as part of the RRCConnectionSetupComplete message, the eNB forwards the request to the mobile management entity (MME) by establishing the S1 signaling connection with the MME. The MME is the control unit that processes the signaling between the UE and the core network (EPC) in terms of bearer and connection management (see TS 23.002, TS 24.301, TS 36.300 and TS 36.401). As the interface S1 represents the connection between the eNB and the EPC, the S1 signaling connection is a dedicated connection, established separately for each user and thus identified by identities assigned by the eNB and MME (eNB UE S1AP, MME S1AP). S1AP messages (Fig. 2-6) are used to carry information between the base station and the MME. In the initial attach procedure case, this message carries the attach request.

Upon establishment of the S1 connection with the MME, the UE transitions to the EMM-Registered and ECM-Connected state. These transitions mark the first part of the initial attach procedure from a core network perspective as the attach request message not only contains the UE capabilities as previously discussed, but also includes the international mobile subscriber identity (IMSI), i.e. the identity of the UE. Based on the UE capabilities, the MME also knows which security algorithms the UE supports, which is mandatory for the following step in the initial attach procedure (Fig. 2-7).

Step 2 involves authentication between the network and end-user device. There are two parts in the authentication procedure. First, the end-user device authenticates the network and then the network authenticates the device.

Initially, the MME obtains authentication vectors from the authentication center (AUC). The AUC is typically part of the home subscriber server (HSS). The HSS/AUC uses the UE's IMSI and the serving network's unique PLMN identity: country identifier (mobile country code, MCC) and network identifier (mobile network code, MNC) that it receives from the MME and looks up the related LTE master key K which is only stored in the USIM and the HSS/AUC. With this key, the HSS generates a sequence number (SQN) and a random number (RAND). K, SQN and RAND are input parameters to a cryptofunction that generates the values for the eXpected Response (XRES), an authentication token (AUTN) and the ciphering key and integrity key (CK, IK). With the help of a key derivation function (KDF) CK, IK, SQN and the PLMN ID are used to generate the top-level security key KASME (see Fig. 2-8).

The HSS (AUC) submits the RAND, AUTN, XRES and KASME to the MME, which uses these keys for mutual authentication with the UE. LTE is one cellular technology where the network authenticates the UE and the UE also authenticates the network. Therefore, the MME forwards only RAND and AUTN directly within the authentication request message (NAS level) to the eNB which sends these parameters via the established RRC connection using the downlink information transfer message to the UE. This message is typically used to carry any type of NAS information between the UE and MME. Instead of sending KASME, only an index is sent by the network (KSIASME) to provide the UE with all required information to calculate its own authentication keys.

The UE uses AUTN to derive the SQN and then follows the same procedure as the HSS/AUC to calculate its keys. The calculated AUTNUE is then compared with the received AUTN and if there is a match, the network has been authenticated by the UE. After that, the UE sends the calculated RESponse (RES) back to the network using the authentication response message where the MME compares RES and XRES and thus authenticates the UE. At this moment, both the network and the UE are mutually authenticated. The NAS security setup now runs to ensure secure delivery of NAS messages between the network and UE. In this step, the MME selects a ciphering and an integrity algorithm that is supported by the UE.

From the KASME, the UE creates an integrity key (IK) and a ciphering (encryption) key (CK) that is applied to any NAS message to ensure proper ciphering and integrity protection. By sending the security mode command, the MME informs the UE about the selected algorithms which the device acknowledges with the security mode complete message. The security mode command is already integrity-protected. The UE performs an integrity check on the security mode command and calculates both NAS security keys, assuming that the keys are calculated properly once the security check is passed. At this moment, communication between the UE and the network is ciphered and integrity-protected.

At this point, two more steps (location update and EPS session establishment) are required in the core network to complete the initial attach procedure for the UE. At the same time, the base station acquires additional information from the UE about its capabilities in a more detailed manner than provided by the UE network capability indication in the attach request message.

On the core network side, the MME contacts the HSS to indicate that the subscriber has been registered on the network and to check the subscribed services. It informs the HSS that the UE is located in one of its controlled tracking areas (TA). In return, the HSS provides the MME with information about which APN the UE is subscribed to, the packet gateway ID (P-GW ID) through which the user can access this APN, and the subscribed quality of service (QoS) profiles. The final step in the initial attach procedure is EPS session establishment (see Fig. 2-9). This process involves several steps and a brief summary is given hereafter to allow subsequent comparison to the relevant procedures executed in the 5G core network.

After the activation of NAS security, the eNB sends a UECapabilityEnquiry message over the established RRC connection to the UE. The message can include different types of requests of which three are meaningful for 5G: eutra, eutra-nr or nr. During initial registration with the LTE network, the network will set the request type to eutra. With Release 15, the enquiry message has been extended by an additional information element requestedFreqBandsNR-MRDC-r15 with which the network informs the UE about the frequency bands that it supports in terms of 5G. For the UE, it is also the trigger to include information about these bands in its reply to the network (but only if it supports any of them). The term MR-DC stands for multi-RAT dual connectivity and relates to connectivity between LTE and 5G NR in non-standalone mode.

The general response by the UE to the enquiry message is sent as UECapabilityInformation. This message has evolved over time with the continuous addition of features to LTE to become the longest and most complex RRC message. Based on the request type set to eutra, the UE would return UE-EUTRA-Capability in its response to the LTE network. This information element provides the necessary information on all UE-supported features and functionalities with respect to LTE. It includes the RF parameters (which frequency bands are supported for single carrier operation), feature group indicator (FGI), physical layer parameters and supported inter-RAT technologies. This is fundamental information sent by any attaching LTE UE. Over time, the content of the information element has been gradually extended as the LTE specification has evolved. For example, to support carrier aggregation, there is a 3GPP Release 10 feature to increase the supported bandwidth and thus the throughput. The UE submits its carrier aggregation capability by reporting supported frequency band combinations, individually for the downlink and uplink. For a complete overview of all supported capabilities, see TS 36.331, section 6.3.6.

With 3GPP Release 15, the element was extended with another non-critical regular extension to provide information regarding 5G NR support. Fig. 2-10 shows a high-level view of the UE message by expanding the 5G relevant information fields.

From IRAT-ParametersNR-r15, the network is ensured that the UE is EN-DC capable and is informed of which frequency bands it supports for 5G NR. It also receives an indication of whether the UE supports the mobility event B2. The inter-RAT mobility event B2 defines a situation in which the serving cell degrades below one absolute threshold and a neighbor cell improves over another absolute threshold, in wich case a handover is triggred.

Besides the frequency bands, the UE provides information on its capabilities in terms of the packet data convergence protocol (PDCP) layer for NR, including support for header compression profiles and whether the UE supports voice over NR via the master cell group (MCG) bearer or secondary cell group (SCG) bearer.

Now that the network knows this UE supports NR in addition to LTE, the network sends another enquiry to that UE, but this time setting the request type to eutra-nr. The UE responds again with its capabilities where the RAT type is set to eutra-nr and includes information about supported EN-DC features as specified in TS 38.331. The UE provides the network with a list of band combinations that it supports for MR-DC. This list is filtered (or better, âmirroredâ) based on the list the network has provided in its enquiry since the UE potentially supports more band combinations than indicated by the network. The provided list points further to FeatureSetCombination identities, also provided with the UE-MRDC-Capability information element returned by the UE to the network based on the enquiry request type set to eutra-nr. A FeatureSetCombination is a two-dimensional matrix of feature set entries per supported frequency band combination. The feature set then provides the supported feature set per component carrier that is captured in the UE radio access capability specification (TS 38.306).

2.1.2 5G NR signal quality measurements and reporting

Based on the UE capability transfer that takes place during the LTE initial attach procedure, the network obtains information about 5G NR frequency band support by the attaching UE. A UE does not start to scan for surrounding 5G NR signals by itself. Instead, the LTE network provides support and instructs the UE to perform due diligence and carry out signal quality measurements on neighbor cells that support 5G NR. The advantage is that the network knows which 5G NR cells are accessible in its serving area and what frequency band is used for each of those cells. The signal quality measurements are carried out on the previously introduced synchronization signal blocks (SSB); see 1.3.2.1 SS/PBCH block details, page 174). To perform these measurements, the UE must synchronize to the 5G NR downlink signal which is accomplished with the aid of the SSBs. In the following sections, we will discuss some remaining SSB details before continuing with an explanation of how the UE carries out signal quality measurements on NR signals transmitted by the gNB.

2.1.2.1 Other fundamental properties of synchronization signal blocks (SSBs)

The SSBs consist of the primary synchronization signal (PSS), secondary synchronization signal (SSS) and physical broadcast channel (PBCH). Note that in 5G NR, the same names for physical signals and physical channels are used as in LTE. As shown in Fig. 1-143, an SSB encapsulates the PSS, SSS and PBCH over four consecutive OFDM symbols. From a frequency domain perspective, a total of 240 subcarriers (= 20 PRB) are reserved for an SSB. These subcarriers are numbered from 0 to 239 and do not necessarily need to follow the default resource grid defined for 5G NR (see 1.2.5 General description of the physical layer, page 73). The reason is that the SSB can utilize a different subcarrier spacing than the one used for the control channel (PDCCH) and data channel (PDSCH), e.g. 240 kHz instead of 120 kHz when using frequencies above 6 GHz.

In contrast to LTE where the PSS and SSS have a periodicity of 5 ms and PBCH of 10 ms, all signal components of the SSB are transmitted together, i.e. they all have the same periodicity. SSBs are organized in burst sets, where a burst set is composed of one or more SSBs. The maximum number of SSBs per burst (= Lmax; see Fig. 2-11) depends on the deployment frequency range. For f < 3 GHz, Lmax = 4. For 3 GHz < f < 6 GHz, Lmax = 8 and for f > 6 GHz, Lmax = 64. To provide greater flexibility for transmission of the SSB, the SS burst set periodicity can be set to 5 ms, 10 ms, 20 ms, 40 ms, 80 ms or 160 ms. During initial synchronization, a UE would assume a default periodicity of 20 ms. Not all SSBs are always transmitted. In fact, for LTE and NR coexistence some SSBs in certain deployment scenarios or band combinations are not transmitted by the network to avoid interference between LTE and NR.

In LTE, the PSS/SSS and PBCH are always transmitted around the center frequency of the signal. In 5G NR, the SSB can be positioned anywhere within the transmission bandwidth of the signal but are subject to either a carrier raster or a so-called synchronization raster depending on the operation mode (NSA or SA).

The SSBs are repeated within an SS burst set and all transmitted SSBs are mapped to the same antenna port (p = 4000) (see also 1.2.5.5 Antenna ports, precoding and quasi co-located Â­antennas, page 98). This stands in contrast to any pre-5G technology such as the proprietary 5G Technology Forum (5GTF) standard. Therefore, SSBs are transmitted with time division multiplexing which allows simplified beam sweeping transmission since each SSB can be beamformed in a different spatial direction. This concept also supports a simplified, low-cost analog beamforming architecture.

Primary synchronization signal (PSS) and secondary synchronization Â­signal (SSS)

As in LTE, the PSS and SSS represent the physical cell identity (PCI). In 5G NR, however, the number of identities has been doubled compared to LTE from 504 to 1008 in total. This is because 5G NR is required to support high-density deployment scenarios. The PSS consists of one of three frequency-domain-based binary phase shift keying (BPSK) m-sequences with a length of 127. This sequence is mapped to 127 consecutive subcarriers (subcarriers 56 to 182; see Fig. 1-143) out of 12 reserved PRBs in the center of the SSB. The length 127 allows the usage of a 128 FFT size. The secondary synchronization signal is one of 335 Gold sequences with the same length as the PSS, which is also mapped to the same contiguous subcarriers but in a different symbol. During the initial cell search process, the UE correlates the received signals with the aid of matched filters to identify the physical cell ID and based on signal position in the time domain, the overall symbol timing.

Physical broadcast channel (PBCH) and demodulation reference signal (DMRS)

A polar code is used as the channel code for the PBCH. For an introduction to polar code principles, see 1.2.5 General description of the physical layer, page 73. The modulation scheme used for the PBCH and its demodulation reference signal is QPSK. The transmit time interval (TTI) for the PBCH is defined to be 80 ms. This means the PBCH is updated and transmitted every 80 ms, although repetitions may be sent more often. Given the 80 ms TTI and the shortest SS burst periodicity of 5 ms, there are 16 possible positions within this time interval for transmission of SSBs within the SS burst set. These 16 positions (= 24) can be identified by the three least significant bits of the SFN and the one-bit half frame index that are transmitted as part of the PBCH's payload (see Fig. 2-14). For demodulation purpose, the PBCH does contain demodulation reference signals, further details on the mapping procedure of DMRS within PBCH are shown in Fig. 1-145, page 176.

Master information block (MIB) on the PBCH

As in LTE, in 5G NR the physical broadcast channel (PBCH) also carries the master information block (MIB). However, its content is tailored to 5G. The payload size of the MIB is 23 bits.

The 23 bits of the MIB are used as follows:

  • MSB of the system frame number (SFN) (6 bits)
  • Subcarrier spacing used for SIB1, message 2 and message 4 transmission (scs15or60, scs30or120) (1 bit)
  • Subcarrier offset (0 to 15) (4 bits)
  • Position of demodulation reference signal (DMRS) for PDSCH (dmrs-TypeA-Position: pos2 or pos3) (1 bit)
  • PDCCH configuration to receive SIB1 (pdcch-ConfigSIB1) (8 bits)
  • Cell is barred from UE camping on it (cellBarred) (1 bit)
  • Intra-frequency reselection support (intraFreqReselection) (1 bit)
  • Spare bit (1 bit)

The first six bits represent the most significant bits (MSB) of the system frame number. Next is the info on which subcarrier spacing is used for transmission of SIB type 1 (PDCCH, PDSCH) and messages 2 and 4 in the random access procedure (see 2.1.4 Random access procedure in 5G NR, page 250). If the UE acquires the MIB at sub-6 GHz frequencies, a 0 or 1 represents 15 kHz or 30 kHz respectively. For frequencies above 6 GHz, it is 60 kHz or 120 kHz. The subcarrier offset corresponds to the parameter kSSB (see the resource grid definition in 1.2.3 Frame structure, page 61), which is the frequency domain offset between the SSB and the overall resource block grid in terms of the number of subcarriers. The value range can be extended by an additional bit during PBCH payload generation (see below for additional information). The next bit defines the first position of the PDSCH's demodulation reference signal. A detailed introduction to the usage of demodulation reference signals in 5G NR can be found in 1.2.5.6 Physical signals in 5G NR, page 110. The next info provided by the MIB is the configuration for the control channel to retrieve SIB1, including the bandwidth for the PDCCH, a control resource set (CORESET), the search space and the necessary PDCCH parameters. This information is relevant for standalone access (SA) (see 2.4 Overall access procedure for SA mode, page 408). For NSA, this field is not relevant since the remaining minimum system information (RMSI) is delivered via dedicated RRC signaling through the established LTE connection (Fig. 2-12). The next two bits determine whether the UE is allowed to camp on this cell (barred, not barred) and whether the UE is allowed to perform an intra-frequency cell reselection in case the cell is barred. The last bit is a spare bit and is not used.

Since the MIB contains higher layer information, it is transmitted as an RRC message (BCCH-BCH message) utilizing the BCCH logical channel and BCH transport channel and is then finally mapped onto the PBCH. The structure of the BCCH-BCH message adds another bit to the payload, a so-called âchoice bitâ. The choice bit was implemented to indicate a change in the MIB content that might be added in a later release of the specification. 3GPP is providing some flexibility here for future development of the 5G NR standard.

The (23 + 1) bits are now channel-coded. Fig. 2-13 illustrates the individual steps in the channel coding process for the MIB.

First, eight additional bits are added to the MIB bits (Fig. 2-14). The first four bits represent the least significant bits of the system frame number. With the six bits transmitted in the MIB, a UE is able to determine the SFN (0 to 1023) depending on successful decoding of the PBCH and the carried MIB. The next bit identifies the half frame (5 ms) the SSBs are transmitted in. The meaning of the next three bits depends on the frequency at which the signal is transmitted. As mentioned earlier, for frequencies over 6 GHz a maximum of 64 SSBs per SSB burst is possible. To address each SSB uniquely with an index, six bits are required. For this case (Lmax = 64), the three bits represent the three most significant bits (MSB: 6th, 5th and 4th bit) of the SSB index. The three least significant bits (LSB) are derived by the UE from the changing DMRS sequence of the PBCH transmitted over the three OFDM symbols in the time domain. These three bits are enough to identify the SSB index for frequencies below 6 GHz. Above 6 GHz, the additional three bits in the PBCH payload generation are required. For frequencies below 6 GHz, the three remaining bits are used as follows: The 6th bit is used to extend the range for the parameter kSSB. This means the SSB can now be shifted in theory by up to 25 = 32 subcarriers compared to the basic resource grid. The value of kSSB indicates to the UE whether there is an SIB type 1 transmitted in this NR cell. This is the case if kSSB > 23 for FR1 and if kSSB > 11 for FR2. Bits seven and eight are reserved for future use.

The PBCH payload (32 bits) is then interleaved in accordance with TS 38.212, followed by scrambling, where the initialization of the scrambling sequence depends on the physical cell identity. After scrambling, 24 bits are added as a cyclic redundancy check (CRC), increasing the PBCH payload to 56 bits in total. This payload is then polar-coded, producing 512 coded bits which now have to be mapped to 864 available physical bits in the rate matching procedure. Rate matching for polar-codes to increase the number of coded bits to a higher number of physical bits is basically performed by the repetition of bits (352 bits in case of PBCH), preceded by a sub-block interleaving step. An optional additional successive bit interleaving is omitted for the PBCH. The resulting 864 bits are then mapped on the subcarriers that carry the PBCH in the three symbols within an SS block.

2.1.2.2 Provisioning of the measurement configuration to the end-user device

The signal quality measurements are carried out by the end-user device on the secondary synchronization signal. To determine the received signal quality of surrounding NR cells, three distinct measurements have been defined in accordance with TS 38.215:

  • Secondary synchronization signal reference signal received power (SS-RSRP) is defined as the linear average of the power contributions (in W) of the resource elements that carry secondary synchronization signals (SS). When examining the relevant 5G NR specifications, we must always recall that they are written for both modes: NSA and SA. TS 38.215 states that for assessing RSRP, the DMRS for the PBCH and the channel state information reference signal (CSI-RS) can also be optionally utilized by the end-user device. However, this must be signaled by higher layers. The NR cell quality assessment during initial access is based on the SSS only
  • Secondary synchronization signal reference signal received quality (SS-RSRQ). The RSRQ measurement sets the RSRP and received signal strength indicator (RSSI) in relation to both indicators assessed over the same measurement bandwidth. The difference between the RSRP and RSSI measurement is that RSSI considers total wideband power including all interference and noise contributions within the signal bandwidth. RSRP only measures the power on those subcarriers carrying the signal component of interest. In this case, it is the secondary synchronization signal. Therefore, the measurement bandwidth for that measurement is the used subcarrier spacing. TS 38.215 defines the option to measure the RSSI over a certain number of OFDM symbols only. There are four possible configurations that indicate over how many OFDM symbols the RSSI for NR is to be measured. The configuration that the UE should use is signaled via higher layers (RRC). This type of information is not provided by the measurement object sent over the established RRC connection via the LTE network. Therefore, this additional setting applies only when sent over the NR RRC connection (SA Mode Option2 or NE-DC Option4)
  • Secondary synchronization signal interference to noise ratio (SS-SINR). Like in the SS-RSRP measurement, the DMRS for PBCH can be optionally utilized when indicated by higher layers

To enable the UE to synchronize and carry out these signal quality measurements, the network provides support by sending the configuration of the SSB to the UE over the established RRC connection via the LTE link. The network transmits an RRCConnectionReconfiguration message that includes the measurement configuration with the newly introduced information element MeasObjectNR (see TS 36.331).

For each frequency to be measured, one individual measurement object is sent that includes the following information:

  • Carrier frequency (carrierFreq-r15) â This information element provides the frequency (as ARFCN-ValueNR-r15) on which the SSB is transmitted
  • Configuration of SSB (rs-ConfigSSB-r15) â Besides indicating which subcarrier spacing is used for the SSBs (15 kHz, 30 kHz, 120 kHz or 240 kHz), this field provides all required information to the UE to further calculate the measurement window to carry out the quality measurements
  • Quality thresholds (threshRS-Index-r15) â The threshold for SS-RSRP, SS-RSRQ, SS-SINR to determine if the measurement results are included in the measurement report or not
  • Cell quality (maxRS-IndexCellQual-r15) â To assess the overall NR cell quality, the measurement results must be averaged over this number of SSB indices when these indices are above the quality threshold (threshRS-Index-r15)
  • Offset frequency (offsetFreq-r15) â Defines an offset frequency for the two mobility events B1 and B2
  • Do not measure these cells â With two fields (blackCellsToRemoveList-r15, black-CellsToAddModList-r15), frequencies/cells can be removed or added to the so-called black list. Black-listed cells are not considered for event evaluation or measurement reporting
  • Quantity configuration (quantityConfigSet-r15) â Selects one of up to two quantity configurations
  • Frame time difference (cellsForWhichToReportSFTD-r15) â Cells for which the UE must report the time difference observed between the SFN and frame timing of the LTE (EUTRA) cell (PCell) and the NR cell (PSCell). The UE reports the SFN offset between both cells as the frame boundary offset (see TS 38.215)

The carrier frequency for the SSB requires a little further explanation. LTE follows a bandwidth-centric approach. A UE only needs to scan the respective frequency band following the channel raster to find the carrier frequency of the signal. That was sufficient and allows the UE to identify the (LTE) PSS, (LTE) SSS and (LTE) PBCH since they were transmitted on six reserved resource blocks centered around the carrier frequency. A fundamental difference between LTE and 5G NR is the support for so-called bandwidth parts (see 1.4 Bandwidth part fundamentals, page 182) that allow for the first time in cellular communications an asynchronous bandwidth setting between the base station and the UE. Bandwidth parts are not just defined by e.g. occupying a different number of resource blocks but can also use a different numerology. Therefore, the frequency position of the SSB within the downlink signal needs to be signaled to the UE. This information is signaled as the new radio absolute radio frequency channel number (NR-ARFCN), which can assume a value in the range 0 to 3 279 165. This range is dictated by the global frequency raster defined by 3GPP's working group RAN4 for 5G NR, covering frequencies from 0 to 100 GHz (Fig. 2-15). In this table, ÎFGlobal defines the fundamental granularity of the global frequency raster and is therefore the basis for calculating the channel raster ÎFRaster defined for each frequency band in both frequency ranges FR1, FR2. Ultimately, this results in an NR-ARFCN range per frequency band with a corresponding step size. The relevant details are covered in TS 38.101-1 and TS 38.101-2.

FR1, FR2Frequency rangeÎFGlobal  FREF-OffsNREF-Offs  Range of NREF
(NR-ARFCN)
  FR1: 450 MHz to 0 to 3000 MHz5 kHz000 to 599 999
7.125 GHz3000 to 24 250 MHz15 kHz3000600 000600 000 to 2 016 666
  FR2: 24.25 GHz to
52.6 GHz		24250 to 100 000 MHz60 kHz24 250.08 MHz2 016 6672 016 667 to 3 279 165

Fig. 2-15 NR-ARFCN parameters for the global frequency raster.

The NR-ARFCN provided within MeasObjectNR corresponds to subcarrier #0 in RB#10 of the SSB.

5G NR may use the same or a different frequency band compared to LTE and even explore mm-wave frequencies up to 52.6 GHz. For any quality measurement, the UE may have to retune its receiver to a different frequency or frequency band than the current serving LTE cell. Therefore, a time period needs to be defined such that the UE can make these measurements on different frequency bands. This time is provided by either the so-called measurement gap or a measurement window. As mentioned above, the measurement object provides the required information to calculate the measurement timing configuration (MTC) to carry out the quality measurement on the SSS. This includes the periodicity, offset and duration of the window. Fig. 2-17 shows an example assuming a periodicity of 40 radio frames and an offset value of 22. The measurement timing configuration window offers great flexibility. However, it needs to match the transmission of SSB within an SS burst to enable measurements on the SSS.

With this information, the UE is now able to carry out signal quality measurements on 5G NR cells since it knows the frequency on which to find the SSB and when it can retune its receiver to these frequencies to perform the measurements. If the UE detects multiple beams, it will calculate the linear average over the maximum number of beams (maxRS-IndexCellQual-r15) allowed, only taking SSB beams into account that exceed the defined threshold (threshRS-Index-r15). This will determine the overall cell quality which normally must be reported by the UE.

Consequently, all measurement results have to be reported back to the LTE network. The measurement configuration (MeasConfig) within the received RRCConnectionReconfiguration message includes all required information on how to report the results in terms of quality measurements for 5G NR. Each measurement object has an associated measurement identity that is linked to a reporting identity with an associated reporting configuration. The measurement reports for neighboring NR cells include the physical cell identity for that cell, the measurement result for the cell (RSRP, RSRQ, SINR) and the measurement results for each detected SSB listed by index with the RSRP, RSRQ and SINR result if configured. The best SSB index is reported first, and a hierarchy is built up by decreasing SSB index but only for indexes that are above the configured threshold. To send the report, the UE needs to send a scheduling request on the LTE physical uplink control channel (PUCCH) in order to receive an uplink scheduling grant by the eNB to transmit the measurement report (MeasResultCellNR-r15) using the LTE physical uplink shared channel (PUSCH).

2.1.3 Connecting the 5G RAN and reconfiguration of the air interface

Based on the received measurement report, the eNB can then decide to add a 5G NR base station as a secondary node. A basic overview of this procedure is given in Fig. 2-18 (see TS 37.340, section 10.2.1 for further details).

In step 1, the eNB assumes the role of master node (MN, MeNB) and initiates the addition of the secondary node by sending the SgNB addition request command over the non-ideal X2 interface to the desired gNB and starting the timer TDCprep. With this message, the MN requests preparation of radio resources for EN-DC operation for a specific UE. The detailed content of the message is defined in TS 36.423.

This message includes the following parameters:

  • MeNB to SgNB container with various information as specified in TS 38.331, including:
    • Entire UE capabilities
    • Latest 5G NR measurement results with a list of frequencies configured by the MN to be measured by the UE. This information can be used by the SN to decide which SCell to configure for this UE
  • NR security capabilities of the device â The encryption and integrity protection algorithms the end-user device supports for 5G NR
  • EUTRAN radio access bearer (E-RAB) configuration â E-RAB parameters, transport network layer (TNL) address information
  • Information about X2-U bearer operation of MN terminated SCG bearers and SN terminated MCG bearers
  • The maximum supported QoS level using SN terminated split bearer

The request can be rejected by the secondary node or acknowledged, in which case the gNB returns the SgNB request acknowledge command to the MN. While doing so, it secures the required radio resources and decides on a primary Â­secondary cell (PSCell) and other secondary cells (SCell) to be added to the UE. In case of NSA, one 5G NR carrier is combined with one or more LTE carriers. Therefore, the carrier activated by the gNB is at this point the PSCell and the only SCell at the very same time. Now, the secondary gNB (SgNB) sends a message back to the MeNB that includes the NR RRCReconfiguration message, the radio bearer configuration, the measurement configuration with frequencies to be measured, their serving cell index and the frequency range type (FR1, FR2) they belong to.

As the MeNB receives the acknowledgment over the X2 interface, it initiates the second major step of the addition procedure by using the provided information to configure or reconfigure the air interface for 5G NR. This involves sending an RRCConnectionReconfiguration message over the LTE link. With the evolution of LTE, the content of this message has been extended multiple times. Now, with support for 5G NR, new information elements have been added. One of these new elements is the nr-SecondaryCellGroupConfig-r15 message, which carries the NR RRCReconfiguration message that was received from the SgNB. The MN forwards this message without any modification to the UE, embedding the message content in the LTE RRCConnectionReconfiguration message as nr-SecondaryCellGroupConfig-r15. The content of this message provides the UE with the bearer configuration, radio resources, cell configuration and measurement configuration. As shown in Fig. 2-19, the message also includes all relevant information on how to use the random access channel to synchronize to the 5G NR cell. The random access procedure in 5G NR is explained in 2.1.4 Random access procedure in 5G NR, page 250.

nr-RadioBearerConfig is also part of the RRCConnectionReconfiguration message and includes the configuration of the radio bearers configured with NR PDCP. Another important information that is provided with the reconfiguration message is the sk-Counter which provides a value in the range 0 to 65 535. This value is used for initial configuration of security for EN-DC. The LTE network provides this info to facilitate the configuration of signaling radio bearer 3 (SRB3). SRB3 is configured for the transfer of some NR RRC messages (e.g. measurement configuration and reporting) between the UE and SgNB via the NR radio interface.

The UE acknowledges successful reception of the message by sending the RRCConnectionReconfigurationComplete message back to the LTE network. The next task for the UE is to establish uplink synchronization with the 5G NR cell using the provided information. Acknowledgment of reception of the RRCConnectionReconfiguration message is not dependent on successful execution of the random access procedure for 5G.

2.1.4 Random access procedure in 5G NR

As in LTE, 5G NR uses a contention-based (CBRA) or contention-free random access (CFRA) procedure. In general, the procedure encompasses the transmission of the random access preamble on the PRACH (message 1), the random access response by the network via PDCCH and PDSCH (message 2) and for the contention-based random access procedure, the transmission of the L2/L3 message on PUSCH (message 3) and the reception of the PDSCH for contention resolution (message 4).

CFRA is the mode the UE initially uses to perform the random access procedure in non-standalone mode. As shown in Fig. 2-20, the UE uses an assigned preamble to perform random access and the procedure is concluded once the UE receives the random access response. Contention-based random access is the fallback scenario in non-standalone mode. If CFRA fails, e.g. transmission of the dedicated preamble is not acknowledged within a configured time period, the UE may switch to CBRA to establish uplink synchronization. Fig. 2-21 provides an overview of the different use cases for each procedure. Generally speaking, CFRA is typically applied when the UE is already in connected mode (RRC_CONNECTED).

Random access procedure modesUse cases
Contention-free random access (CFRA)
  • Uplink synchronization (e.g. non-standalone mode (EN-DC))
  • Beam failure recovery
  • Handover
  • System information (SI) request
Contention-based random access (CBRA)
  • Initial access (standalone mode)
  • Fallback (non-standalone mode)

Fig. 2-21 Overview of the different use cases for each procedure

For both modes, the network provides dedicated and common resources to perform the random access towards the SgNB. The information elements that provide all the required information are highlighted in Fig. 2-19 in blue (CFRA) and green (CBRA, CFRA), respectively.

The fundamental difference between LTE and 5G NR regarding the random access procedure is that transmission of the random access preamble for initial access is typically tied to reception of the SSB on the downlink. In other words, the UE performs the previously described signal quality measurements on surrounding NR cells and decides on the best received SSB (beam) index. The identified index now determines on which frequency-time resource the random access preamble is transmitted using the PRACH. This enables the base station to focus its subsequent downlink transmission of the random access response in the same direction. For CFRA, the procedure ends with reception of the random access response. For CBRA, the UE uses the information provided by the random access response to begin initial transmission on the PUSCH (message 3) using the same beam direction as for preamble transmission. Consequently, the base station sends the contention resolution using the same beam direction as for message 2. Fig. 2-22 summarizes the subcarrier spacing and beam management during the initial random access procedure.

Message no.DirectionDescriptionChannelSubcarrier spacingBeam,
beam direction
1UE â¶ gNBPreamble transmission (random selection (CBRA) or assigned (CFRA))PRACHIndicated in RACH-ConfigCommon, received via LTE RRC connectionBeam determined based on SSB index and related PRACH occasion in frequency-time
2UE âµ gNBRandom access response (RAR)PDCCH, PDSCHDerived from MIB as subCarrierSpacing-CommonObtained based on detected PRACH and RACH preamble transmission
3UE â¶ gNBScheduled transmission of e.g. RRCSetup Request
(CBRA only)		PUSCH
(transform precoding might be enabled via RACH-Config-Common		Use subcarrier spacing set for initial uplink bandwidth partSame as message 1
4UE âµ gNBContention resolution
(CBRA only)		PDCCH, PDSCHSame as for message 2Same as message 2

Fig. 2-22 Beam management during the 5G NR random access procedure.

2.1.4.1 Transmission of the random access preamble

Fundamentals of random access preambles in 5G NR

The section Physical random access channel (PRACH), page 89 provided an introduction to the random access preamble, including how it is generated and transmitted on the physical random access channel. This section builds upon on the information provided there. Similar to LTE, the random access preamble is a Zadoff-Chu sequence, i.e. a sequence with constant amplitude zero auto correlation (CAZAC). The standard specifies a short and a long sequence. Like in LTE, the long sequence format is designed for the frequency range FR1 and uses a subcarrier spacing of 1.25 kHz or 5 kHz. It is intended to be used for macro deployments (large cells). There are four different formats available supporting different types of cell sizes. The short sequence, intended for small cell and indoor deployments, can be used for both frequency ranges FR1 and FR2. It utilizes a subcarrier spacing of 15 Hz and 30 kHz for FR1 and 60 kHz and 120 kHz for FR2 (see Fig. 1-51, page 74 and Fig. 1-52, page 75). For FR2, this results in a minimum bandwidth requirement for PRACH transmission of 10 MHz for an SCS of 60 kHz and 20 MHz for an SCS of 120 kHz. This is a major difference compared to LTE. There, the PRACH that carries the preamble occupied only six resource blocks and thus a total of 1.08 MHz bandwidth using a subcarrier spacing of 1.25 kHz.

With reception of RRCReconfiguration over the established LTE RRC connection, the UE receives the RACH-ConfigCommon information element. This message is used to specify cell-specific random access parameters. It includes generic parameters for the regular random access procedure as well as for beam failure recovery. With RACH-ConfigCommon, the network informs the UE directly about which subcarrier spacing (ÎfRA) to use for transmitting the random access preamble on PRACH. Only the values 15 kHz, 30 kHz, 60 kHz and 120 kHz are applicable for this information element. In other words, if the field is absent the UE must determine the subcarrier spacing differently. In this case, the UE uses the prach-ConfigurationIndex (further details on this information element are found throughout this paragraph). Since higher subcarrier spacings are not applicable, this index will only signal one of the preamble formats 0, 1, 2 or 3 that use 1.25 kHz or 5 kHz, respectively. In other words, in this particular cell only one of these formats (and thus one subcarrier spacing) is applicable.

The two different types of sequences (long, short) that could be used for the random access preamble differ not only regarding the subcarrier spacing they are defined for. Long sequences support an unrestricted set of preambles and restricted sets of type A and Type B, while short sequences only support unrestricted sets of preambles. An unrestricted set could include all 64 possible preambles, but this is not mandatory due to the support for CFRA in 5G NR since a certain number of preambles are thus reserved for it. For restricted sets, the available number of preambles is organized in two groups (A and B). Group A includes preambles from 0 to the signaled number of preambles and group B consists of the remainder of the available preambles. Group A exists only if group B is configured. There are two groups due to the required uplink grant for message 3 transmission. If the UE only has a small amount of data to transmit or the radio conditions are not very good, an uplink grant with only a small resource allocation but a robust transmission scheme is required. For UEs with more data to transmit or in cases where radio conditions are ideal, a grant reflecting these conditions is required. Therefore, group A has a setting that defines the required transport block size (TBS) threshold in bits for the transmission of message 3. In other words, if the potential message size exceeds this threshold (and certain power conditions are met), the UE is required to pick a preamble from group B but otherwise from group A. Preamble selection from one of these groups is still random, so there can be collisions on the air interface since another UE within that cell may pick the same preamble. Again, this âgroupingâ is only supported for long sequences (i.e. 839) with a subcarrier spacing of 1.25 kHz or 5 kHz and is therefore the same definition as for LTE. Furthermore, it is only applicable to CBRA and not to CFRA.

As stated in the section Physical random access channel (PRACH), page 89, generation of the preamble is influenced by several parameters that are available to the UE upon reception of RACH-ConfigCommon and RACH-ConfigGeneric. Upon reception of the root sequence index, the set of 64 preambles can be generated by the UE.

Based on the provided subcarrier spacing, the UE can already determine if the procedure is based on an unrestricted set (15 kHz, 30 kHz, 60 kHz, 120 kHz) or if there is an unrestricted and restricted set type A or B (1.25 kHz, 5 kHz). Based on this type of information and the subcarrier spacing, the value for the cyclic shift (NCS) to generate the preamble is determined by the UE based on the parameter zeroCorrelationZoneConfig (see TS 38.211) signaled with RACH-ConfigGeneric in RACH-ConfigDedicated and RACH-ConfigCommon. RACH-ConfigDedicated and thus RACH-ConfigGeneric are also part of the RRCReconfiguration message received over the LTE RRC connection.

When to transmit the random access preamble?

The generic parameter (RACH-ConfigGeneric) also includes the prach-Â­ConfigurationIndex, which informs the UE not only about the preamble format to use but also about the point in time at which to transmit the preamble in the uplink. There are a total of 256 indices (0 to 255), and the configuration of each index depends on the frequency range (FR1 or FR2) and for FR1 also the type of spectrum (paired, unpaired) utilized by the network. Fig. 2-23 shows selected examples from the 0 to 255 indices for FR1 and unpaired spectrum (TDD). The complete table as well as tables for all other configurations can be found in TS 38.211, section 6.3.3.2.

PRACH
configuration index		Preamble formatnSFN mod x = ySubframe numberStarting symbolÂ­Number of PRACH slots within a subframeNumber of time- domain PRACH occasions within a PRACH
slot		PRACH
duration
0016190--0
108190--0

109A2100, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 99114
â¦â¦â¦â¦â¦â¦â¦â¦â¦
132A3100, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 97116

â¦â¦â¦â¦â¦â¦â¦â¦â¦

â¦â¦â¦â¦â¦â¦â¦â¦â¦
169C016192262
â¦â¦â¦â¦â¦â¦â¦â¦â¦
210C2100, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 98116
â¦â¦â¦â¦â¦â¦â¦â¦â¦
255A3/B3100, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 92126

Fig. 2-23 Random access configurations for FR1 and unpaired spectrum (TDD).

Let us now consider an example for CFRA with non-standalone access while assuming that the prach-ConfigurationIndex sent in RACH-ConfigDedicated (see Fig. 2-19) was set to 133.

This index instructs the UE to use preamble format B1. Since the above table is for FR1, the potential subcarrier spacing used for data transmission is 15 kHz, 30 kHz or 60 kHz. Assumption is, that the network is configured to use 30 kHz for the initial bandwidth part. In that case, one subframe with the standardized duration of 1 ms consists of two slots with 14 OFDM symbols each. In accordance with TS 38.211, Table 6.3.3.1-2, the total length of any preamble format is determined by the used subcarrier spacing, the cyclic prefix and the sequence length (see Fig. 2-24). For format B1, the sequence is repeated and therefore transmitted twice. Due to the total length of the preamble, some preamble formats (i.e. B1 to C2) must use a guard period (GP) to satisfy the timing definitions for 5G NR. The resulting guard periods are listed in Fig. 1-68.

Based on the index, the UE has an opportunity to send the random access preamble in every radio frame (SFN) that fulfills nSFN mod 4 = 1. In other words, the UE can send its preamble in radio frames 1, 5, 9, 13, 17, â¦, etc., which results in a periodicity of 40 ms. Within these radio frames, subframe #9 is reserved for preamble transmission. The starting position (= OFDM symbol) for preamble transmission is based on Fig. 2-25 as defined in TS 38.211, section 5.3.2.

Parameter l0 is given by the prach-ConfigurationIndex and in the example with index 133, it is set to 2. The next two parameters define the PRACH transmission occasion within the PRACH slot, i.e. the possibility to send the preamble.

There can be a maximum of eight occasions in the time domain. For index 133, this results in a range from 0 to 5, where the duration is given by the index itself with 2 corresponding to two OFDM symbols. Since the subcarrier spacing for the preamble in this example is set to be 30 kHz, the RACH slot parameter is set to two.

Frequency position for transmission of the random access preamble

As explained, 5G NR makes use of bandwidth parts (BWP), dividing the available channel bandwidth into different parts that utilize one of the defined numerologies and occupy a defined number of contiguous resource blocks. The fundamentals of bandwidth parts are discussed in 1.4 Bandwidth part fundamentals, page 182. As it was mentioned there, a UE camps on an initial downlink and uplink bandwidth part that is configured by the network either through dedicated RRC signaling or broadcasting of system information. In non-standalone mode, or more detailed EN-DC mode, the information is provided to the UE by the established signaling connection via LTE. Upon reception of the RRCReconfiguration message, the network specifies among an initial downlink bandwidth part also the initial uplink bandwidth part a UE should use for its initial transmission such as the random access preamble. First of all, the UE has to determine the position of the carrier. This information is provided by frequencyInfoUL with the two information elements absoluteFrequencyPointAand scs-SpecificCarrierList. These elements are highlighted in orange in Fig. 2-26. The latter provides the numerology of the carrier as well its overall bandwidth and the offset to reference Point A that is given as the number of common resource blocks (offsetToCarrier, 0 to 2199). The locationAndBandwidth information element, which is also highlighted in orange in the same graphic, now defines the exact frequency domain location and the number of resource blocks allocated for the uplink bandwidth part. It can assume a value in the range 0 to 37 949. This value is treated as a resource indicator value (RIV) using a BWP size of 275 RB as the basis. With this information, the UE can exactly determine the location of the uplink bandwidth part where the random access preamble should be transmitted (Fig. 2-27).

Continuing with our example, we will assume that the subcarrier spacing used for transmission of the random access preamble is ÎfRA = 30 kHz. Based on the also known subcarrier spacing used by the initial uplink bandwidth part (Îf), the number of resource blocks required to transmit the preamble in the frequency domain can be determined.

Fig. 2-28 lists the possible combinations and resulting number of required resource blocks.

LRAÎfRA for PRACH (in kHz)Possible preamble formatÎf for PUSCH (in kHz)NRARB, allocation expressed in number of RB for PUSCHk
8391.250, 1, 21567
8391.253031
8391.25602133
83953152412
8395301210
83956067
13915A1, A2, A3,
B1, B2, B3, B4, C0, C2		15122
139153062
139156032
1393015242
1393030122
139306062
1396060122
1396012062
13912060242
139120120122

Fig. 2-28 Supported combinations of ÎfRA and Îf.

Now the UE is aware of the required bandwidth for transmitting the random access preamble. With the generic parameter (RACH-ConfigGeneric), the UE receives two additional parameters related to transmission of the random access preamble: msg1-FDM and msg1-FrequencyStart. The latter dictates the frequency offset in terms of the number of resource blocks from the first resource block in the initial uplink bandwidth part (see Fig. 2-27). The parameter msg1-FDM determines how many PRACH occasions in the frequency domain within one time instance (RACH Occasion, RO) are available to transmit the random access preamble. msg1-FDM can assume values of 1, 2, 4 or 8, which means there is a maximum of eight instances in the frequency domain.

Based on this information and the previously determined timing information, the UE can clearly identify the time-frequency resource in the uplink direction that allows transmission of the random access preamble. Returning to the example with PRACH configuration index 133 and assuming msg1-FDM is set to 4 (see Fig. 2-24), we have a total of 24 RACH occasions (RO). The missing piece of information is how a RACH occasion is linked to a synchronization signal block (SSB) and which preamble(s) are assigned or mapped to an SSB.

The answer to this is slightly different when discussing initial access for standalone and non-standalone mode. NSA uses the CFRA procedure for initial access and the RACH-ConfigDedicated information element provides the following input to the UE to help answer this question: ssb-perRACH-Occasion, Â­ra-ssb-OccasionMaskIndex and CFRA-SSB-Resource. The latter assigns one random access preamble to an SSB index. Recall that depending on the deployment frequency range, there can be a maximum of 4 (fc < 3 GHz), 8 (3 < fc < 6 GHz) or 64 SSB indices (fc > 6 GHz) available and transmitted by a network. However, based on ssb-PositionsIn-Burst, the UE determines how many of these SSB indices are actually transmitted by the network since not all are required to be transmitted. This typically depends on the applied beamforming principles as well as the hardware design and configuration of the 5G NR base station, which naturally can vary from vendor to vendor. The example we were considering is based on FR1. Assuming a carrier frequency of 3.5 GHz, the UE analyses an 8-bit bitmap. If the bit is set to â1â, the SSB is transmitted and otherwise it is not. We will now assume that all eight SSBs are transmitted. These SSBs need to be above a threshold that is signaled in RACH-Config-Common as rsrp-ThresholdSSB to be considered for random access. Based on the detected SSB(s) that are above the threshold, the UE will select one of these SSBs and use the information provided in CFRA-SSB-Resource to identify the associated sequence for the random access preamble to be used for this SSB index. The question is now which occasion in the time domain to use for transmitting this preamble. This information is identified with the aid of ssb-perRACH-Occasion which can assume values of â, Â¼, Â½, 1, 2, 8 or 16. A value of â means that one SSB is assigned to eight consecutive PRACH occasions (marked in blue in Fig. 2-30). Now, ra-ssb-OccasionMaskIndex comes into play, which defines PRACH occasion(s) associated with an SSB in which the random access preamble is now transmitted (see TS 38.321, section 5.1.2). Fig. 2-29 lists all possible indices. In our example with prach-ConfigurationIndex set to 133, there is a total of six PRACH occasions available within a PRACH slot. The PRACH mask index now clearly identifies which of the occasions to use for the preamble transmission.

PRACH mask indexAllowed PRACH occasion(s) of SSB
0All
1PRACH occasion index 1
2PRACH occasion index 2
3PRACH occasion index 3
4PRACH occasion index 4
5PRACH occasion index 5
6PRACH occasion index 6
7PRACH occasion index 7
8PRACH occasion index 8
9Every even PRACH occasion
10Every odd PRACH occasion
11Reserved
12
13
14
15

Fig. 2-29 PRACH mask index values.

Assuming the PRACH mask index is set to 4, then RACH occasion index 4 is used for transmission of the preamble, even if there are eight consecutive occasions associated with the SSB. As was indicated previously, the parameter msg1-FDM defines the additional occasions from a frequency domain perspective. In the example, it was set to 4. The UE now selects one of the four possible occasions randomly but with equal probability among the consecutive PRACH occasions. Fig. 2-30 illustrates our example.

Now the UE has identified the resources in frequency and time for transmission of the random access preamble.

PRACH transmission power

The final piece of information that the UE requires involves parameter settings to calculate the initial power for transmission of the preamble on the identified resources. Fig. 2-31 shows that this transmit power is a minimum function like in LTE.

PCMAX corresponds to the maximum UE transmit power. As of today, 5G NR defines three different power classes for FR1. However, only power classes 2 and 3 are applicable. Power class 2, defined for frequency bands n41, n77, n78 and n79, defines a maximum power of +26 dBm with a tolerance of +2/â3 dB. Power class 3, which is applicable to all frequency bands, including n41, n77, n78 and n79, defines +23 dBm, but with frequency band-dependent tolerances.

The second aspect of the minimum function depends on the preamble initial target power and the path loss. The path loss is determined based on the SS-RSRP measurement carried out on the SSB that was selected by the UE to identify the time-frequency resources for preamble transmission. The actual transmit power of the SSB is signaled to the UE as ss-PBCH-BlockPower (via the RRCReconfiguration message) and can be in the range â60 dBm to 50 dBm. The preamble initial target power is signaled as part of the generic parameters for random access signaled to the UE and can assume values between â202 dBm and â60 dBm. This is common for both CFRA and CBRA as the generic parameters are part of both messages (RACH-ConfigCommon and RACH-ConfigDedicated).

In case the UE does not receive a random access response from the network in adequate time (ra-ResponseWindow), the power to transmit the preamble is increased by a Î-power value that is dependent on the preamble format and subcarrier spacing. In the earlier example with preamble format B1 (index 133) and subcarrier spacing for the preamble transmission of 30 kHz, the Î-value is 11 dB. Fig. 2-32 shows the settings for each preamble format. Depending on the counter for transmission of the preamble, the power is increased even further as the current counter setting is multiplied by the signaled power ramping step (powerRampingStep) which can be either 0 dB, 2 dB, 4 dB or 6 dB. The maximum number of preamble transmissions is also signaled to the UE and is equal to 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 10, 20, 50, 100 or 200 transmissions.

Preamble formatValues (in dB), Âµâ {0, 1, 2, 3}
00
1â3
2â6
30
A18 + 3 Â· Âµ
A25 + 3 Â· Âµ
A33 + 3 Â· Âµ
B18 + 3 Â· Âµ
B25 + 3 Â· Âµ
B33 + 3 Â· Âµ
B43 Â· Âµ
C011 + 3 Â· Âµ
C25 + 3 Â· Âµ

Fig. 2-32 Î-preamble power values.

2.1.4.2 Reception of the random access response

Like in LTE, the random access response (RAR) is transmitted by the network on the physical downlink shared channel (PDSCH). Information sent on the physical downlink control channel (PDCCH) makes it possible to identify the resource blocks that carry the response. The sections Physical downlink control channel (PDCCH), page 82 and Physical downlink shared channel (PDSCH), page 79 provide a detailed introduction to these two physical channels and their usage in 5G NR.

Random access radio network temporary identifier (RA-RNTI)

Each transmission of a random access preamble is associated with a random access radio network temporary identifier (RA-RNTI). The gNB receiving the preamble will calculate this identifier to scramble the downlink control information (DCI) format with the correct identity. The UE receiving the random access response will also calculate the identity to know for which RA-RNTI it must monitor the control channel to identify the resources that carry the expected random access response. The RA-RNTI is calculated as follows (TS 38.321):

RA-RNTI = 1 + s_id + 14 â t_id + 14 â 80 â f_id + 14 â 80 â 8 â ul_carrier_id

The individual parameters are as follows:

  • s_id corresponds to the first OFDM symbol index on which the PRACH is transmitted (0 â¤ s_id < 14)
  • t_id is the index of the first specified PRACH in a system frame (0 â¤ t_id < 80)
  • f_id is the index of the specified PRACH in the frequency domain (0 â¤ f_id < 8)
  • ul_carrier_id indicates which uplink carrier is used for message 1 transmission (0 for normal uplink carrier, 1 for supplemental uplink)

Monitoring the PDCCH for RA-RNTI

With reception of RACH-ConfigGeneric, the UE also receives information about the random access response window (ra-ResponseWindow), i.e. the time at which the UE should receive a response from the network on the transmitted preamble. The time period between the start of this window and the transmission of the random access preamble is at least one OFDM symbol. The length of this monitoring window is provided as the number of slots and can be 1, 2, 4, 8, 10, 20, 40 or 80 slots. A slot is always 14 OFDM symbols, but due to the different subcarrier spacings and thus different symbol lengths, a slot can have a different duration. The network configures a value less than or equal to the radio frame length of 10 ms. For a subcarrier spacing of 30 kHz, the maximum configurable length would be 20 slots. For this time period, the UE starts monitoring the PDCCH for DCI format 1_0 with its CRC scrambled with the previously calculated RA-RNTI. Here, the question is which time-frequency resources the UE should monitor.

This information is available to the UE since the reception of the RRCReconfiguration message that was received as nr-SecondaryCellGroupConfig-r15 as part of the RRCConnectionReconfiguration message sent via the LTE link. This message includes the common configuration for the control channel and thus provides the UE with information about the so-called search space. The random access response is transmitted in the common search space, thus the UE starts monitoring a Type1-PDCCH common search space set configured by the parameter ra-SearchSpace in the RRC information element PDCCH-ConfigCommon. If the parameter ra-SearchSpace is not configured by higher layers, then the UE uses the information provided within the MIB to access the Type0-PDCCH common search space. In the following discussion, the assumption is that the network provides information on the search space for random access.

The total number of search spaces per BWP is limited by the standard to ten. Each search space, and thus the ra-SearchSpace, is identified by a SearchSpaceId associated with a ControlResourceSetId. Both are linked in the information element SearchSpace that defines how and where to search for PDCCH candidates. This field provides information on which slots to monitor, which offset to the monitoring period to apply, and what the monitoring duration is. An example is given in Fig. 2-33 where the UE monitors the PDCCH for a DCI format 1_0 with CRC scrambled with the RA-RNTI within the random access response window duration. It monitors the control channel for four slots and for the signaled number of OFDM symbols (monitoringSymbolsWithinSlot). In the example, it is three OFDM symbols, highlighted in orange.

As explained in Physical downlink control channel (PDCCH), page 82, the frequency domain information is provided with the information element ControlResourceSet that is linked to the particular ControlResourceSetId. The control set provides a bitmap with a length of 45 bits. Each bit stands for six consecutive resource blocks. Thus, the maximum bandwidth for transmission of the control channel in 5G NR is 45 . 6 = 270 RB, where the maximum total signal bandwidth (depending on the used subcarrier spacing) can be 273 (TS 38.101-5.3.2). The other information provided by the control resource set information element is the duration (i.e. how many OFDM symbols â up to 3 â are used by the PDCCH), the bundling size info and whether the PDCCH resources are interleaved or non-interleaved.

If the UE detects the expected scheduling grant (DCI), it decodes the provided information accordingly (see next section). If the UE does not detect a DCI within the random access response window or if it detects the DCI but does not correctly receive the transport block on the PDSCH or does not correctly decode the associated transport blocks, then the UE transmits another random access preamble. It is supposed to begin transmission NT,1 + 0.75 ms after the last symbol of the random access response window or the last symbol of the PDSCH reception. NT,1 is a time duration of N1 symbols corresponding to a PDSCH reception time for UE processing capability l when additional PDSCH DMRS are configured. This next preamble is transmitted with an increased power level as shown in Fig. 2-32.

DCI format 1_0

The scheduling grant with information about which resource blocks carry the PDSCH with the random access response (RAR) is provided to the UE via DCI format 1_0. If the network decides to send the RAR, the DCI format is mapped to the time and frequency resources discussed in the previous section.

The actual content of DCI format 1_0 depends on its purpose. In this case, since its CRC is scrambled with the RA-RNTI, it provides the following information:

  • Frequency domain resource assignment (â¡log2(NRBDL, BWP (NRBDL, BWP + 1) / 2â¤ bits)
    • The number of bits depends on the bandwidth part size. Here, this is the size of CORESET 0 (see TS 38.212)
  • Time domain resource assignment (4 bits)
  • VRB-to-PRB-mapping (1 bit)
  • Modulation and coding scheme (5 bits)
  • TB scaling (2 bits)
  • Reserved (16 bits)

5G NR supports two different resource allocation types (0, 1) for the frequency domain in the downlink direction. For DCI format 1_0, resource allocation type 1 is always used. It is based on interpretation of the signaled resource indication value (RIV). The value of RIV represents a starting resource block (RBStart) and a number of contiguously allocated resource blocks (LRB). Calculation of RIV depends on the bandwidth part size. In case of DCI format 1_0 scrambled with RA-RNTI, it is the number of resource blocks used for the CORESET that carries the DCI. If (LRBs â 1 â¤ â£NsizeBWP/2â¦ then RIV = NsizeBWP (LRBs â 1) + RBstart, otherwise RIV = NsizeBWP (NsizeBWP â LRBs + 1) + (NsizeBWP â 1 â RBstart) (see TS 38.214).

The four bits that encode the time domain resource assignment value m are used by the UE to determine an index as m + 1. This index points to one row in a table that provides the required information on the applied offset K0 from the slot that carries the PDCCH with DCI format 1_0, the start symbol S of the PDSCH and the number of allocated symbols L. In terms of the Type1-PDCCH common search space with RA-RNTI, the default PDSCH time domain resource allocation type A applies (see Fig. 2-34).

Based on that table, there is no slot offset K0 applied as it is for all row indices set to 0. This means the PDSCH carrying the RAR is transmitted in the very same slot as the PDCCH. The start symbol (S) and the number of contiguously allocated OFDM symbols (L) depend on the position, i.e. the symbol in which the (first) demodulation reference signal for the PDSCH is sent. This can be OFDM symbol #2 or #3 within the slot and this information is encoded in the MIB. The PDSCH mapping type (A, B) determines if the mapping is based relative to the start of the slot (i.e. OFDM symbol #0) or relative to the start of the PDSCH transmission since e.g. the second, third can still be used by the control channel. For more details on the physical layer, see chapter 1.2 Physical access fundamentals, page 46.

Row indexdmrs-TypeA- PositionPDSCH mapping typeK0SL
12Type A0212
30311
220210
3039
32029
3038
42027
3036
52025
3034
62Type B094
30204
72044
3064
82, 3057
92, 3052
102, 3092
112, 30122
122, 3Type A0113
132, 3016
142, 3024
152, 3Type B047
162, 3084

Fig. 2-34 Default PDSCH time domain resource allocation type A for normal cyclic prefix.

The next indication provided with DCI format 1_0 is whether virtual resource block to physical resource block (VRB-to-PRB) mapping is active or not. The setting of this bit determines whether non-interleaved is active or not. Non-interleaved means that a virtual resource block is mapped one-to-one to a physical resource block. However, in case of PDSCH transmission scheduled by DCI format 1_0 that is transmitted in a common search space, virtual resource block n is mapped to physical resource block n + NstartCORESET. NstartCORESET corresponding to the lowest-numbered physical resource block in the control resource set that the DCI was received in. In case the bit is set, interleaved mode is enabled. There are different rules for how interleaving is handled based on the type of PDCCH, the received DCI format and the RNTI. Typically, the VRB-to-PRB-Interleaver setting, which is sent in the PDSCH-Config information element, comes into play. The interleave size sets the virtual resource block bundling size to either two or four resource blocks (n2, n4). However, for DCI format 1_0 which is transmitted in any common search space other then the Type0-PDCCH common search space, the bundle size L is set to two resource blocks (see TS 38.211, section 7.3.1.6). The total number of bundles Nbundle depends on the size of the initial bandwidth part (NsizeBWP,init), the start of the bandwidth part (NstartBWP,i) and the start of the Â­CORESET (NstartCORESET). The last parameter corresponds to the lowest-numbered physical resource block in the control resource set in which the corresponding DCI format 1_0 was received. The first bundle (bundle #0) can have a different size than two, depending on the start of the bandwidth part the DCI is transmitted in and the resource block that marks the start of the CORESET. Similar to the first bundle, the last bundle can also have a different size than two resource blocks. This is the case when (NsizeBWP, init + NstartBWP,i + NstartCORESET) mod L > 0 and thus the number of resource blocks used for the last bundle would be (NsizeBWP, init + NstartBWP,i + NstartCORESET) mod L. The mapping of virtual resource block bundles to the physical resource block bundle is based on Fig. 2-35, where j corresponds to the current bundle with an interval of {0, 1, 2, â¦, Nbundleâ 2}. Virtual resource block bundle Nbundleâ 1 is always mapped to physical resource block bundle Nbundleâ 1. The same is true for bundle #0 according to the equation below. The mapping principle is basically dictated by the parameter C and is thus dependent on the total number of bundles.

Fig. 2-36 shows a simplified example where the total number of bundles Nbundle is assumed to be eight. Bundle size L is equal to two according to the above rules. For simplicity, we assume the first and last bundles have the same size. In a real network deployment, however, this depends on the overall network settings

The next information in the scheduling grant is the modulation coding scheme used for the PDSCH carrying the random access response. This information is coded with 5 bits. Theoretically, it points to one of 32 possible indexes in one of the three defined MCS tables (modulation and coding scheme, MCS) (see 2.2.4 DL data reception, page 307 for details). For DCI format 1_0 where the CRC is scrambled with RA-RNTI, only MCS index table 1 is relevant (see Fig. 2-37). Furthermore, only entries where the modulation order Qm is not greater than two are applicable (Qm > 2; see TS 38.214, section 5.1.3.1). In other words, the resource blocks that are allocated for the PDSCH, carrying the random access response, are QPSK modulated.

MCS index IMCSModulation order QmTarget code rate R Ã 1024Spectral efficiency
021200.2344
121570.3066
221930.3779
322510.4902
422080.6016
523790.7402
624490.8770
725261.0273
826021.1758
926791.3262
1043401.3281
1143781.4766
1244341.6953
1344901.9141
1445532.1602
1546162.4063
1646582.5703
1764382.5664
1864662.7305
1965173.0293
2065673.3223
2166162.6094
2266663.9023
2367194.2129
2467724.5234
2568224.8164
2668735.1152
2769105.3320
2869485.5547
292Reserved
304
316

Fig. 2-37 MCS index table 1 for PDSCH.

The next two bits inform the UE about the transport block (TB) scaling. As explained in 2.2.4 DL data reception, page 307, the transport block size (TBS) determination is different compared to LTE. It is defined as a two-stage process for 5G NR. After determining the modulation and coding scheme (see previous step), two additional calculations are required to determine the TBS. First, the number of information bits (Ninfo) is calculated. This number is based on the number of OFDM symbols allocated, the resource elements carrying DMRS and the higher layer parameters.
