Based on the modulation order Qm, the code rate R Ninfo is calculated as Ninfo = S â NRE â R â Qm â Î½ (see Fig. 2-56, page 311). Î½ corresponds to the number of transmission layers. In this particular case, it is one spatial layer (= SISO operation). Only in case the PDSCH is assigned by the PDCCH with DCI format 1_0 where the CRC is scrambled with RA-RNTI, a scaling factor S is applied to the calculation of Ninfo. Values for the scaling factor S, based on bit settings within DCI format 1_0, are listed in Fig. 2-38.

TB scaling fieldScaling factor S
001
010.5
100.25
11Reserved

Fig. 2-38 Scaling factor of Ninfo for P-RNTI and RA-RNTI.

By successfully decoding DCI format 1_0, the UE has all required information to identify the physical resource blocks on the PDSCH that carry the random access response

Content of the random access response

The decoded transport blocks from the PDSCH form a MAC PDU that consists of one or more MAC subPDUs and optional padding. The presence and length of the padding are based on the available TB size and the size of the MAC subPDUs.

Each MAC subPDU consists of one of the following:

  • MAC subheader with backoff indicator (BI) only
  • MAC subheader with random access preamble identifier (RAPID) only
  • MAC subheader with RAPID and random access response (RAR)

Fig. 2-39 shows an example of a MAC PDU that carries a different type of information. For more details on processing of the MAC subheader with RAPID and RAR, including processing of the RAR and subsequent message 3 transmission, see 2.4 Overall access procedure for SA mode, page 408.

Backoff indicator (BI)

The UE may receive the backoff indicator (BI) with the MAC PDU. As the name implies, the BI enables the gNB to instruct the UE to back off for a period of time before attempting random access again. The six bits for BI can be used to set values in the range 5 ms to 1920 ms. In case there is no subMAC PDU, the UE sets the BI to 0 ms.

RAPID only

The MAC PDU may also contain a MAC subPDU that provides the random access preamble identifier (RAPID) only. This MAC subPDU is used to acknowledge to the UE that its transmitted random access preamble was successfully received by the network. RAPID only is a special case and is used by the network to respond to the case where the UE used the RACH procedure for the system information (SI) request.

RAPID and RAR

The common case is that the network is transmitting RAPID and RAR as the subMAC PDU. The RAR now contains specific information, dependent on which type of random access procedure was used: CFRA and CBRA. Fig. 2-39 shows for the RAR the common content when CBRA is used.

In non-standalone mode, the provided information is different. The purpose of using the RACH procedure in non-standalone mode is to establish uplink synchronization with the gNB. Any cellular network requires the transmissions from all terminals to arrive at the same time at the receiver of the base station to avoid interference. Therefore, terminals further away from the base station have to advance their transmission compared to devices that are close to the base station. This process is known as timing advance (TA). A UE is not allowed to make any transmission (other than the random access preamble) without the proper timing advance. The TA determined (and maintained) for the LTE connection cannot be used since the LTE eNB and 5G NR gNB might not be co-located and use different frequencies. Therefore, the gNB will determine the time delay based on the transmission of the random access preamble. This delay will be translated into the TA command that is sent as part of the RAR on the downlink. The timing advance (TA) command is 12 bits long and assumes values from 0 to 3846. The time alignment NTA is now calculated as NTA = TA.16.64/2Î¼, where Î¼ depends on the used subcarrier spacing.

Upon reception of the random access response (with the TA command only), the random access procedure (CFRA mode) is considered successful. Contention resolution (like for CBRA) is not required since the UE is uniquely identified by the dedicated RACH resources that were configured by the network and used by the UE to perform random access. At this point in time, the UE is fully synchronized to the gNB on the downlink as well as the uplink.

What if no random access response (RAR) is received?

If the random access response window expires and no random access response was received, the UE considers the procedure to be unsuccessful and increments the random access preamble transmission counter by 1. It continues this process until it has successfully received an RAR or the counter reaches its maximum. The maximum depends on the maximum number of allowed attempts to transmit the random access preamble, which was signaled to the UE (preambleTransMax in RACH-ConfigGeneric). If the counter reaches its maximum value, there are two options. First, the UE randomly chooses a value between 0 and the maximum value of the backoff indicator (BI, 1920 ms; see Fig. 2-39) before it selects a preamble and starts the random access procedure again. In CFRA, using dedicated resources, the UE may switch to CBRA.

2.2 Overall data transmission

The 5G system is a pure packet-switched network that supports data exchange between a UE and a data network. One motivating factor in 5G is to support various services known under the umbrella of the IMT2020 vision concept containing the three main services eMBB, mMTC and URLLC (Fig. 1-1). For these reasons, 5G NR highly focuses on supporting various quality of service profiles. For the sake of simplicity, we can say that 5G NR is a quality of service driven network. This QoS driven approach will have an impact on the overall 5G NR system, including the flexible architecture which covers aspects such as network slicing, a flexible protocol structure and a highly flexible radio interface. One should not restrict the understanding of the above term âdata networkâ to a remote data server in a traditional client-server architecture. 5G NR is much more flexible. Furthermore, several connection scenarios can be assumed, starting from the classic client-server connection of a UE to an external data network (as is known from the internet) through further connections where the packet data network or data server is part of the 5G system and described by terms such as mobile edge computing (MEC). There is even the future possibility that two UEs will communicate between one another, i.e. device-to-device (D2D). 5G NR supports data transfer procedures for all of these scenarios and the 5G system even inherits the flexibility to support data transfers for future scenarios. The general 5G system data transfer between a UE and a data network can be described with a buffer-based transmission model, i.e. first, a data transfer session is established and then in either direction (UL or DL), the pending data is stored in a data buffer. RAN only allocates radio resources to the DL or UL for buffered data. In the uplink direction, the UE can transmit over the air interface only if the gNB assigns radio resources. The radio resource for data transfer is described in the time and frequency domain. In the time domain, the transmitter in the UE or gNB can transmit only in specific time slots or OFDM symbols. In the frequency domain, the UE or gNB can send or receive only in dedicated physical resource blocks (PRB). The main goal of this chapter is to describe the procedures that are involved in the data transfer and explains how such data transfer is performed.

These procedures are briefly discussed in a top level overview in the next section. Later sections will provide greater detail.

End to end data session establishment procedure

This procedure establishes a packet data unit (PDU) session that transfers data packets between a UE and a data network. A PDU session involves several functions provided by the 5G core network, including session management (SMF), user plane functions (UPF) and access & mobility functions (AMF). From the protocol perspective, a signaling connection covering the non-access stratum (NAS) is established between the UE and the 5GC to perform control communications procedures such as registration procedure, security procedure or mobility procedure.

The protocol message flow for the end to end data session establishment procedure is depicted in Fig. 2-40 and details about it are provided in 2.2.1 End to end data session establishment procedure, page 280.

End to end quality of service

One important characteristic of a 5G system is strong support for various quality of service profiles. Unlike the analogy of a âcommunistic network, where all bits are equalâ, 5G NR supports multiple QoS profiles for data transfer. QoS profiles are used to guarantee a certain throughput (GBR), guarantee a certain throughput in latency critical situations (latency critical GBR) or offer data transfer services on a best effort basis for a so-called non-guaranteed bit rate (non-GBR) QoS profile. Parameters describing the various QoS profiles are guaranteed throughput, priority of the data packets among one other or vs. other connections, latency or delay, and packet loss ratio describing the reliability of the connection. To support QoS, 5G NR introduces a new protocol, the SDAP, which establishes a QoS flow between the UE and 5GC that can be summarized as a data tunnel through the entire network providing a certain QoS profile. Chapter 2.2.2 End to end quality of service, page 285 describes further details of the QoS aspects and how they will be configured and controlled within the 5G system. Note that the QoS aspects are visible in the entire description of 5G NR, even if not directly obvious. For example, consider the various 5G numerologies as a method to provide QoS profiles even on the radio interface.

Radio resource assignment and data reception

The procedures used for data transmission are the assignment procedures for radio resources on the uplink and downlink and the procedures related to data transfer. Later sections will explain these procedures in more detail, separated into procedures for UL and DL assignment and UL and DL data transfer.

First, the gNB may allocate resources on the downlink (2.2.3 DL resource assignment, page 295) when data for that specific UE is available on the gNB coming via the NG interface from the 5GC or EPC. There are various options for deployment of the 5G system architecture, and Fig. 1-4 shows more details on these various connection options for SA or NSA based architectures. The first downlink assignment happens after completion of the RRCSetupComplete which is called message 5 (Msg5) for a UE transferring from idle mode to connected mode (chapter 2.4 Overall access procedure for SA mode, page 408 provides more details on the RRC connection setup). The general downlink data reception model is based on a shared channel model for control and data. First, the shared scheduling control channel provides information about the content and ownership of the data channel and second, the shared data channel transmits user data with flexible and dynamic allocations. The two channels providing scheduling information and downlink data are the downlink data channel (PDSCH) and the downlink control channel (PDCCH), both described in 1.2.5.3 Physical channels in 5G NR, page 78. Since the PDCCH is shared between multiple UEs and in order to support the UE in knowing its specific assignments, the CRC is scrambled or marked with a UE-specific identifier (C-RNTI) that was allocated to the UE during the RRC connection setup procedure. The UE reads the content of this scheduling information (DCI) and knows the resource in time and frequency where to receive data on PDSCH. Further details about data scheduling procedures are found in 2.2.3 DL resource assignment, page 295.

The motivation behind shared channel operation is an increase in throughput from a network perspective as well as support for flexible allocation, i.e. adaptive modulation and coding schemes as well as dynamic resource allocation in time and frequency. This can be used to describe the performance of the downlink data channel (PDSCH) which also contains specific reference signals (DMRS) that support decoding and demodulation (2.2.4 DL data reception, page 307).

The radio resources on the uplink are assigned via PDCCH scheduling and are based on a similar concept to the downlink assignments. The CRC of the PDCCH is scrambled with a UE-specific identifier (RNTI). If the UE successfully detects its identity and thus decodes a DCI scheduling, it uses those assigned resources to transmit data on the UL over the uplink data channel PUSCH (2.2.8 UL data transmission, page 335) and waits for the next assignment on the DL or UL.

Uplink channel information (UCI)

To support the network scheduler in optimizing the MCS or with beamforming decisions, the UE is configured with UL resources to report feedback information on the DL channel status. One status information is the downlink signal quality reported as CQI feedback. It represents the result of regularly executed measurements estimating the signal quality of the DL reference signals. Due to this reporting of the radio signal quality status, the gNB can optimize the assignment of the next resource with an appropriate MCS for the current channel condition. Since 5G NR is a beamforming-based technology, the UE can be configured to provide feedback on the channel status that can be obtained based on channel status reference signals (CSI-RS). The reporting can be configured in a very flexible way by the RRC protocol layer. What has to be reported, when and in what quantity, to name a few possibilities. See 2.2.9 Uplink control information (UCI), page 340 for further details on reporting.

HARQ operation

To ensure proper transfer of data packets, a feedback mechanism is applied that is familiar from LTE. The mechanism known as the hybrid acknowledge repeat (HARQ) acknowledges the data transmission on the DL. Each data packet is automatically acknowledged and is retransmitted if necessary. To support higher data throughput for a single receiver, there can be multiple receive processes in parallel known as HARQ processes. Such a HARQ process includes data processing steps such as demodulation, decoding, consistency check based on CRC and transmission of ACK/NACK feedback. Retransmission can be handled similar to the initial transmission or with a modified puncturing scheme known as the redundancy version. In the uplink HARQ, the UE transmits HARQ feedback to confirm reception of DL data via a physical control channel (PUCCH) or PUSCH. If this feedback is a negative acknowledgement, the network will retransmit the data packet. In the downlink direction, there is no direct HARQ feedback channel like the PHICH channel from LTE. The gNB uses a new data bit (NDI) in the scheduling message to request either a new data packet or the retransmission of a previous one.

A major difference compared to LTE is the flexible configuration and handling of timing aspects for the HARQ operation. There is no longer a constant time between reception of a data packet and its corresponding HARQ feedback or consecutive retransmission. These timings can be configured on a bilateral basis between the UE and network by the RRC layer. Further details on the HARQ procedure are given in 2.2.5 Hybrid automatic repeat request (HARQ) operation, page 318.

Scheduling request and buffer status reporting

As soon as higher application request data transmission, the UE needs to request resources to transmit on the UL. The data transmission is based on a transmission buffer concept in which pending data for transmission is placed in a buffer waiting to be transferred. When no radio connection is established, the UE starts the establishment of an RRC connection setup as a first step via a random access procedure (see 2.1 Overall access procedure for NSA mode, page 219 and 2.4 Overall access procedure for SA mode, page 408 for details). After completion of the random access procedure, the UE receives the first UL grant in the RRCConnectionSetup (LTE) or RRCSetup (5G NR) message known as message 4 (Msg4). This represents the procedure for a UE-originated data connection or PDU session for UE outgoing data. If there is an ongoing PDU session but the UE needs to request UL resources for additional data transmission, it will request resources with the UL grant procedure using a specific PUCCH scheduling request message (see 2.2.6 Uplink scheduling request and buffer status reporting, page 326 for further details). The objective of this scheduling request procedure is to receive permission to transmit data via the physical data channel (PUSCH) on the UL (see 2.2.7 UL grant reception or UL assignment, page 329).

As was already mentioned, the goal of the 5G system is to allow resource allocation and quality of service association for data transmission in a flexible way. To support the scheduler within the network in its decision on how many radio resources should be scheduled to that UE in case of an ongoing PDU session with uplink data transfer cases, the UE periodically transmits a buffer status report (BSR) to inform the gNB of the amount of data that is pending to be transmitted. See Fig. 2-98, page 375 for further details on BSR reporting.

Data flow through the 5G NR protocol stack

The 5G NR protocol stack is divided into a user plane (UP) and a control plane (CP). From a general perspective, the protocol layers have similar functions to those known from LTE, but some differences are worth mentioning. First, there is a new protocol layer introduced for QoS flow management. The SDAP layer at the highest position in the 5G NR user plane stratum manages QoS aspects. The PDCP layer supports security procedures, the data radio bearer procedure and the mechanisms for carrier aggregation or DC due to the introduction of an optional split bearer concept. The radio link protocol (RLC) offers the well known transfer modes AM, UM and TM. Unlike in LTE, 5G NR no longer supports the option to concatenate data packets; only segmentation is possible. This change in RLC was introduced to support latency-critical QoS profiles. The MAC layer offers a wide range of procedures supporting data transfer such as logical channels to the transport channel mapping and control functions such as timing advance control or buffer status and power headroom reporting. See 2.2.10 Data flow through 5G NR protocol layers, page 349 for further details on the 5G NR protocol structure procedures.

Dynamic, semi-persistent and grant-free scheduling

As a ubiquitous and universal mobile communications standard, the 5G system supports several types of data transmission depending on what kind of services are requested. If the UE or network needs sporadic data transmission, this refers to dynamic scheduling. In the downlink direction, the gNB uses the PDCCH scheduling channel to send DCI messages scheduling radio resources to the UE. In the uplink direction, assuming a radio connection has been established via RRC procedures, the radio resources for the PUSCH are assigned via DCI scheduling on the PDCCH. The scheduling request procedure provides a method to request more resources on the uplink. It describes the situation where the UE requests a specific buffer size on the UL with a scheduling request and the gNB assigns in one or more assignments the requested radio resources permitting the clearance of the data transmission buffer. If the UE requires data constantly, for periodic transmission (such as video or voice services), then the procedure is described as semi-persistent scheduling, or grant-free scheduling if configured by the RRC layer. After the first scheduling request, the UE is granted periodic assignments in time and in frequency without the need to repeat the request (see 2.2.11 Dynamic, semi-persistent and grant-free scheduling, page 382).

Data security

5G NR is expected to support a wide range of applications expanding the legacy voice and subscriber data centric behavior of a network to multiple tenants and multiple services such as automotive and industrial applications, mission-critical applications and medical or financial services, to mention a few examples. Thus, data security is becoming a vital aspect of future mobile communications networks. 5G NR security procedures include ciphering to avoid eavesdropping, authentication to avoid subscriber fraud, and integrity protection to avoid non-authorized control messages like man in the middle attacks. Chapter 2.2.12 Data security, page 384 provides a brief overview of 5G NR security procedures.

Recalling chapter 1.1.2 Overall 5G architecture, page 12, we will now review the two different connection types: NSA mode where LTE is in joint operation with 5G NR and SA mode where 5G NR is operated solely. Summarizing the message flows and connection establishment, Fig. 2-42 and Fig. 2-40 illustrate the connection setup. In EN-DC mode, first the LTE connection is established and afterwards, the 5G NR connection is established using the RRCReconfiguration message procedure. For SA mode, the 5G NR connection is established in a similar procedure to that known from LTE: First, an RRC signaling radio bearer is established via the random access procedure and after the NAS security and authentication procedures, a data connection is activated.

The following sections describe these UL and DL data transfer procedures in greater detail.

2.2.1 End to end data session establishment procedure

Data transmission between the UE and 5G network requires establishment of a packet data unit (PDU) session and involves logical 5GC functions such as SMF, UPF and AMF. A PDU session or connectivity service provides the exchange of data packets between a UE and a data network, identified by a data network name (DNN). The data network DNN can be considered as the LTE access point name (APN). The session management works in close cooperation with the registration management and connection management, i.e. it is based on interaction between SMF, UPF and AMF (see 1.1.2.4 Functional split between 5GC and NG-RAN, page 17 for further details). The session management is part of the NAS protocol structure. The term non-access stratum represents a protocol structure, and thus not just a single layer. It is called non-access as it is independent and on-top of the underlying protocol structure controlling the radio interface, i.e. the âaccessâ Â­layers.

The registration management, led by the AMF, performs a registration of the UE with the network to receive services that require registration. The registration is updated by the UE in three situations: First, based on a mobility triggered registration update, i.e. registration area change or PLMN re-selection, second based on a periodic time requiring a periodic registration update, or third based on a capability update or renegotiation of protocols. The registration procedure is performed via the exchange of the NAS control messages Registration Update, Registration Accept for the successful case or Registration Reject for the unsuccessful case. The registration status is stored in a registration state on both sides, one in the UE and one in the AMF, as shown in Fig. 2-43:

Connection management (CM) is the function that takes care of communications between the AMF and the UE. It comprises the functions of establishing and releasing a signaling connection between a UE and the AMF over the N1 interface. This signaling connection is used to enable a NAS signaling exchange between the UE and the core network.

The CM procedures are started after the access stratum (AS) procedures having successfully established an RRC connection that is used to exchange higher layer protocol information. The connection management is used to exchange

NAS control information for either the NAS connection between UE and the 5GC, UE connection related control information or network control information that is connection related. Like the registration management, also the connection management is based on a state model. A UE can be in CM-IDLE or CM-CONNECTED state. A UE in CM-IDLE state has no NAS signaling connection established. This is the state when having successfully established an RRC connection but not yet a CM connection for NAS messages. In this state, the UE performs cell selection/re-selection and PLMN selection. It is possible that the UE is in RM-REGISTERED state and in CM-IDLE. In such a case, the UE listens and responds to paging messages triggered by NG-RAN and it may perform a Service Request signaling procedure in case user data has to be sent. The transmission of an initial NAS message such as a registration request, service request or deregistration request initiates the transition from CM-IDLE to CM-CONNECTED state (see Fig. 2-44). It is possible for the UE to be in CM-CONNECTED state but in RRC_INACTIVE state. In such situations, the UE reachability is managed by the NG-RAN and the paging or channel access procedures are used to transfer into the RRC active state (TS 23.501).

PDU session

For each UE, 5GC establishes one or more PDU sessions. A PDU session should be understood as the connectivity service that supports the exchange of protocol data units (PDU) between a UE and a data network. Since 5G is understood as a quality of service driven technology, there is a certain QoS profile (better known as a QoS flow) accompanying a PDU session. For more details on QoS flow aspects in 5G, see 2.2.2 End to end quality of service, page 285. The responsible entity in the network to handle the PDU session is the session management function (SMF). Note that the SMF belongs to the NAS protocol stack like the access and mobility function (AMF), but both entities are independent. TS 23.501 describes the interaction between both entities. The subscription information of the connectivity service may include multiple data network names and it may contain a default DNN to which the UE is assigned in case of a missing valid DNN in a PDU session establishment request procedure. Examples of PDU sessions are the IP PDU session (supporting both IPv4 and IPv6), the Ethernet PDU session and the unstructured PDU session. Note that each PDU session supports only a single PDU session type. The Ethernet PDU session type uses the SMF and UPF as the session anchor and supports specific behaviors related to the fact that the PDU session carries Ethernet frames and no IP data packets. Allowing some flexibility in architecture deployment, operators can configure whether either the UPF can act as an anchor or redirect traffic via the SMF. An example is the usage of mobile edge computing where a remote MEC inherits some UPF functions and provides a lower latency QoS flow. Protocol details regarding Ethernet such as the Ethernet preamble and start of frame delimiter will not be sent over the PDU session and also no IP or MAC address will be allocated to the UE for this PDU session.

In addition, the 5G PDU session supports the unstructured PDU session type, allowing different point-to-point tunneling techniques based on UDP/IPv6 tunneling to send unstructured PDU type data. A probable motivation for such an option could be to serve a network tenant that wants to orchestrate his own data network on proprietary protocol profiles based on a 5G system where it would be up to the negotiation between the 5G system operator and the 5G tenant to agree on the implementation details. See TS 23.501 for more information about the tunneling techniques allowed in 5GC. The NG-RAN establishes for each UE at least one data radio bearer (DRB) together with the PDU session. Additional DRB(s) for QoS flow(s) of that PDU session can be subsequently configured, based on scheduling decisions by the network. The mapping of QoS flows to data radio bearers (DRB) is decided by the network and is flexible. First, the end to end data connection can be described as a session data flow (SDF) and one SDF is described by its type of service. Such a SDF is associated with a QoS flow and later, there can be several QoS flows mapped onto the same DRB or various QoS flows can be mapped on various DRBs. Later in this section, further details are given.

PDU sessions are established, modified and released using NAS session management signaling messages exchanged between the UE and the SMF. The SMF is responsible for checking whether the UE session requests are compliant with the user subscription in cooperation with the data management in the UPF. A PDU session is described and stored with certain attributes, linked to the DNN and if applicable also the network slice via the parameter S-NSSAI:

  • PDU session ID to uniquely identify one of a UE's PDU sessions
  • PDU session type and optionally a default PDU session type, both given as one of the values IPv4, IPv6, Ethernet or unstructured
  • Quality of service information, i.e. session AMBR, default 5QI, default ARP (see 2.2.2 End to end quality of service, page 285)
  • Session and service continuity mode
  • Data network name (DNN)
  • Single network slice selection assistance information S-NSSAI if applicable
  • Static IP address or IPv6 prefix if applicable

A UE can establish multiple PDU sessions. They may even end at various SMF entities and thus support the network slicing concept. A PDU session is RAT agnostic, thus a PDU session can either be 3GPP RAN based like 5G NR or EUTRAN, or it can involve non-3GPP access, e.g. WLAN. Another proof of the total flexibility of 5G systems is visible by contemplating the overall possibilities of PDU data sessions that are offered by the system. The following PDU session details are supported, for example:

  • A single PDU session with multiple PDU session anchors implies the possibility that one UPF is connected via multiple N6 interfaces to the data network to support selective traffic routing functions
  • Support for local area data network, meaning that data network access is only available in a specific service area, described as a set of tracking areas
  • Secondary authentication/authorization by a DN-AAA server during the establishment of a PDU session, representing either a kind of two-stage security procedure performed by the 5GC and by the external data network or the option that the SMF passes the authentication/authorization information for the UE to the data network AAA server
  • Selective activation and deactivation of a user plane connection for an existing PDU session in case the UE has established multiple PDU sessions

Session and service continuity (SSC)

This function guarantees the session and service mobility for certain mobility or access network change procedures. In the current version of the specification, three SSC modes are supported. They are associated with the PDU session and do not change during the lifetime of the PDU session:

  • Seamless session and service continuity with SSC mode 1: The network preserves the connectivity service provided to the UE. For the case of a PDU session of the IPv4 or IPv6 type, the IP address is preserved. The UPF acting as PDU session anchor is maintained regardless of the access technology, thus SSC mode 1 would enable any kind of inter-RAT mobility, even between 3GPP access and non-3GPP access networks, similar to the idea of WAN offloading that has been applied in LTE for some time. SSC mode 1 can be used as the general session continuity function providing a certain latency and session continuity for data services that require a kind of latency and guaranteed bit rate (e.g. voice or video services).
  • Non-seamless session and service continuity with SSC mode 2: The network may release the connectivity service delivered to the UE and release the corresponding PDU session. If a continuation is required, a new PDU session would have to be established. For the case of the IPv4 or IPv6 type, the network may release IP address(es) that were allocated to the UE. In case of a single PDU session anchor, the network may trigger the release of this PDU session and instruct the UE to establish a new PDU session to the same data network immediately after the access network change. The SSC mode 2 can be understood as the service continuity mode that is applied when latency aspects are less critical, e.g. a standard web browsing application that can tolerate certain delays or interruptions.
  • SSC mode 3 is the seamless session and service continuity funtion for either a latency-critical or interruption-critical data connection. It avoids interruption by applying a âmake before breakâ mechanism. With SSC mode 3, changes to the user plane can be visible to the UE, while the network ensures that the UE suffers no loss of connectivity. A connection through a new PDU session anchor point is established before the previous connection is terminated in order to ensure better service continuity. For the case of the IPv4 or IPv6 type, the IP address is not preserved in this mode when the PDU session anchor changes, but the network supports IPv6 address multi-homing or maintains the old IP address for a certain time to avoid any data losses. This SSC 3 mode may be used in cases where the interruption time should be minimized, especially for new services in the background of URLLC like autonomous driving vehicles.

The network may provide the UE with a policy of SSC selection, but it is up to the network to accept the UE requested SSC mode or to renegotiate or reject the proposal.

2.2.2 End to end quality of service

Universal and ubiquitous mobile communications technologies like the 5G system are much more than just a âbit pipeâ to provide a binary data connection between two endpoints in a kind of âcommunist â all bits are equalâ approach. Furthermore, there is a requirement to offer sufficient quality of experience within different data connection services. The challenge for a universal communications system is the plethora of data connections outlining a multitude of diverse data transmission behaviors, e.g. continuous data transmission vs. sporadic data transmission, periodic data transmission vs. incident driven data, lower latency requirements, requirements for a guaranteed bit rate or priority definition for different data connections among one other, just to name a few examples. Unlike previous technologies, 5GS is designed to serve multiple vertical industry use cases and service types. The technology enablers offer flexibility that allows the optimization of each vertical industry use case, but vertical industries are very diverse and their performance requirements are dictated by the service characteristics of the related vertical segment. End to end QoS support implies various use of 5G technology enablers due to diverse service-specific requirements. A current study item in 3GPP investigates the need for further service-specific requirement specification, e.g. medical requirements, unmanned aerial vehicles or industrial process automation.

As an abstract definition of certain IP flows, the term service data flow (SDF) is used. A service data flow (SDF) is one or an aggregation of IP flows classified by the type of service in use.

Later, such an SDF is linked to a QoS flow. The binding mechanism is the procedure that associates a service data flow with the QoS flow deemed to transport the service data flow [TS 23.503]. Therefore, the capability should be implemented in a 5G system to handle various data connections with different QoS requirements simultaneously. Thus, one of the key features of the 5G system is not only the flexibility and the wide support for various service scenarios such as eMBB, but also the capability to negotiate, guarantee and supervise a quality of service profile on a bilateral basis. We tend to describe an expression like 5G system within the context of a quality of service driven technology, and one can observe such QoS aspects in all stages of the protocol layers. Different terms are introduced in the concept of a QoS service model. As a first definition, one should consider the term QoS characteristic, described as a data treatment policy within the overall network including all protocol layers for the forwarding of data. According to the definition of QoS parameters, two entities can exchange QoS characteristics in control messages. A set of QoS parameters belonging to such a data connection is grouped into a QoS profile. To guarantee the simultaneous provisioning of different QoS characteristics, the term QoS flow is used.

A simplified example helps clarify these expressions. Given a data connection between a UE and the 5G network, a QoS characteristic could be the negotiation of a guaranteed bit rate. The QoS parameter is the term âguaranteed bit rateâ that is used in communications between the UE and network and is analogous to the statement âfor a video call, I need a guaranteed bit rate of 10 Mbpsâ. Now, this guaranteed bit rate is, for example, combined with a priority configuration among other packets and this is now the QoS profile that both entities will use. Finally, the simplified description of the QoS flow to be the finest granularity could be the agreement of a data connection that guarantees a bit rate of 12 Mbps with a deviation of Â±1 Mbps. As QoS characteristics, the 5G system considers the following parameters:

  • Data rate or throughput that can be guaranteed or not, known as GBR or non-GBR data flows
  • Motivated by potential new URLLC services, the 5G system also offers GBR QoS with latency critical requirements
  • Priority level to prioritize data flows among one other
  • Packet delay budget signifying the latency control
  • Packet error rate as a kind of measure of the PDU connection quality or error probability and reliability of the end to end connection

QoS flow

Based on the 5GS quality of service model, the term QoS flow is specified in TS 23.501. A QoS flow represents the finest granularity of QoS differentiation in the PDU session and is identified within a PDU session by a unique QoS flow ID (QFI) in the 5G system. The scheduling function and admission control function in the network entities guarantee the same traffic forwarding treatment for user plane traffic having the same QFI within a PDU session. Three type of QoS flows are supported: QoS flows that require a guaranteed flow bit rate (GBR), QoS flows with a GBR that are latency critical, and QoS flows that do not require a guaranteed flow bit rate (non-GBR). Data connections can be different regarding their QoS requirements and in addition they may be direction-dependent. Thus, the QoS flow is allocated independently per direction (downlink and uplink). The characteristics of the QoS flow on the downlink are decided by the network. There are two ways to assign the QoS flow characteristics for the uplink. As the first option, the QoS flow parameters are negotiated between the UE and network via higher layer signaling.

As the second option, the 5G QoS model supports reflective QoS, i.e. the QoS flow on the uplink reflects the QoS flow settings on the downlink. Such mechanisms reduce the control overhead especially for bi-directional services such as a typical voice call between two humans in a voice over 5G connection. There is the option for direct negotiation of QoS flow parameters between the UE and 5GC with a corresponding QFI allocation. To simplify the negotiation, default QoS characteristics are defined, indicated by the identifier 5QI, and optionally the network can use this 5QI scalar value as the QFI value. A 5QI is a scalar that is used as a reference to predefined 5G QoS characteristics (see Fig. 2-46 for details). Within the 5G system, the entity responsible for QoS flow control, establishment or reconfiguration via the PDU session establishment or modification procedure is the SMF (see also 1.1.2.4 Functional split between 5GC and NG-RAN, page 17.) Any QoS flow is characterized by:

  • A set of parameters describing the QoS policy of data forwarding treatment, given as a QoS profile. Examples of predefined QoS profiles are given in Fig. 2-46
  • One or more QoS rules are provided by the SMF to the UE. A QoS rule can be interpreted as a mapping profile of how to define QoS flow parameters for uplink data. Alternatively, the network can configure the UE for reflective QoS flows, in which case, the uplink QoS flow profile is copied from the downlink QoS profile
  • One or more service data flow (SDF) templates. An SDF can be simplified as an IP flow or an aggregation of IP flows of user traffic classified by the type of service in use. It is defined in TS 23.501 as: âThe set of Service Data Flow filters in a policy rule or an application identifier in a policy rule referring to an application detection filter, required for defining a Service Data Flowâ

QoS profile and QoS parameters

As was already mentioned, 5G provides support for various diversified data connections inheriting various requirements for the quality of service characteristics. Clearly, end-to-end data connections require a minimum throughput to ensure a satisfactory user experience, e.g. voice or video transfer, while other connection types, e.g. background traffic, are more tolerant of fluctuating data rates. This variance is supported by the introduction of a QoS profile concept in 5G. This profile can be described as a set of parameters to control and maintain a data flow with the required data forward treatment characteristics. Such a QoS profile is identified with an ID value known as the QFI, which can either be a scalar value assigned randomly by the network, or if default QoS profile characteristics are used, the QFI can be replaced by the QoS characteristic identifier 5GI.

As the first distinction, three types of QoS profiles are defined: one that is based on a guaranteed data rate (guaranteed flow bit rate or GBR), one for a non-guaranteed flow bit rate (non-GBR) and in addition, to support URLLC, there is a new definition of delay-critical GBR bit rates. These are not the only definition parameters for a QoS profile. There are additional parameters to describe a QoS profile, but unfortunately they are somewhat abstract. The definition of a QoS profile is based on two expressions: QoS parameters and QoS characteristics. What is the difference between them? As a QoS parameter, we may understand the definition of information that is exchanged during a conversation. By using an analogy, we may understand the QoS parameter as the repository or list of allowed words in a language dictionary. For example, during the QoS profile negotiation the UE and SMF may exchange these QoS parameters to define the QoS profile. The detailed content or better, the definition of a policy that represents the QoS aspects for data forward treatment, is then called the QoS characteristic. Using our example with the language or dictionary terms as the QoS parameters, the QoS characteristics are then the âfederal constitutionâ of our data forward treatment policy. To give another example to clarify the difference between QoS parameters and QoS characteristics: As a parameter, 5G defines the allocation and retention priority (ARP), which is a parameter to negotiate the possibility of setting a priority level for data flows. The corresponding QoS characteristics in one QoS profile could then be, for example, a priority level of 8 in a range of priority levels from 1 to 15. Thus, a QoS profile is described with these parameters:

  • A 5G QoS identifier (5QI), which is a scalar used to refer to QoS characteristics, such as negotiated data forward treatment values, e.g. GBR or non-GBR type, priority level, packet delay budget for latency aspects or packet error rate for classification of the vulnerability tolerance of the overall PDU session. 5G defines some default QoS characteristics in TS 23.501 (see Fig. 2-46 for details). In addition, it is possible to negotiate the QoS characteristics bilaterally between the UE and network
  • An allocation and retention priority (ARP) parameter containing information about the priority level, pre-emption capability and pre-emption vulnerability. The priority level defines the relative importance of a resource request and influences data packet forwarding within the network entities, especially when data buffers are pending for the next transmission. In addition, the priority allows a decision on whether a new QoS flow may be accepted or must be rejected in case of resource limitations or congestion situations. The entity responsible for this function is the access and mobility management function (AMF). It may also be used to decide which existing QoS flow to pre-empt during resource limitations occurring e.g. in hot spots when the number of users becomes very large and thus the prevailing capacity has to be distributed over a higher number of users. Note that the priority level does not speed up the actual data packet flow (since radio waves travel at the speed of light which represents a physical limit), but the priority level is a parameter of priority among other packets, e.g. from other users or other data connections, and may influence the buffer flow in case of congestion scenarios or limited capacity. The range of the ARP priority level is from 1 to 15 where 1 is the highest level of priority. The pre-emption capability information defines whether a service data flow may obtain resources that were already assigned to another service data flow with a lower priority level. In terms of the signaled value, the pre-emption capability is either âyesâ or ânoâ. The same is also valid for the pre-emption vulnerability information, which defines whether a service data flow may lose the resources assigned to it in order to admit a service data flow with higher priority level
  • A reflective QoS attribute (RQA) optionally for each non-GBR QoS flow. As was mentioned above, this parameter indicates that the uplink QoS flow uses the same profile as the dowlink QoS flow
  • For each GBR QoS flow, the expected bit rate that will be provided per QoS flow in either the UL and DL direction, given by the two values guaranteed flow bit rate (GFBR) and maximum flow bit rate (MFBR). The MFBR limits the bit rate to be provided based on a subscription profile of a user. Here, we can imagine the marketing potential based on the ability to provide different subscription data rates depending on the maximum speed
  • The sessionaggregate maximum bit rate (AMBR) as an aggregate rate limiting QoS parameter that is derived from the subscription profile
  • Notification control is used in case of GBR QoS flows to indicate whether notifications are requested from the RAN when the guaranteed bit rate can no longer be fulfilled for a QoS flow during the lifetime of the QoS flow. In such instances, the 5GC may take further actions such as suspending the QoS flow or renegotiating the QoS flow parameters
  • The maximum packet loss rate in either the UL and DL direction, representing the maximum rate for lost packets of the QoS flow that can be tolerated

For the uplink direction, the UE uses certain rules to classify and mark the uplink data packets and to associate or map them onto QoS flows. Such rules can either be explicitly provided by higher layer signaling during the QoS negotiation procedures or they may be preconfigured in the UE or implicitly derived from the downlink rules in case reflective QoS flow is applied. Such rules contain values such as the QFI, a QoS parameter set, a precedence value and a packet filter set. There is the possibility of a default QoS rule being chosen. The specification TS 23.501 describes a QoS flow model that indicates how the QoS mapping procedure is handled within the 5G system in either the uplink or downlink direction. In the downlink direction, the entities SMF and UPF cooperate in mapping steps such as the binding of an SDF to QoS flows based on the QoS and service requirements. The SMF assigns the QFI for a new QoS flow and derives its QoS profile from the information provided by the policy control function PCF. In case reflective QoS is applicable, the SMF provides the QFI together with the QoS profile to the 5G-(R)AN for the UL traffic.

As already introduced, we can consider 5G as a QoS driven technology and the QoS requirements should not only be negotiated but also maintained and controlled in an ongoing data connection. The methodology in 5G for QoS maintenance is enhanced compared to legacy mobile radio technologies, i.e. the general idea of network slicing is just one example thereof. Another aspect is the configuration of QoS parameters throughout the entire 5G network: Not just a label that is applied to a data packet for forwarding treatment policies, but furthermore, the 5G QoS flow will impact the mapping decisions throughout the 5G network and protocol stack. We refer to Fig. 1-9 illustrating the channel mapping throughout the network. On the top level, the QoS flow is defined and the lower layers within the stack apply the mapping according to this QoS flow. Relevant details are explained in this section:

Due to the fact that the 5G system supports various types of services and data flows and as a term to distinguish the various data flows, a so-called session data flow (SDF) is introduced. An SDF is an IP flow or an aggregation of IP flows of user traffic classified by the type of the service in use. For each SDF, when applicable, the SMF generates a QoS rule. Each of these QoS rules contains the QoS rule identifier, the QFI for the QoS flow, the packet filter set for the UL part of the SDF template, optionally the packet filter set for the DL part of the SDF template, and the QoS rule precedence value set to the precedence value for the PCF rule from which the QoS rule is generated. The QoS rules are then provided to the UE. The principle of classification and marking of user plane traffic and mapping of QoS flows to AN resources is illustrated in Fig. 2-45 (TS 23.501). On the DL, incoming data packets are classified by the UPF based on SDF templates. The UPF conveys the classification of the user plane traffic belonging to a QoS flow through the 5GC interface N3 or N9 by marking the user plane data with the QoS identifier QFI. The RAN binds QoS flows to AN resources, which in 5G NR scenarios are the data radio bearers (DRB). Note that there is not a strict 1:1 relationship between QoS flows and DRB resources. It is up to the RAN to establish the necessary RAN resources that QoS flows can be mapped to, and to release them. The RAN must indicate to the SMF when the RAN resources on which a QoS flow is mapped are released. On the UL, the UE evaluates UL packets against the packet filter set in the QoS rules based on the precedence value of QoS rules in increasing order until a matching QoS rule is found. The UE uses the QFI in the matching QoS rule to bind the UL packet to a QoS flow and then binds QoS flows to RAN resources.

5G QoS characteristics

The characteristics of the packet forwarding treatment that a QoS flow receives between the UE and the UPF are described as QoS characteristics and are defined based on certain performance characteristics. Note that the QoS characteristics are maintained and controlled within the 5G system only. Thus, it does not correspond to the end-to-end connection between the UE and a probable external data network. The QoS characteristics are given as a set of performance characteristics that can either be negotiated individually or can use some of the default QoS characteristics identified with the 5QI scalar.

  • The resource type has the following possible values: guaranteed bit rate (GBR), delay critical GBR or non-GBR. The type determines if the network resources related to a QoS flow are permanently allocated and controlled (as in the case of GBR QoS flows) or if they are preauthorized through a static policy and charging control or billing function at the initiation (as in the non-GBR QoS flow cases). In addition to LTE, now in 5G NR there is a resource type for QoS flow treatment indicated as delay critical GBR, supporting the URLLC service. The major difference between GBR and delay critical GBR is the setting of the packet delay budget and packet loss rate
  • The priority level, indicating a priority in scheduling resources among QoS flows. The priority levels are used to differentiate between QoS flows for the same UE. This happens especially in multi-connection situations and must also be used to differentiate between QoS flows from different UEs. In addition, there is the ARP priority that influences the establishment of new QoS flows, especially in congestion situations. In 5G NR, priority levels from 1 to 15 are specified, where 1 is the highest priority, and there is a difference in priority level settings when either in the HPLMN environment or under roaming conditions (see TS 23.501 for further details)
  • The packet delay budget (PDB) defines an upper bound for the time that a packet may be delayed between the UE and the UPF, and thus represents a very important QoS characteristic for supporting URLLC services. If standardized QoS characteristics are used by certain 5QIs, the value of the PDB is the same on the UL and DL. As specified in TS 23.501, the PDB is interpreted with a confidence level of 98 % and in case of delay-critical GBR QoS flows, a packet arriving later than the PDB is considered to be lost
  • The packet error rate (PER) defines an upper bound for the rate of lost data packets. For some 5QIs, the value for PER is the same for the UL and DL. Refer to TS 23.501 for the exact definition of when a packet is considered to be lost. This can involve, for example, a CRC checksum failure detected on lower layers or a PDU that arrives delayed beyond the tolerated waiting time such as the PDB
  • The averaging window for GBR QoS flows represents the duration over which the GFBR and MFBR must be calculated
  • The maximum data burst volume represents the largest amount of data that the 5G access network is required to serve within a period of time (specified as the 5G-AN PDB in TS 23.501, typically 20 ms)

As indicated above, these QoS characteristics may be signaled via higher layers or there may be a direct mapping of the 5QI to the corresponding QoS characteristics as shown in Fig. 2-46.

5QI valueResource typeDefault priority levelPacket delay budgetPacket error rateDefault m aximum data burst volumeDefault
averaging window		Example services
1GBR20100 ms10â2N/A2000 msConversational voice

Fig. 2-46 QoS characteristics. Standardized 5QI to QoS characteristics mapping [TS 23.501]

2.2.3 DL resource assignment

A cellular system for mobile communications shares resources on the air interface among all UEs in the same cell. Each UE is allowed to receive data on the downlink, either initiated by a network in a UE-terminated data connection or initiated by the UE in a UE-originated data connection, when the UE starts an application that requires the reception of downlink data traffic. In both cases, the network decides when and which radio resources in time and frequency can be assigned to that specific UE.

A data connection can only happen after the UE has successfully established an RRC connection (see Fig. 2-40). The first step in this procedure in cellular communications is the cell acquisition performed by the UE and described in 2.1.1.1 LTE cell search, selection and system information acquisition, page 219, and 2.4.3 Random access procedure in standalone mode, page 416.

After cell acquisition, the UE is in idle mode, also known as âcamping on a cellâ. In this stage, the UE has to obtain system information and paging information and performs mobility management related procedures such as cell reselection. When triggered by higher layers or paging, either a mobile originated or mobile terminated data connection has to be established using a data bearer setup procedure (see Fig. 2-40). In both modes, idle or connected mode, the UE has to react to assignment messages sent in the downlink direction on the PDCCH channel. The whereabouts of this PDCCH control channel is given by control resources allocated to the UE via RRC signaling, the so-called control resource set (CORESET) as further described in 1.2.5.4 Control resource set CORESET, page 94. The PDCCH will not only contain scheduling information for the downlink, but also scheduling information for the uplink direction (see 2.2.7 UL grant reception or UL assignment, page 329 for details about assignment of UL resources). Fig. 2-47 explains the used channels in a simplified manner: The UE wants to read system information, paging information or downlink data, all sent via the physical data channel (PDSCH). To obtain information on how and where these resources are scheduled, it acquires initial scheduling control information via the PDCCH channel.

The network uses the control resource set (CORESET) to send DCI control information. Further details on the DCI control information are discussed in the section Downlink control information (DCI), page 302. A UE monitors the assigned CORESET resources and when it recognizes a DL resource assignment via a DCI containing a CRC scrambled with its identifier C-RNTI, it will redirect to data channel PDSCH. Unlike in LTE, in 5G NR the situation regarding assignment can be slightly more complex, as it allows a higher degree of flexibility in both the frequency and in the time domain. Frequency resource assignments are based on the term resource block and can be understood as the granularity of frequency spectrum for allocation of PDSCH or PUSCH resources. A resource block in 5G is defined as a unit in the frequency domain of 12 subcarriers, but unlike LTE, a 5G resource block does not bear any duration in the time domain (see 1.2.2 Resource grid, page 56 for further details). Regarding resource allocation in the time domain, 5G offers more flexibility. LTE uses the concept of a transmit time interval (TTI) representing the granularity of time domain allocation with a fixed duration of 1 ms, which coincides with the duration of one subframe in LTE. This means the LTE control channel PDCCH schedules to a specific UE always the full duration of one subframe, comprising two slots. In 5G NR, the time duration of the PDSCH allocation can be more flexible. It introduces the so-called mini-slot offering a flexible length of two or more OFDM symbols and a flexible start within one subframe. For this reason, there can be multiple configuration options regarding the position and duration of the control information Â­CORESET. Just to give a few examples of how complex such a scheduling situation can become, the Fig. 2-48 and Fig. 2-49 describe such situations. As a kind of simple configuration which is more LTE-like, the PDCCH containing the CORESET advances the PDSCH within one slot. In this case, the scheduling period that can be obtained refers to the slot boundary. In addition to the flexible allocation of the control information CORESET, the PDSCH also comprises a flexible number of OFDMA symbols that are scheduled and has flexible start, indicated by the value SLIV, as further described in 2.2.4 DL data reception, page 307. One reason for such a scheduling configuration could be more flexible multiplexing of various UEs inheriting various QoS flow requirements, i.e. within one slot, the CORESET schedules a mini-slot to a UE with latency-critical QoS parameters and a longer OFDM symbol allocation to a UE with a focus on a higher data rate.

With the more complex configuration of CORESET due to the introduction of the mini-slot, it would now be possible for CORESET to overlap in the time domain with data and even for multiple CORESETs to overlap in time. In such a configuration, the UE is challenged to receive scheduling and data information simultaneously [Ref. 29]. A possible motivation for such a scheduling decision could be the simultaneous reception of data and system information updates, to give just one example.

Radio network temporary identifier (RNTI)

As described above, the CORESET contains control information (DCI) to schedule resource assignment on the PDSCH. We might wonder how the UE knows that the scheduling message belongs to it and what kind of scheduling message is sent. We need some type of name or identifier to address the proper receiving entity. This identifier on the physical layer is known as RNTI and several RNTIs exist for various purposes. Some of those RNTI values are common and known to every UE while other RNTI values are UE specific. The network allocates the UE specific RNTI values during initial access or RRC connection setup or reconfiguration procedures.

Radio network temporary identifiers in 5G NR:

  • Cell RNTI (C-RNTI) â unique and UE-specific identifier used to schedule UE-specific data on PDSCH or UL allocation on PUSCH
  • System information RNTI (SI-RNTI) for indication of SIB broadcast on PDSCH
  • Paging RNTI (P-RNTI) for indication of paging information
  • Random access RNTI (RA-RNTI) for PRACH response to scheduling Â­message 3 (see also Fig. 2-3, page 224)
  • Temporary C-RNTI for scheduling the random access response or message 3 in random access procedure, contention-based (see 2.1.4 Random access procedure in 5G NR, page 250
  • SP-CSI-RNTI for semi-persistent CSI reporting on PUSCH
  • TPC-PUCCH-RNTI for PUCCH TPC commands on DCI
  • TPC-PUSCH-RNTI for PUSCH TPC commands on DCI
  • TPC-SRS-RNTI for SRS TPC commands on DCI
  • CS-RNTI â unique identifier for downlink SPS and uplink configured grant
  • INT-RNTI for indicating pre-emption in DL (INT stands for interruption); used e.g. for URLLC vs. eMBB priority settings
  • Slot format indicator RNTI (SFI-RNTI) for TDD slot configuration information (see also Dynamic TDD configuration, page 72)
  • MCS-C-RNTI was introduced to provide a fast scheduling mechanism to switch between various tables indicating the highest possible order modulation scheme (e.g. 64QAM or 256QAM) to derive the resulting modulation index and transport block size, especially for the case of reliable transmission URLLC where new MCS tables were introduced

The DCI message sent on the PDCCH can be considered as a data container containing scheduling information. To identify the proper receiver, the RNTI value is used. To save resources, the following principle is applied: The DCI message is error-protected by attaching a CRC and to avoid additional attachment of a value such as RNTI (producing a longer message length), the RNTI is used to scramble the CRC sequence. This can be understood as a bitwise modulo 2 operation. The Fig. 2-50 illustrates this principle (similar to LTE) in a simplified manner. At the transmitting end, we first assume there is a properly calculated CRC sequence that will be attached to a data bit pattern. The second step is a bit-by-bit scrambling operation known as masking of the CRC with the bit pattern representing the mask (in our case, the RNTI value). The third step is to replace the calculated CRC with the masked CRC and transmit it. At the receiving end, there is no knowledge of which mask has been used. The receiver can apply all possible masks and perform a CRC check on the data section. If the right mask was selected and no transmission error occurred, only one check would result with a proper CRC indication. Thus, we can kill two birds with one stone here, as error detection and identification are sharing the same bit pattern. Note that this method is not applicable to debugging, i.e. if there is a CRC failure, this could be due to having applied the wrong mask or due to a transmission error. The consequence is the same in both cases: The receiver discards the message.

5G NR allows simultaneous reception of physical channels on the downlink, depending on the UE complexity, either on one carrier or in case of the NR-DC dual carrier scenario, on multiple carriers that can either be multiple NR carriers or in case of EN-DC, LTE and NR carriers. The specification TR 38.802 contains two tables defining the downlink reception types, i.e. possible combinations for simultaneous reception of physical channels on the downlink. Note that some channels, e.g. PBCH, are common channels, and thus they are not related to a RNTI value. Other channels are physical channels only with no linkage to any transport channel.

Reception typePhysical channel(s)Monitored RNTIAssociated transport channel
APBCHN/ABCH
BPDCCH+PDSCHSI-RNTIDL-SCH
C0PDCCHP-RNTIN/A
C1PDCCH+PDSCHP-RNTIPCH
D0PDCCH+PDSCHRA-RNTI or temporary C-RNTIDL-SCH
D1PDCCH+PDSCHC-RNTI, CS-RNTI(s), MCS-C-RNTIDL-SCH
EPDCCHC-RNTIN/A
FPDCCHC-RNTI, CS-RNTI(s), MCS-C-RNTIUL-SCH
GPDCCHSFI-RNTIN/A
GHPDCCHINT-RNTIN/A
J0PDCCHTPC-PUSCH-RNTN/A
J1PDCCHTPC-PUCCH-RNTIN/A
J2PDCCHTPC-SRS-RNTIN/A
KPDCCHSP-CSI-RNTIN/A

Fig. 2-51 Downlink reception types in 5G NR.

UE capabilitySupported combinations
PCellPSCellSCell
1. RRC_IDLE
 A + B + C1 + D0  
2. RRC_INACTIVE
 A + B + C1 + D0  
3. RRC_CONNECTED
All UEsA + C0 + (B and/or D0 or D1) + E + F + G + H + J0 + J1 + J2 + K + J2+ KA + C0 + (B and/or D0 or D1) + E + F + G + H + J0 + J1 + J2 + KD1 + F + G + H + J0 + J1

Fig. 2-52 5G NR downlink reception type combinations.

Fig. 2-52 describes the channels that a UE has to decode in certain situations, e.g. the entry RRC_IDLE and combinations A + B + C1 + D0 request a UE to decode PBCH + PDCCH and PDSCH for paging, system information update and random access response if applicable. Fig. 2-51 and Fig. 2-52 describe the various 5G NR modes of either standalone single cell, carrier aggregation and dual connectivity. The term PSCell refers to the primary cell of the secondary cell group, here representing the condition of dual connectivity, while SCell is the secondary cell, here representing the condition of carrier aggregation. Fig. 2-53 summarizes the downlink allocation scenarios possible in 5G NR. It only depicts the simultaneous reception of downlink assignment and downlink DCI assigning uplink resources.

Note that the supported combination is limited by the UE capability.

Downlink control information (DCI)

The downlink control information (DCI) is sent over the physical channel PDCCH to assign downlink or uplink resources. The previously described RNTI values indicate the content and which UE should decode the scheduling message content. In carrier aggregation or dual connectivity scenarios, the downlink control information may be valid for one or more carriers or cells. 5G NR defines various DCI formats indicating different resources. The following DCI formats are defined:

Downlink control information types:

  • DCI format 0_0 is used for scheduling of uplink data resources sent over PUSCH in one cell
  • DCI format 0_1 is used for scheduling of uplink data resources sent over PUSCH in one cell, with more parameters than format 0_0
  • DCI format 1_0 is used for scheduling of downlink data resources sent over PDSCH in one cell
  • DCI format 1_1 is used for scheduling of downlink data resources sent over PDSCH in one cell, with more parameters than format 1_0
  • DCI format 2_0 is used for notifying the slot format size to a group of UEs if TDD duplex mode is used within the cell. See the section Dynamic TDD configuration, page 72 for details on TDD slot configuration aspects
  • DCI format 2_1 is used for notifying a group of UEs of the PRB(s) and OFDM symbol(s) where the UE may assume no transmission is intended for the UE, i.e. pre-emption indication.
  • DCI format 2_2 is used for the transmission of uplink power control commands (TPC). See 1.2.5.7 Transmit power allocation, page 121 for details on uplink power control aspects
  • DCI format 2_3 is used for the transmission of uplink power control for sounding reference signals. See 1.2.5.7 Transmit power allocation, page 121 for details on uplink power control aspects

Each DCI message is constructed by multiplexing control message elements, CRC attachment and masking with RNTI as described in Fig. 2-50, channel coding using polar codes as described in 5G NR channel coding for control information, page 151 and finally, rate matching to match the physical layer rates. Note that the PDCCH used to carry DCI is always QPSK-modulated. The following section provides more details on the DCI control message content.

DCI format 0_0 for scheduling one PUSCH in one cell

The DCI format 0_0 is scrambled with the C-RNTI or CS-RNTI or MCS-C-RNTI and is used to schedule uplink resources in one cell. The content of the format 0_0 is described in detail in 2.2.7 UL grant reception or UL assignment, page 329.

DCI format 0_1 for scheduling one PUSCH in one cell

Similar to DCI format 0_0, this scheduling information also assigns uplink resources, but the difference is that DCI format 0_1 contains more parameters for higher flexibility. See 2.2.7 UL grant reception or UL assignment, page 329 for more details.

DCI format 1_0 for scheduling one PDSCH in one cell

DCI format 1_0 is used for scheduling one PDSCH in one DL cell. Its CRC is scrambled with C-RNTI, CS-RNTI or MCS-C-RNTI. Note that DCI format 1_0 is also used to schedule the PDSCH resource related to control procedures such as paging with P RNTI, the system information broadcast with SI-RNTI or the random access response indication with RA-RNTI. In such cases, the content of the DCI control message is slightly different from what is described below (see TS 38.212 for details). Regarding frequency domain allocation, DCI format 1_0 only allows allocation type 1 (see Resource assignment in the frequency domain, page 314 for details). The content of DCI format 1_0 can be described as follows:

  • Identifier for DCI formats â 1 bit. This bit is used to distinguish between DCI format 0_x for uplink allocation and format 1_x for downlink allocation. If bit = 1, it is a downlink allocation and otherwise uplink
  • Frequency domain resource assignment indicating the physical resource on the downlink assigned to the UE (see Resource assignment in the time domain, page 312)
  • Resource allocation in the time domain (see Resource assignment in the time domain, page 312)
  • Virtual to physical resource block mapping â One bit that indicates whether VRB to PRB mapping is true or not. See 1.2.2 Resource grid, page 56 and Fig. 2-36, page 268 for further details on VRB to PRB mapping
  • Modulation and coding schemes, indicating the used modulation scheme and the puncturing rate or code rate. The integer value refers to a table specified in TS 38.214. Note that there are 3 different tables for modulation order and coding rate defined. RRC controls which of those tables is relevant.
  • New data indicator â One bit that toggles if the transport block is a new data block; otherwise, this bit indicates a retransmission. The NDI is used for HARQ operation feedback, see also HARQ operation, page 276.
  • Redundancy version â Indicates the puncturing scheme used in the channel coding procedure for rate matching purposes. This information is required by the soft combining buffer operation for data decoding. Especially in retransmission cases, a changed puncturing scheme allows incremental redundancy for higher decoding efficiency
  • HARQ process number â Indicates the HARQ process so the UE may use soft combining with previously received transport blocks (see HARQ operation, page 276 for details)
  • Downlink assignment index (DAI) â Used in TDD configuration with asymmetric assignment between UL/DL. Based on the assumption that there are more resources allocated in the DL direction than in the UL direction, a one to one mapping between transport blocks and their corresponding HARQ feedback is not possible. The main idea is to introduce a bundling mechanism to be applied for HARQ feedback, i.e. a âkill two birds with one stoneâ approach where a single ACK/NACK may confirm two transport blocks. The DAI is an indication of what âsegmentâ within the bundle of transport blocks is transmitted herewith to support the proper decoding mechanism
  • Transmit power control (TPC) command for the scheduled uplink control channel PUCCH. See 1.2.5.7 Transmit power allocation, page 121 for details on uplink power control aspects
  • PUCCH resource indicator â Indicates one out of eight possible PUCCH resources configured by higher layers that must be used for HARQ feedback by the UE (TS 38.213)
  • PDSCH-to-HARQ feedback timing indicator (see HARQ operation, page 276 for details). Unlike in LTE, HARQ feedback can be flexibly configured by the higher layers and several feedback timing values may exist. This 3 bit value indicates what feedback timing applies in the UE for transmission of HARQ feedback. Via higher layer parameters, the network can configure multiple timing relations Slot-timing-value-K1 and via this DCI parameter, the specific timing value can be selected, as shown in Fig. 2-54.

DCI format 1_1 for scheduling one PDSCH in one cell

Like DCI format 1_0, format 1_1 is also used to schedule downlink resources in one cell by using the same RNTI types (C-RNTI, CS-RNTI or MCS-C-RNTI). However, it supports more parameters and thus more scheduling scenarios. DCI format 1_1 is used with carrier aggregation, or it allows scheduling of two transport blocks in case of spatial multiplexing or MIMO scenarios. The content of the DCI format 1_1 message is as follows:

  • Identifier for DCI formats â As described above, indicates whether uplink or downlink assignment is involved
  • Carrier indicator â 0 or 3 bits. If carrier aggregation is configured by higher layers, this index describes the component carriers to which the assignment of resources applies
  • Bandwidth part indicator â See also 1.4 Bandwidth part fundamentals, page 182. There, it is noted that the UE can have up to four bandwidth parts configured by higher layers. With DCI format 1_1, it is possible to switch between these bandwidth parts. Note that active switching of the BWP via DCI scheduling is optional for the UE
  • Frequency domain resource assignment to allocate the downlink physical resource (see Resource assignment in the frequency domain, page 314)
  • Time domain resource assignment (see Resource assignment in the time domain, page 312 for details)
  • Virtual to physical resource block mapping valid flag
  • PRB bundling size indicator â Dependent on the higher layer precoding bundle configuration (see Precoding configuration aspects in 5G NR, page 107)
  • Rate matching indicator for indication of the rate matching pattern dependent on higher layer settings
  • ZP CSI-RS trigger â See Fig. 1-91, page 117 for details. The PDSCH on the downlink may contain zero power CSI-RS that are configured by higher layers. This field indicates the position of those reference signals that are not transmitted. The UE may use them for measurement reporting, e.g. feedback about inter-cell interference situations
  • For transport block 1
    • Modulation and coding scheme indication
    • New data indicator bit
    • Redundancy version
  • For transport block 2
    • Modulation and coding scheme indication
    • New data indicator bit
    • Redundancy version
  • HARQ process number
  • Downlink assignment index
  • TPC command for scheduled PUCCH
  • PUCCH resource indicator
  • PDSCH-to-HARQ feedback timing indicator
  • Antenna ports â In reference to a table in TS 38.212 indicating the antenna ports. Here, the antenna port is identical to the structure of the DMRS, configured by higher layers
  • Transmission configuration indication based on the possibility to configure a list of transmission configuration indications (TCI) to the UE, taking into account various propagation aspects such as Doppler shift, average delay, spatial RX parameters, etc. to configure quasi co-location relationship for reference signals DMRS. This DCI indication allows mapping of such TCI states. See the section on physical access fundamentals (1.2.5.5 Antenna ports, precoding and quasi co-located Â­antennas, page 98) and TS 38.214 for further details
  • SRS request â Used to trigger transmission of sounding reference signals by the UE (see 1.2.5.6 Physical signals in 5G NR, page 110)
  • CBG transmission information â As shown in Fig. 1-119, page 151 it is possible to attach a CRC to each code block, then combine several code blocks into a code block group CBG and apply HARQ feedback per CBG
  • CBG flushing out information â Determined by higher layers if the code block group is still active
  • DMRS sequence initialization â One parameter that can be used as an initial value for the pseudo-noise sequence generator for generation of DMRS sequences. See Fig. 1-86, page 111 for further details on DMRS sequence generation

DCI format 2_0 for notifying the slot format

This DCI message is attached with a CRC scrambled with the SFI-RNTI and may be sent to a group of UEs to notify about the slot format for TDD operations. The length of DCI format 2_0 is configurable by higher layers. This method is also known as dynamic TDD configuration. See also Dynamic TDD configuration, page 72 for further details about the TDD slot format.

DCI format 2_1 for indicating the PRBs and OFDM symbols where no transmission is intended

A possible option for higher layers is to configure the UE for so-called pre-emption operation, i.e. if the IE DownlinkPreemption is activated. The UE may assume that no transmission to the UE is present in the PRBs and in symbols from a set of PRBs and a set of symbols from the last monitoring period that are indicated by DCI format 2_1, scrambled with the value INT-RNTI (TS 38.213). The size of DCI format 2_1 is configurable by higher layers and the content is an enumeration of pre-emption indication values.

DCI format 2_2 for transmission of TPC commands for PUCCH and PUSCH

This DCI message is used to send transmit power control commands to a group of UEs corresponding to the possible transmission of uplink data or control channels. DCI format 2_2 is scrambled with the TPC-PUSCH-RNTI or TPC-PUCCH-RNTI and contains an enumeration of power control commands valid for the applicable channel and UE (TS 38.212).

DCI format 2_3 for transmission of a group of TPC commands for SRS

This DCI allows the network to control the uplink transmit power if a sounding reference signal (SRS) is configured for one or several UEs. See 1.2.5.6 Physical signals in 5G NR, page 110 for further details on sounding reference signals. Via DCI scheduling of SRS signals, the network has the ability to request uplink signals to perform channel estimation, which is essential for link maintenance, link adaptation and obviously for beamforming decisions.

2.2.4 DL data reception

Like LTE, 5G NR uses packet-switched connections combined with the shared physical channel principle to provide the highest possible flexibility. The main channels involved in downlink data reception are the physical data channel (PDSCH) and the downlink transport channel (DL-SCH). Since the network decides about scheduling resources within a cell to multiple UEs, the shared channel concept allows a greater degree of flexibility to assign resources to UEs in the time and frequency domain. The PDSCH uses a flexible modulation and coding scheme (MCS) and through the control channel PDCCH, all UEs receive scheduling information via DCI messages for the specific PDSCH.
