See 2.2.3 DL resource assignment, page 295 for details on the downlink assignment. The gNB provides a dynamic scheduler in its MAC layer which is in charge of distributing DL resources in time and frequency among all UEs in a cell to guarantee highest flexibility and efficiency in scheduling decisions on the physical layer. The transport channel DL-SCH uses the concept of transport formats to provide a QoS related data transfer. Higher layers in 5G NR have configured a quality of service flow inheriting QoS parameters such as guaranteed bit rate, priority and latency aspects (see 2.2.2 End to end quality of service, page 285 for further details). This configuration leads to QoS requirements for each UE and the associated radio bearers. The downlink scheduler assigns resources between UEs based on shared channel operation, taking into account the radio conditions at the UE by means of the adaptive modulation and coding principle. To support the gNB scheduler with proper MCS selection, the UE sends measurement reports containing information about the radio network field strength and quality, like CSI-RSRP described in Fig. 2-74. The measurements reported by the UE are configured by the higher layer RRC. The scheduler assigns time domain resources in units of slots: one mini-slot, one slot, or multiple slots. It assigns frequency domain resources in resource blocks within the active bandwidth part (BWP). As described above, the UEs identify resources by receiving a scheduling control information DCI on the physical control channel. The PDSCH uses the modulation schemes QPSK, 16QAM, 64QAM and 256QAM. Note that the highest order modulation scheme to be used can be restricted by RRC signaling. The transport block sizes are no longer indicated directly, but must be calculated by the UE. Like in LTE, frequency resource assignment is based on resource block granularity. However, there is one major difference compared to LTE: Physical resource assignment is no longer based on a TTI duration that is constant 1 ms, but is now much more flexible. These aspects are described in greater detail in the following section.

Downlink data rate

A common question for 5G NR revolves around the maximum data rate to be expected (even if such numbers are unrealistic in real life since 5G NR is based on a shared network concept). TS 38.306 contains a formula to calculate the approximate data rate or throughput based on the number of carriers and layers.

Unlike LTE, the data rate is not given in a table derived from UE categories or based on maximum transport block sizes as the only limiting factor. The data rate must be calculated based on the resource allocation circumstances and the higher layer settings. The formula in Fig. 2-55 uses the following parameters:

  • J: The number of aggregated component carriers in a band or band combination, with maximum 16 component carriers for carrier aggregation
  • Rmax: Maximum possible code rate (948/1024) or lower
  • Î½: Number of layers (the maximum number of layers is 8)
  • Q: Bits per modulation symbol, depending on the modulation scheme. Q = 1 for BPSK, 2 for QPSK, 4 for 16QAM, 6 for 64QAM and 8 for 256QAM, which is the maximum allowed modulation scheme
  • f: Scaling factor, signaled via higher layers. The following values for f are allowed: 1, 0.8, 0.75 or 0.4. A first guess about the scaling factor is that it allows the adaptation of the UL-DL configuration in TDD with respect to the data rate, but the real motivation behind the scaling factor is based on the idea that it should be permissible for a UE to indicate a lower performance with respect to the maximum peak data rate (see [Ref. 33]). As described in 1.1.4 Non-access stratum protocol, page 39, the 5G system does not directly define certain UE categories; only UE capabilities are defined. This scaling factor allows the adaptation of a lower data rate supported by the UE as it would be calculated as peak data based on the actual band configuration and baseband capabilities
  • NRB: Maximum number of resource blocks per bandwidth part or lower
  • Ts: Average symbol duration, taking into account the longer CP duration of the first OFDMA symbol in one slot and the possible extended cyclic prefix instead of the normal CP length
  • OH: Overhead due to signaling information. Currently, OH can assume the following values:
    • 0.14 for frequency range FR1 for DL
    • 0.18 for frequency range FR2 for DL
    • 0.08 for frequency range FR1 for UL
    • 0.10 for frequency range FR2 for UL

In addition to the formula in Fig. 2-55 for calculating the maximum data rate, the maximum data rate can be limited due to a certain UE capability. Capability indications such as the total layer 2 buffer size will determine the maximum data rate if indicated by the UE (see TS 38.306 for details).

Transport block size calculation

We should now recall LTE where the transport block size (TBS) is precalculated and provided in tables containing all possible values and the DCI value modulation and coding schemes, together with the number of allocated resource blocks received on the PDCCH, refers to the corresponding table indicating the TBS size directly. In 5G NR, the procedure is slightly different. It requires a certain amount of calculations by the UE and is far more complex than in LTE. Main difference is, in 5G NR, the UE calculates the TBS and there is an algorithm to calculate the TBS depending on higher layer signaled parameters. The following section will provide more details on that algorithm.

To start the TBS determination, the UE first has to read the downlink allocation information: MCS, redundancy version, number of layers and number of resource blocks. The specification TS 38.214 contains three different tables indicating the modulation order and the target code rate resulting in a spectral efficiency value (bit per second per Hertz). Why are there three tables instead of one? Recall the behavior of a coded transport block when faced with a degrading SNR: First, assuming a high SNR, we see a constant data rate for the given code rate, but at a certain point, we see a drop in the data rate, i.e. a âfall off the cliffâ situation. Now, the idea behind adaptive modulation and coding is to design multiple such curves, known as âwaterfallâ curves, with different data rates and different positions of the âdropâ. Depending on the prevailing SNR, the scheduler can select a more robust or a higher rate MCS. See [Ref. 18] for details on adaptive modulation and coding based on the example of 3G (or HSPA) where the idea of adaptive modulation and coding in combination with a dynamic scheduling scheme for shared channels was first introduced. With three different tables now in 5G NR, the granularity of these curves can be influenced and the goal of achieving the highest possible data throughput under the given channel conditions can be reached.

The following are the main characteristics of these three tables:

  • MCS index table 1 for PDSCH mainly for SPS with modulation schemes QPSK â 64QAM only and spectral efficiency ranging from 0.2344 up to 5.5547 with 28 steps
  • MCS index table 2 for PDSCH, if higher layer PDSCH_config = 256qam with modulation schemes QPSK â 256QAM only and spectral efficiency ranging from 0.2344 up to 7.406 with 27 steps
  • MCS index table 3 for PDSCH, if higher layer PDSCH_config = 64qam with modulation schemes QPSK â 64QAM only and spectral efficiency ranging from 0.058 up to 4.523 with 28 steps

The next step involves a preliminary calculation of the number of information bits needed for detailed calculation of the TBS. The following Fig. 2-56 and Fig. 2-57 illustrate this algorithm in detail. First, the UE calculates the estimated number of resource elements, taking into account the scheduled resource in the time domain as the number of symbols multiplied by the number of subcarriers per RB (Fig. 2-56), minus the number of REs that are used by DMRS transmission and a higher layer value xOverhead indicating possible overhead due to signaling. This value, representing the number of resource elements for PDSCH per RB is then multiplied with the assigned number of RBs, given via the DCI frequency domain information. The final step is to multiply this number of allocated resource elements with the DCI scheduling information modulation index, code rate and number of layers to obtain an initial estimation of the total number of information bits Ninfo. This initial number is then used in a second part of the TBS calculation algorithm to determine a TBS size.

The second part of the TBS calculation algorithm consists mainly of a selection process to decide on the transport block size that best fits the estimated number of information bits Ninfo derived in the first part. This selection process is based on a floor and rounding procedure for the number of information bits taking into account the code rate and the transport block size. Details of the TBS selection algorithm are shown in Fig. 2-57. If the estimated number of information bits is less than or equal to 3824, the TBS is selected based on TS 38.214, table 5.1.3.2-2. Otherwise, the code rate is checked if it is less than Â¼. For low code rates, the TBS size can now be calculated directly. For higher code rates, an additional check is performed. Depending on whether the quantized number of information bits is greater than 8424 or not, a corresponding formula from 3GPP specification is chosen to calculate the scheduled TBS on the PDSCH. Note that the UE ignores the PDSCH if the code rate is higher than 0.95.

Resource assignment in the time domain

In comparison to LTE where the assignment in the time domain is based on a duration of 1 ms corresponding to one TTI or subframe, 5G NR allows much greater flexibility for allocation of physical resources in the time domain to support a multitude of application scenarios such as eMBB or URLLC. Therefore, the time resource is allocated based on a number of OFDMA symbols instead of subframes or slots (Fig. 2-58). The control information DCI indicates a time domain resource assignment field. This time assignment is a row index to a table that provides further information such as the slot offset K0, the start and length indicator value SLIV and the PDSCH mapping type A or B, indicating the DMRS symbol mapping (see Fig. 1-87, page 112). The values in this table are either indicated by higher layer signaling directly or by using default values. The direct signaled RRC IEs pdsch-ConfigCommon or pdsch-Config may contain an IE pdsch-AllocationList that will define the rows of an allocation table and the DCI parameter will refer as a row index to that table. In case the higher layers do not define these information elements, there are default tables defined in TS 38.214. In that case, the DCI parameter points to the row index of the default tables.

To summarize time allocation in 5G NR, the major difference compared to LTE is that the scheduling period in time is no longer constant (equal to one subframe), but instead there are various time lengths, indicated as a multiple of OFDM symbols. The shortest time duration that can be assigned using the above described SLIV method is two consecutive OFDMA symbols. In the literature, the shorter TTI is also referred to as a mini-slot. There are multiple numbers of symbols possible as scheduling assignments in the time domain (Fig. 2-59). The main ones are 2, 4 and 7 OFDMA symbols, but additional durations are also possible. On the other hand, it is possible with the higher layer parameter aggregationFactorDL to aggregate certain slots. If such slot aggregation is applied, the time configuration obtained from the SLIV value is identical for all the aggregated slots.

Resource assignment in the frequency domain

The frequency resource information for the PDSCH is scheduled via DCI control information on the PDCCH. There are two types of frequency allocation: type 0 and type 1. They differ in that the frequency resource allocation can either be distributed or contiguous and in their spectral granularity. Allocation type 0 combines a certain number of resource blocks into a resource block group RBG and uses a bitmap to allocate frequency resources with RBG granularity. Allocation type 1 indicates to a scheduled UE a set of contiguously allocated localized or distributed virtual resource blocks that will be mapped onto physical resource blocks to obtain either a contiguous or distributed allocation with resource block granularity. If the DCI uses format 1_0 for scheduling frequency resources, type 1 is used. If the DCI uses format 1_1, the allocation type 0 or 1 is indicated by the most significant bit in the FrequencyDomainResource field within the DCI message, or it may be configured by the higher layer parameter resourceAllocation in the IE PDSCH-Config directly.

Downlink resource allocation type 0

Frequency resource allocation type 0 represents the possible frequency distributed case of resource allocation and introduces the term resource block group (RBG), representing a set of consecutive virtual resource blocks. The RBG size P is given by the table in Fig. 2-60. The RBG size is configured by the higher layer parameter rbg-Size contained in the IE PDSCH-Config, indicating configuration 1 or 2 and the size of the bandwidth part. The allocation mechanism uses a bitmap where each bit indicates whether the corresponding RBG is scheduled or not (Fig. 2-61). Thus, the granularity of frequency allocation is on an RBG size basis. Note that depending on the configuration of the bandwidth part with start and size values, the first and last RBG may differ slightly from the RGB size P (see TS 38.214 for further details).

Bandwidth part size in #RBsConfiguration 1 set by IE ârbg- SizeâConfiguration 2 set by IE ârbg- Sizeâ
1 to 3624
37 to 7248
73 to 144816
145 to 2751616

Fig. 2-60 Nominal RBG size P for allocation type 0.

Downlink resource allocation type 1

Allocation type 1 represents the frequency contiguous resource allocation cases and is similar to LTE allocation type 2, where resource blocks are assigned contiguously. The scheduling information indicates a start RB (RB_start) and a number of RBs (RB_length) within the active BWP.

To indicate these parameters, via DCI scheduling a resource indication value (RIV) is given via the frequency domain scheduling info. The RIV parameter is calculated specific to the bandwidth part (see TS 38.214 for details). The bandwidth part size is the size of the active BWP except when allocation type 1 schedules resources in the common search space in CORESET 0. In this case, the initial bandwidth part size is chosen and the start RB is relative to the start of the BWP. The Fig. 2-62 shows how the RIV parameter indicates the frequency resource.

We will now consider some examples. We assume a BWP size of 50 RB. In our first example, the network wants to schedule 20 RBs with start RB = 5 to the UE. Then, the RIV is calculated as 50 â (20 â 1) + 5 = 955. We must use the upper formula since the allocated length of 20 is less than half of the BWP size. In our second example, we assume a BWP size of 50, but now the network schedules a length of 40 RBs with start RB of 5. Now, we must apply the lower formula in the figure and calculate a RIV value of 50 â (50 â 40 + 1) + (50 â 1 â 5) = 594. Note that the UE must perform this calculation in reverse since the DCI scheduling contains the integer value representing the RIV and the UE has to derive the length and RB start based thereupon. This is similar to frequency indication in LTE. In addition, the RIV parameters RB start and length describe so-called virtual RBs, which are mapped to physical RBs. This mapping can result in either a contiguous allocation or a distributed allocation (see also Fig. 2-36, page 268)

Reference signals for downlink data reception

The downlink data channel PDSCH is accompanied by various physical reference signals to optimize and support decoding and demodulation. In contrast to LTE where cell-specific reference signals were introduced as a kind of âone fits allâ mechanism for both data decoding and channel estimation, the procedure in 5G NR is slightly different. It is intentionally a more flexible approach where various reference signals are defined for different purposes such as channel decoding, channel status or synchronization aspects. A second benefit is the lean channel concept, reducing the overhead given by cell specific âalways-onâ reference signals. These physical reference signals are described in 1.2.5.6 Physical signals in 5G NR, page 110.

The downlink DM-RS signals multiplexed onto the downlink PDSCH play an important role in data decoding. To support high flexibility and respond to various propagation conditions such as SNR fluctuations, device mobility, interference, coverage requirements and so on, the DMRS signals can be configured by the higher layer IE DMRS-DownlinkConfig. This configuration message makes it possible to define the density in the time domain, the density in the frequency domain and the content such that the sequence used for the DMRS is UE-specific. The DMRS signals can be common or cell-specific in case of common channels such as the PBCH. In our situation here, UE-specific data on PDSCH, the pseudorandom bit sequence used for generating the DMRS signal is UE-specific. This allows implementation of the precoding in a flexible manner, i.e. codebook based or non-codebook based or beamforming on PDSCH (see 1.2.5.5 Antenna ports, precoding and quasi co-located Â­antennas, page 98). In addition, the demodulation reference signals support SU-MIMO or spatial multiplexing, which has to be considered as a dynamic procedure determined by the channel correlation status or rank of the channel matrix. To support the estimation of the correlation between the multiple layers, the DMRS signals are covered with the aid of an orthogonal cover code and can thus enable the receiver to estimate the cross-correlation or condition number for rank indicator feedback (see Fig. 1-89, page 113 for further details).

For better precoding support, 5G NR introduces the term precoding resource block group (PRG), i.e. the UE may assume a certain number of PRBs as the granularity for precoding. This granularity P'BWP,i can be equal to one of the values 2, 4 or wideband. It defines the size of the PRG. The IE prb-BundlingType in the pdsch-config message can define either a static size for the PRG, or it can define two sets of PRG sizes that can be scheduled dynamically via DCI format1_1 (see Downlink control information (DCI), page 302 and TS 38.214). Obviously, radio physics have not changed in 5G NR. Thus, the DMRS signals are also used at the receiver for traditional equalizing techniques, channel evaluation and also for power estimation since the network can set the ratio PDSCH EPRE to DMRS EPRE (Fig. 1-95, page 123).

In addition to the DMRS, there are two other important reference signals supporting downlink data reception. First, there are the CSI-RS reference signals which are described in 1.2.5.6 Physical signals in 5G NR, page 110. The initial impression here is that the main purpose of the CSI-RS is to estimate the channel status and calculate CSI reporting values. Since 5G introduces techniques such as non-codebook based precoding and beamforming, the CSI-RS play an important role in optimizing the beamforming via aspects such as beam switching, beam refinement and the beam recovery procedure. Thus, the CSI-RS can be understood to be essential for mobility and for supporting the network with downlink scheduling decisions such as link adaptation and beamforming. This is true especially in view of the potential non-reciprocity of the channel condition between the UL and DL (as is the case in FDD systems). See also 1.3 Beamforming fundamentals, page 169 for further details.

Also for CSI-RS, there are configuration parameters given by higher layers to define the density in frequency and time, the UE-specific scrambling ID and the critical setting of zero-power reference signals for channel estimation and beam switching procedures. The CSI-RS signals do not only enable the UE to acquire channel status information, but they also play an essential role in uplink control information (UCI) feedback supporting network downlink scheduling decisions and beamforming implementations. Further details on uplink feedback are given in 2.2.9 Uplink control information (UCI), page 340.

Taking into account aspects such as phase noise as described in 1.2.1.1 Motivational aspects behind wider subcarrier spacing, page 53 which have a major impact especially in the higher frequency ranges (FR2), another reference signal helps the UE to fulfill its receiving task: the phase tracking reference signal (PTRS). These reference signals support mitigation techniques tackling the phase noise effect which impacts the orthogonality of subcarriers since OFDMA-based waveforms require precise synchronization. The phase tracking reference helps the receiver to adjust its local oscillator to the received frequency and thus compensate and mitigate the phase noise influence.

Another type of reference signals are the tracking reference signals (TRS) which may be used in the absence of or in addition to the PSS or SSS. Besides the impact of phase noise that affects the receiver demodulation performance, good synchronization in time and frequency has to be maintained. The TRS is a reference signal supporting synchronization. Especially at higher frequencies, it is likely that the local oscillators in the receiver and transmitter hardware may lose their common synchronization. The tracking reference signal helps the receiver to adjust its timing reference to the received signal and thus compensate and mitigate deviations resulting from mobility effects (Doppler shift) or hardware issues (i.e. oscillator drift).

2.2.5 Hybrid automatic repeat request (HARQ) operation

To guarantee reliable data transfer, both the UE and gNB are required to confirm proper data reception through the process of the hybrid automatic repeat request (HARQ). Generally speaking, the term HARQ implies an automatic retransmission request mechanism that introduces some multitasking aspects and adaptive retransmission. For readers who are not overly familiar with wireless communications, a brief digression into error correction mechanisms based on retransmission is given in the next sentences. Later, some details on HARQ process implementation within 5G NR will be given.

Brief digression into error correction mechanisms + HARQ

Circuit-switched communications systems such as GSM were confronted with a tradeoff between reliability on one hand and complexity on the other. Reliability can be improved by mechanisms such as acknowledgement of data or redundant transmission, but this occurs at the cost of more signaling information and implementation complexity. The acknowledgment of data in a circuit-switched network such as GSM can be described as a counter-based retransmission request. The transmitter counts every outgoing data unit (âpacketâ) in a circuit-switched connection and the receiver increments its counter with every successfully decoded packet. After some time instance, these counter values are exchanged between the TX and RX entity. The advantage is the simplicity in implementation and the low data rate required for feedback provisioning. The disadvantage is the fact that in case of a counter mismatch, all packets up from the common counter status are retransmitted, regardless of whether they have already been properly received or not. This lead to the implementation of a selective acknowledgement scheme in the first packet-switched network GPRS. Packets were numbered with a SN and the feedback was only about the lost packets. The resulting retransmission was more efficient as only lost packets were retransmitted. Such a feedback mechanism is based on a bitmap matrix indicating the sequence number indices. Feedback is provided after a number of packets that have been transmitted based on the exchange of such a bitmap. The drawback of this efficiency improvement concerning retransmission of only lost packets is that it results in long delays between the initial transmission, feedback and retransmission. Thus, the main mechanisms of HARQ as known today have been introduced with the presentation of HSPA in 3GPP Release 5. For readers who are not familiar with HARQ in general, further information can be found in [Ref. 18]. HARQ is based on an automatic acknowledgment technique (ARQ) and transmitted packets are automatically acknowledged. This has an advantage for latency aspects since there is an immediate response, but this methodology requires control channel resources for such ACK/NACK information, i.e. the known channels PHICH or PUCCH in LTE. But HARQ is not just the automatic acknowledgement of data packets; it further introduces a concept of multitasking to run several HARQ processes in parallel. If the receiver is able to decode the incoming data packet (indicated by a successful CRC check), it transmits an ACK and otherwise a NACK (see also the section on channel coding aspects in 5G NR, i.e. chapter 1.2.5.8 Channel coding, page 132). By way of reminder, the HARQ process is illustrated in Fig. 2-63. The term HARQ process introduces multitasking of several processes with steps such as data packet demodulation, descrambling, FFT operation and CRC check + appropriate ACK or NACK feedback. To avoid any stalled situations from the TX perspective and to increase the data throughput for one connection between one UE and one network, the receiver and transmitter perform several parallel RX and TX buffering processes in a multitasking operation. This concept was first introduced in 3GPP Release 5 with the introduction of HSDPA in UMTS.

In addition to the multitasking operation, the term hybrid in HARQ also signifies the idea of soft combining. Soft combining is a technique where the receiver does not discard an erroneous packet but instead uses it in combination with the retransmission to increase the decoding probability. Assuming a random distribution of errors occurred in a communication, this soft combining mechanism improves the decoding success ratio at the price of requiring an interim memory buffer at the receiver, the so-called soft buffer. Besides the need for soft buffer memory, the soft combining technique requires proper signaling or identification of the retransmission to perform the overlapping or soft combining in the right manner. Chase combining is the case where the retransmission applies the same puncturing scheme as the initial transmission, while incremental redundancymay switch to another puncturing scheme, thereby increasing the chance of proper decoding together with soft combining. Both mechanisms differ in their ability to add redundancy information due to retransmission, but perhaps at the cost of forfeiting their self-decodable status. Consequently, each of the schemes can be beneficial and the network has the flexibility to select them accordingly, depending on whether the error probability on the communications channel is either sporadic, affecting single bits within a transport block, or more block error oriented, where a whole transport block may be lost. These mechanisms are explained in detail in [Ref. 18]] as well as in other literature (especially academic publications).

HARQ mechanisms in 5G NR

At first glance, the HARQ operation in 5G NR appears similar to the HARQ operation applied in LTE, but some marginal differences are defined in the specifications, especially when considering details such as the feedback mechanism, selection of control channels involved in ACK/NACK feedback, or HARQ timing aspects. This section will focus on the HARQ mechanisms used in 5G NR.

If the receiver is able to decode the incoming data packet (which is indicated via a successful CRC check after decoding), it will transmit an ACK and otherwise a NACK (see also the information on channel coding aspects in 1.2.5.8 Channel coding, page 132) to request its retransmission. Soft combination of the previous packet and the newly transmitted one increases the probability of recovering from the error and reconstructing the original packet. In addition, the transmitter may perform retransmission with an identical puncturing scheme (âchase combiningâ) or with a different puncturing scheme (âincremental redundancyâ). The puncturing scheme is indicated to the receiver with the DCI scheduling information redundancy version. Note that the DCI scheduling of the puncturing is either the indication of the puncturing scheme that is applied to the scheduled data packet on the downlink PDSCH, or it is to be understood as a command about which puncturing should be used for the assigned data packet on the uplink PUSCH. 5G NR supports the possible segmentation of large code words into smaller code blocks and as a consequence, the feedback mechanism and retransmission can be code block based. Due to the absence of the downlink control channel PHICH, the ACK/NACK feedback for uplink data is slightly different compared with LTE. The HARQ feedback on the downlink is piggybacked with the new data indicator (NDI) bit. Instead of direct ACK/NACK feedback, the network indicates with the NDI whether the assigned data packet on the uplink should be a new data packet or a retransmission. Regarding downlink data, the HARQ feedback on the uplink can be transmitted over the PUCCH channel multiplexed with other UL information like SR or CRI, or alternatively HARQ ACK/NACK information can be multiplexed with data on the PUSCH.

As just described, HARQ signifies hybrid automatic repeat request and can be considered as a multitasking operation of multiple legacy automatic request procedure (ARQ). Therefore, the HARQ entity in the MAC layer is a multi-process module, meaning that in each time unit only one HARQ process is in charge of transmission and reception, and during the time interval when one HARQ process is waiting for ACK/NACK reception, the other process can transmit. The main influencing parameters are, for example, the length of one data packet as the TTI and the receiver processing time shown as the round-trip time in Fig. 2-63. 5G NR provides a very flexible air interface numerology without a constant TTI length and even without a constant period for the round-trip time, as has been standardized in legacy networks such as LTE. Thus, the number of HARQ processes that are used overall is dynamic and its number is set via higher layers. As a maximum limit, a total number of 16 HARQ processes given by nrofHARQ-Processes is supported in the current release. This is valid for the uplink and downlink and per cell, thus in dual connectivity situations the UE has to provide more HARQ processes overall. If spatial multiplexing is activated, there can be two transport blocks per HARQ process. In addition, the number of HARQ processes is channel dependent and also depends on the scheduling scheme. Specifically, for uplink data on the PUSCH, there can be one to sixteen HARQ processes configured. For downlink data on the PDSCH, the number of HARQ processes has to be an even number and in the current release the numbers 2, 4, 6, 10, 12 and 16 are allowed. In the absence of an RRC configuration, the UE will use eight HARQ processes by default. In case of downlink semi-persistent scheduling, there can be one to eight HARQ processes configured [TS 38.331].

In the absence of a specific HARQ feedback channel on the 5G NR downlink (like the LTE PHCH channel), the ACK/NACK feedback for UL data transfer is marginally different. The methodology is to piggyback ACK/NACK feedback on the configured grant for the uplink using the new data indicator (NDI) bit. This NDI bit runs in a toggled operation, i.e. when its value changes or toggles compared to the previous value, this signifies a new data transmission request; otherwise, it requests retransmission. An NDI bit that is set to ânew dataâ when assigning the next uplink resource belonging to the same HARQ process number with the DCI scheduling message can then be interpreted as acknowledgment of the previous data packet of this HARQ process. If the feedback is negative, i.e. NACK, the UL grant indicating resources for the next transmisson occasion contains an NDI flag, that is not toggled compared to the value of the previous transmission. In summary, instead of transmitting an explicit ACK or NACK, information that would require a specific physical control channel like the PHICH in LTE, in 5G NR the DCI scheduling information containing the new data indicator (NDI) is used to request retransmission and indicate the new radio resource for retransmission.

Note that the NDI bit is used in both directions. Assuming a UE sending explicitely a NACK can see in if the next received packet contains either the retransmisison as requested or a new data packet. In the latter case, the UE would assume the NACK as not been properly received and indicate this packet as lost to e.g. higher layers.

In 5G NR, HARQ will be handled asynchronously to maintain flexibility on the physical layer and support multiple latency requests in the current QoS flows. This means there is no fixed time relation between transmission of DL and UL HARQ feedback information, and higher layers must indicate those timing aspects considering the QoS request regarding latency and possible restrictions due to UE capability. Summarizing the flexibility regarding resource allocation in the time domain and the corresponding acknowledgments and optional retransmissions, a general model for time-related resource allocation is given in Fig. 2-66.

While in EUTRAN such timing information has been set with constant parameters, i.e. the PDCCH always allocates PUSCH resources 4 ms or four LTE subframes later, this timing information can be configured in 5G NR by higher layers or the RRC. Clearly, there are optional restrictions due to e.g. UE processing time limitations or network operator settings.

Regarding HARQ feedback in DL data transfer, the network RRC layer specifies the time delay for a specific HARQ process to transmit HARQ feedback containing the ACK/NACK message on the UL. Later, this information is embedded in the DL assignment using DCI scheduling (Fig. 2-47). In other words, it is a two-step approach: First, the higher layers may configure various feedback times that are stored in a HARQ set in the receiver and via DCI scheduling indication, one value from those preconfigured timings is activated.

The timing between DL assignment and the corresponding DL data transmission is indicated by a field in the DCI scheduling message referring to a set of values that is preconfigured by the network RRC layer. It is shown as value K0 in Fig. 2-64. The timing between UL assignment via the PDCCH scheduling information and the corresponding UL data transmission on the PUSCH is indicated by a field in the DCI scheduling message referring to a set of values that is preconfigured by the RRC. A similar procedure is applied for the HARQ operation or ACK/NACK feedback timing regarding the DL data reception on the PDSCH. The timing relation of a PDSCH transport block to its corresponding HARQ acknowledgment is indicated by a field in the DCI that takes its exact definition from a set of values that is preconfigured by higher layers. It is shown as value K1 in Fig. 2-64. Finally, the higher layers also configure the corresponding timing relation between UL data transmission on the PUSCH and the corresponding DL HARQ feedback. Note that the timing of the retransmission in the uplink direction is asynchronous since it is piggybacked on the assignment of uplink resources and the toggled operation of the new data indicator.

The timing parameters for the HARQ process are set by the gNB and depend on the UE processing capability (see TS 38.214). Once a UE receives the PDCCH scheduling information (the scheduled data on the PDSCH may be on the same or successive slots), the exact slot offset is indicated via the RRC parameter K0 which has a value range from 0 to 32 slots. Note that this already represents a difference compared to EUTRA, where DCI scheduling for downlink data has always been in the same subframe, and thus DCI scheduling and PDSCH data packets have been in the same subframe (just for reference: this does not refer to EUTRA LTE-M or NB-IoT machine type communications features where this rule has been modified). After data packet decoding and CRC checking, the UE sends UL ACK feedback on the PUCCH channel with the slot offset K1. In the current release of the specification, this values for the slot offset may range from 0 to 15 slots. This timer is given via the higher layer signaling IE dl-DataToUL-ACK and corresponds to the value of Slot-timing-value-K1. It represents critical timing since the gNB scheduler must take into consideration the time the UE needs to decode the DL data plus the time to switch to the UL and generate the ACK message. This is especially important for TDD since there is only one frequency channel and the UE must switch between receive mode and transmit mode on the same channel. To avoid interference between the UL and DL, there is typically a guard time defined. K1 also depends on the processing time capability of the UE, which is given as time value N1, corresponding to the PDSCH decoding time and on the configuration of the DMRS resource. As shown in Fig. 1-87, page 112, the DMRS may consist of additional symbols within one slot. In such a case, the UE requires more time for decoding. TS 38.214 describes the processing time for HARQ-ACK information that follows PDSCH reception given as:

Tsproc, 1 = (N1 + d1,1)(2048 + 144) â Ï°2âÎ¼ â Tc

where d1,1 is either 0 or 1 depending on whether HARQ-ACK is sent on the PUCCH or PUSCH, and additionally depends on the PDSCH mapping type A or B. N1 must be considered as a UE processing capability, but it also depends on the configuration of the DMRS signals within one slot. The values of N1 can be a minimum of 3 symbols or a maximum of 24 symbols (see table in TS 38.214 for more details).

K2 is the period or slot offset required from UL grant to UL transmission, which in turn depends on the UE processing capability given as the value N2, corresponding to the PUSCH preparation time, based on the table definition in TS 38.214. In the current release of the specification, the slot offset K2 can assume values in the range from 0 to 32. If this parameter is absent, default values are defined based on the SCS.

All parameters are defined in slots and are therefore independent of the numerology used in the current bandwidth part. The design of the HARQ timing is particularly important for services which require low latency. For example, in the URLLC case, the gNB may stipulate very stringent HARQ timing, especially for the timers K1 and K2 which may be within the same slot with retransmission within the next slot.

5G NR HARQ operation supports additionally the possibility of ACK/NACK bundling operation, i.e. in case of dual connectivity, carrier aggregation or multiple layer SU-MIMO, higher layers may configure a feedback mechanism HARQ that allows a bundling operation or multiplexing/simultaneous transmission of feedback or the omission of feedback. See the specification TS 38.213 for further details. In cooperation with the channel coding procedures described in Fig. 1-119, page 151, HARQ feedback also supports code block specific feedback. This introduces segmentation of a transport block into smaller code blocks and bundling into a code block group for HARQ codebook based feedback. Chapter 2.2.9 Uplink control information (UCI), page 340 describing the UCI feedback procedure contains further details on HARQ codebook based feedback.

2.2.6 Uplink scheduling request and buffer status reporting

On the UL, the UE needs to request resources to transmit as soon as data from a higher layer application is available. In general, there are two distinct operations for requesting a data resource on the uplink depending on the current UE state that can be either RRC_IDLE, RRC_INACTIVE or RRC_CONNECTED. When in RRC_IDLE mode, the UE requests a data connection first via the random access procedure as described in 2.1 Overall access procedure for NSA mode, page 219. When already in the RRC_CONNECTED state, the UE can request uplink resources via transmission of a scheduling request (SR), Fig. 2-67, page 327. The main objective of the connection setup procedure is to establish a PDU session (see PDU session, page 282) with related QoS flows. Contemplating the protocol stack, described in 2.2.10 Data flow through 5G NR protocol layers, page 349, such a PDU session enables data transfer bearers at PDCP level and maps them one to one to logical channels at RLC level. The underlying MAC protocol is in charge of multiplexing data for all of these logical channels into one single data packet (MAC PDU) called a transport block, to be transmitted on the physical layer. The size of the MAC PDU is given by the UL grant assigned to the UE and is known as the transport block size (TBS). See Transport block size calculation, page 309 for details about the TBS calculation. In the time domain, the duration of one TB transmission is called TTI and in 5G NR its values span from multiple OFDM symbols to multiple slots (Fig. 2-59, page 313).

The reason why the UE has different logical channels is that every channel can be handled from one RLC entity in different ways. There are three modes for RLC operation: transparent mode (TM), acknowledged mode (AM) and unacknowledged mode (UM). These three modes respond to different reliability levels for the data flow in the logical channel. In case of signaling data, for example, the need to be secure necessitates an additional RLC acknowledgement procedure ARQ which implies a status report and retransmission procedure performed on the RLC level or logical channel (see Radio link control protocol (RLC), page 356 and TS 38.322). When combined with HARQ operation on the MAC layer we have two separate retransmission methods to guarantee better reliability. In addition, each logical channel is associated with a transmission profile represented by the allowed SCS and maximum PUSCH duration. For example, the network might map a URLLC service application to a logical channel and to achieve low latency for the user data configure only a high SCS and short transmission time on the UL, i.e. a mini-slot with two symbols. These parameters have an essential influence on the decision on MAC multiplexing by the logical channel prioritization entity. This entity performs multiplexing of logical channels with different priority levels to be conveyed on the same UL grant on the physical layer.

The MAC protocol entity, described in section Medium access control (MAC) protocol, page 367 can be configured with zero, one or more SR configurations which consist of a set of PUCCH resources where the UE may send SR if needed and these SR resources may span various BWPs and cells in consideration of DC scenarios. There is a correspondence between a logical channel and the SR resource. If a logical channel is not able to transmit at a sufficient rate on the currently assigned physical resource or no uplink resource is available, the UE triggers the transmission of a scheduling request (SR). When the UE is requesting a resource for that specific logical channel, it uses the SR message sent over the PUCCH. A logical channel is associated with a specific SR configuration per BWP. The higher layer RRC uses the SchedulingRequestConfig IE to configure the scheduling request messages. SchedulingRequestConfig contains the occasion when the SR request transmission is permitted, a maximum number of SR transmissions and the format for PUCCH transmission. The general procedure for SR requests is shown in Fig. 2-67. Only PUCCH resources on a BWP which is active at the time of SR transmission are considered valid.

Since each logical channel is associated with a specific schedulingRequestIdper cell and BWP, the network knows which logical channel is requesting the UL grant and can assign specific UL resources according to the logical channel transmission profile. In fact, each logical channel is associated with three transmission parameters:

  • Allowed subcarrier spacing
  • ServingCell information
  • Timing information, maxPUSCH-Duration

The UE may transmit the SR as soon as it has pending data in the applicable buffer. Since the resources for the SR are statically configured during RRC dedicated configuration, the UE is able to use this PUCCH resource for SR. We will now provide two examples to demonstrate the association with the logical channel and QoS services. First, we will consider a case where a logical channel is associated with the URLLC service. Data must be scheduled with low latency on any SCS. To ensure a short RTT, the transmit duration for one data packet must have low âtransmission timeâ, i.e. a TTI which is influenced by the IE maxPUSCH-Duration. This parameter can be configured per uplink logical channel and if it is configured, MAC SDUs can only be transmitted using uplink grants that result in a PUSCH duration shorter than or equal to the duration indicated by this field (TS 38.331). In the second example, a logical channel is associated with another service such as eMBB file transfer which does not require stringent RTT. It will be restricted to UL grant with a long transmission time. To prevent an eMBB service with high priority from using UL grant for a specific URLLC service, the MAC layer within the UE performs two prioritization steps:

1. It considers whether the logical channel is allowed to run on the current granted transmission resources

2. It considers the priority and multiplexing policies given by parameters such as PBR, BSD as defined in TS 38.321 and described in section Medium access control (MAC) protocol, page 367.

The parameter allowedServingCell is included to signal which logical channel may be transmitted over which serving cell. For example, in case of bearer split applied in dual connectivity scenarios, where a single PDCP bearer is split between two logical channels running on different cells or even in different carrier aggregation scenarios, the network can force logical channel transmission on a specific carrier (Fig. 1-14, page 32).

However, if the gNB is not able to respond to the request, e.g. due to network overloading, then the UE must stop sending the SR for that particular SR configuration identified with sr-ConfigIndex on the PUCCH if the maximum number of requests sr-TransMax is reached, or delay the next SR transmission with the value of sr-ProhibitTimer (TS 38.321). If there are no PUCCH resources configured and available, the UE must always start the random access procedure if it does not have allocated resources to transmit on the uplink.

In addition to the possibility to request new resources via SR, there is inband control information incorporated into the MAC layer that provides status information about the pending data. A UE uses the MAC layer control message formats as inband signaling to report the pending data amount given as a buffer status report (BSR) and information about the transmit power reserves as the power headroom (PH). The MAC entity in an end-user device determines the amount of UL data that is pending on an established logical channel and reports this amount to the network via MAC CE inband reporting of buffer status reports (BSR). These BSR can be regular BSR reports, periodic BSR reports or padding BSR reports. Further details on BSR reporting are explained in the MAC layer description in Fig. 2-98, page 375.

2.2.7 UL grant reception or UL assignment

The assignment of physical resources in the uplink direction generally follows the procedure for downlink assignment described in 2.2.3 DL resource assignment, page 295. The UE monitors the downlink control channel PDCCH that will send DCI scheduling information for the uplink allocation. The attached CRC of the DCI scheduling message is scrambled with a specific identifier RNTI. There are several identity values RNTI indicating the purpose of the scheduling message content and the addressee of the scheduling information (see Radio network temporary identifier (RNTI), page 298). The uplink assignment is valid for two types of physical channels: PUSCH for data assignment and PUCCH for control information assignment.

5G NR supports three types of uplink assignment depending on the physical channel and configurable by the RRC layer: periodic, aperiodic and semi-persistent. Periodic assignment mainly applies to control information reporting, e.g. CSI reports, and higher layers configure the physical resource for such transmissions that can be either PUCCH or control information multiplexed with user data on PUSCH. Semi-persistent scheduling is a method in which higher layers can configure semi-static physical resources in the time and frequency domain, but the usage is then triggered, e.g. by DCI scheduling. Semi-persistent scheduling is a method that is also used for data transmission to fulfill certain QoS requirements such as guaranteed bit rate or delay aspects e.g. for a voice call. It may be used to allocate a kind of constant bit rate and also guarantee a kind of static latency. In simplified terms, this represents a kind of attempt to emulate circuit-switched behavior in a pure packet-switched network. Aperiodic transmission is more or less the use case for packet-switched applications. Whenever higher layers trigger the transmission of data, the assignment has to be performed. This will be done via scheduling information sent on the downlink PDCCH and contains the resource allocation information, described in 5G NR as a configured grant.

To support the network in such scheduling decisions, the UE may send scheduling requests (see 2.2.6 Uplink scheduling request and buffer status reporting, page 326). Chapter 2.2.10 Data flow through 5G NR protocol layers, page 349 provides more information about the scheduling principles. When discussing the uplink, the following physical channels and signals are involved:

  • PRACH for random access. The assignment of a random access resource does not follow the UL assignment scheme described here. Generally, the random access is open to every user, except in cases where the cell indicates a barred status via a system information broadcast. The PRACH access rules and allocation of PRACH resources are broadcasted via system information (see 2.1.4 Random access procedure in 5G NR, page 250
  • PUCCH for uplink control information (UCI). Transmission of the PUCCH can be periodic, semi-persistent or aperiodic. The allocation of PUCCH resources is configurable by higher layers, i.e. RRC IEs PUCCH-config plus PUCCH-configcommon, and they are allocated via DCI scheduling on the PDCCH
  • SRS for sounding reference signal transmission. The resources for SRS are configured by higher layers, i.e. RRC IE SRS-config and the SRS resource assignment can also be scheduled in a periodic, aperiodic or semi-persistent manner. See also 1.2.5.6 Physical signals in 5G NR, page 110 for further details
  • PUSCH for uplink data transfer. The resources for the PUSCH are scheduled via DCI scheduling on the PDCCH

The uplink resources on the PUSCH are scheduled via DCI sent on the PDCCH and using the identifiers C-RNTI for aperiodic and CS-RNTI for semi-persistent scheduling. In addition there can be the optional identifier MCS-C-RNTI for aperiodic PUSCH scheduling with specific modulation and coding scheme restrictions or MCS table selections (TS 38.214).

In general, 5G NR allows the UE to send and receive multiple physical channels and physical signals simultaneously depending on its capabilities and service requirements. Since there are various physical channels that can coincide, a certain nomenclature was introduced in TS 38.202 to indicate the maximum number of channels that can be sent simultaneously along with the possible combinations. These combinations are described within two tables indicating the uplink transmission types and the transmission type configurations.

  • p is the number of uplink carriers configured for the UE on which physical channels can be transmitted linked to the CA functionality
  • p' is the number of uplink carriers configured for the UE on which SRS can be transmitted
  • q is the number of downlink carriers configured for the UE
  • j is the number of cell groups configured for the UE, linked to the DC functionality
  • k is the number of PUCCH groups configured for the UE

The table in Fig. 2-68 defines the possible uplink transmission types. In other words, it describes the type of physical channel that is sent in combination with a respective transport channel. The table in Fig. 2-69 indicates the possible combinations of these transmission types depending on the UE capability and enumerates how many can be sent simultaneously. At first glance, the reader may observe that a UE can simultaneously transmit multiple PUSCH on multiple carriers (here, given as component carriers) in case of carrier aggregation scenarios, but permission is lacking to simultaneously transmit multiple PUSCH on multiple cell groups, indicating the situation of dual connectivity in the current release of the specification.

Transmission typePhysical channel or SRSAssociated transport channel
APRACHRACH
BPUCCHN/A
CPUSCHUL-SCH
DSRSN/A

Fig. 2-68 Uplink transmission types.

UE capabilitySupported combinations
No direct UE categories in 5G NR, but the UE can exchange its capability with the networkj Ã A
k Ã B
p Ã C
p' Ã D
j* Ã A + k* Ã B
j* Ã A + p* Ã C
j* Ã A + p'* Ã D
k* Ã B + p'* Ã D
p* Ã C + p'* Ã D

Fig. 2-69 Uplink transmission type configurations.

The above combinations indicate the simultaneous transmission of multiple physical channels, but only combinations with PRACH or SRS are allowed in conjunction with any other physical channel. The symbol notation for the maximum number is given as j* â¤ j, p* â¤ p, k* â¤ k and p'* â¤ p'.

The physical resource on the uplink is assigned via the PDCCH sending DCI control information. In 5G NR, there are two possible DCI formats to indicate the PUSCH resource: DCI format 0_0 and DCI format 0_1. Note that some of the control information content for uplink resource assignment is similar to the control information used for downlink resource assignment. This section only contains a brief introduction. See also the discussion on downlink resource assignment in 2.2.3 DL resource assignment, page 295.

DCI format 0_0 for scheduling PUSCH in one cell

DCI format 0_0 is used for scheduling PUSCH in one DL cell. Its CRC is scrambled with C-RNTI, CS-RNTI or MCS-C-RNTI. The content of DCI format 0_0 can be described as follows:

  • Identifier for DCI formats â 1 bit. This bit is used to distinguish between DCI format 0_x for uplink allocation and format 1_x for downlink allocation. If bit = 1, it is a downlink allocation and otherwise uplink
  • Frequency domain resource assignment indicating the physical resource on the uplink assigned to the UE (see Resource assignment in the frequency domain, page 314)
  • Resource allocation in the time domain (see Resource assignment in the time domain, page 312)
  • Frequency hopping flag
  • Modulation and coding schemes, indicating the used modulation scheme and the puncturing rate or code rate. This is given as an integer that refers to a table from TS 38.214 indicating the code rate and modulation order. The RRC layer can configure which table is to be selected, i.e. the RRC parameter mcs-Table
  • New data indicator â One bit that toggles from one allocation to the next for each HARQ process, to indicate that the transport block that is pending for transmission should be a new data block; otherwise, this bit indicates a retransmission request. See HARQ operation, page 276. The NDI bit remains the same from one allocation to the next for this HARQ process which replaces the direct transmission of ACK/NACK feedback used in LTE on a dedicated channel (PHICH)
  • Redundancy version â Indicates the puncturing scheme to be applied for the uplink transmission. Especially for retransmission cases, this allows the network to request either a changed puncturing scheme allowing incremental redundancy or identical retransmission allowing chase combining
  • HARQ process number â Indicates the HARQ process so the UE may use soft combining with previously received transport blocks (see HARQ operation, page 276 for details)
  • TPC command for scheduled PUSCH â For the power control mechanism valid for the uplink data channel PUSCH. See 1.2.5.7 Transmit power allocation, page 121 for details on uplink power control
  • Padding bits if required
  • UL/SUL indicator â The UE may use a carrier as supplementary uplink only; the higher layer pusch-config together with this bit indicates whether the assignment is valid for the UL or SUL resource

DCI format 0_1 for scheduling PUSCH in one cell

DCI format 0_1 is used for scheduling PUSCH in one DL cell. Its CRC is scrambled with C-RNTI, CS-RNTI or MCS-C-RNTI. Many content details of DCI format 0_1 are identical to the DCI format 0_0 or DCI format 1_x, for the sake of completeness, they are presented here again, but in a shortened way. Different to format 0_0 for uplink assignment, format 0_1 allows more configuration flexibility in the allocation, e.g. it is used for UL MIMO, for BWP switching and for codebook feedback scheduling. The content of DCI format 0_1 can be described as follows:

  • Identifier for DCI formats â 1 bit. This bit is used to distinguish between DCI format 0_x for uplink allocation and format1_x for downlink allocation. If bit = 1, it is downlink allocation and otherwise uplink
  • Carrier indicator â If carrier aggregation is applied, this field allows cross-carrier scheduling of UL resources
  • UL/SUL indicator â The UE may use a carrier as supplementary uplink only; the higher layer pusch-config together with this bit indicates whether the assignment is valid for the UL or SUL resource
  • Bandwidth part indicator â To allow switching of BWPs (see Fig. 1-154, page 185). Note that the feature BWP switching via DCI scheduling is optional for the UE. Thus, this field may be ignored
  • Frequency domain resource assignment indicating the physical resource on the uplink assigned to the UE (see Resource assignment in the frequency domain, page 314)
  • Resource allocation in the time domain (see Resource assignment in the time domain, page 312)
  • Frequency hopping flag
  • Modulation and coding scheme indicating the used modulation scheme and the puncturing rate or code rate
  • New data indicator â One bit that toggles if the transport block is a new data block for this HARQ process; otherwise not toggling this bit indicates a retransmission request
  • Redundancy version â Indicates the puncturing scheme to be applied, especially when retransmission, a changed puncturing scheme does allow incremental redundancy for higher decoding efficiency
  • HARQ process number â Indicates the HARQ process so the UE may use soft combining with previously received transport blocks (see HARQ operation, page 276 for details)
  • 1st downlink assignment index for dynamic or semi-static HARQ-ACK codebook
  • 2nd downlink assignment index for dynamic HARQ-ACK codebook with two HARQ-ACK sub-codebooks; ignored otherwise
  • TPC command for scheduled PUSCH â For power control the uplink data channel, see 1.2.5.7 Transmit power allocation, page 121 for further details.
  • SRS resource indicator â To indicate sounding reference signal resources in conjunction with higher layer configuration
  • Precoding information and number of layers â Indicates the possibility of MIMO on the uplink and the precoding matrix. Influenced by higher layer parameters such as txConfig to enable or disable MIMO operation on the UL, maxRank indicating the number of transmission streams, and codebookSubset for possible restriction of precoding matrix values
  • Antenna ports â To select the antenna port for reference signal transmission, e.g. DMRS
  • SRS request â To trigger sounding reference signal transmission
  • CSI request â To trigger CSI reports in case of aperiodic scheduling
  • CBG transmission information â Indicates the number of code block groups per transport block
  • PTRS and DMRS association â To configure the transmission of phase tracking reference signals on the uplink (see also 1.2.5.6 Physical signals in 5G NR, page 110)

Note that in the uplink direction, virtual to physical resource block mapping is performed in the non-interleaved mapping only; the interleaved mapping is applied in the downlink direction only (see also Fig. 2-36, page 268).

2.2.8 UL data transmission

The 5G NR uplink is also based on a packet switched connection and the shared physical channel principle to provide greatest possible flexibility. The two channels involved in uplink data transmission are the physical channel PUSCH, which applies the shared transmission to a physical data channel, and the transport channel UL-SCH, which uses the concept of transport formats to introduce QoS aspects on the lower layers. The PUSCH is based on a dynamic allocation of RF resources in time and frequency domain and uses a flexible modulation and coding scheme (MCS). The PDCCH control channel uses DCI messages for scheduling the RF resources and modulation and coding schemes. To enable the gNB to obtain better channel status information, the UE sends uplink control information (UCI) to the network, either on a separate physical control channel PUCCH or multiplexed within user data on the PUSCH. See 2.2.9 Uplink control information (UCI), page 340 for details on the uplink feedback.

The gNB provides a dynamic scheduler in its MAC layer to guarantee the greatest possible flexibility and efficiency in scheduling uplink resources on the physical layer. In addition, the UE may send scheduling request information to obtain physical resource assignments. The uplink scheduler assigns resources between UEs based on shared channel operation, taking into account the radio conditions at the UE by means of the adaptive modulation and coding principle and the higher layer configured QoS flow. To support the gNB scheduler with making the proper MCS selection, the UE sends measurement reports containing information about the radio network field strength and quality, like e.g. the CSI-RSRP (Fig. 2-74, page 342).

The measurements reported by the UE are configured by the higher layer RRC. The scheduler assigns radio resources in time units of slots (e.g. one mini-slot, one slot or multiple slots). In the frequency domain, resource assignment consists of radio block granularity in the active BWP bandwidth part. The UE identifies the assigned resources by receiving a scheduling control information DCI on the physical control channel containing a specific identifier RNTI. As a minor difference compared to the downlink modulation schemes, the PUSCH on the uplink supports (in addition to the modulation schemes QPSK, 16QAM, 64QAM and 256QAM) a Ï/2-BPSK scheme. This Ï/2-BPSK scheme is allowed when uplink transform precoding is enabled, i.e. the DFT-s-OFDMA scheme has been selected (see DFT-s-OFDMA signal generation, page 166) and if there is only one transmission layer activated. Thus, we may understand this modulation scheme for use in situations with smaller data packets in the uplink direction or where reliability is required and the network schedules a very robust modulation order and sacrifices a higher data rate. The complement number Ï/2 to a classic BPSK modulation scheme produces a phase shift of 90 degrees between two consecutive modulation symbols and avoids a possible loss of tracking in a phase locked loop synthesizer in case of long sequences of ones or zeros.

Like in the downlink direction, on the uplink the transport block sizes are also no longer indicated directly, but must be calculated by the UE. The same happens with the allocation in the time domain, offering much greater flexibility compared to LTE. Besides measurement reports on physical layer conditions such as the SNR, CSI or signal quality, additional inband measurement reports on higher layers support the scheduler decision-making process:

  • Uplink buffer status reports (measuring the data buffered in the logical channel queues in the UE) are used to provide support for QoS-aware packet scheduling
  • Power headroom reports (PHR), measuring the difference between the nominal UE maximum transmit power and the estimated power for uplink transmission, are used to provide support for power-aware packet scheduling.

Section Medium access control (MAC) protocol, page 367 provides more details on those MAC layer inband reporting procedures

Uplink data rate

The maximum data rate in 5G NR is calculated independently for the uplink and downlink directions using the formula given in Fig. 2-55 based on scheduling parameters such as the bandwidth, number of layers or modulation scheme, to name a few of the relevant parameters. Depending on the UE capabilities that influence the scaling factor f in the mentioned formula and the higher layer configuration of radio resources, typically the maximum achievable data rates on the uplink and downlink are different. In addition, the maximum data rate is restricted by the UE capability parameter total layer 2 buffer size, which is defined in TS 38.306 as the sum of the number of bytes that the UE is capable of storing in the RLC transmission windows and RLC reception and reordering windows for all radio bearers.

Transport block size calculation

The 5G NR uplink allows two distinct waveforms, OFDMA and DFT-s-OFDMA, which is also described as transform precoding. Note, that the waveform DFT-s-OFMDA, does only allow one transmission layer and optionally allows the Ï/2-BPSK modulation scheme. Thus, the higher layer parameter transformPrecoder in the PUSCH-Config information element has to be checked to know which scheme is to be used. If transform precoding is disabled, the transport block size calculation uses a similar mechanism as the downlink direction (see Transport block size calculation, page 309). An MCS indicates the modulation and coding scheme with the aid of three different tables. The higher layer parameter mcs-Table in PUSCH-Config (or ConfiguredGrantConfig if semi-persistent scheduling is applied) indicates whether 256QAM is possible and thus which of the three different tables has to be used (TS 38.214). If transform precoding is used, the higher layer parameter mcs-TableTransformPrecoder indicating whether 256QAM is possible or not points to two additional MCS tables in TS 38.214 also containing the lower data rate modulation scheme Ï/2-BPSK. Calculation of the transport block size (TBS) in the uplink direction is similar to calculation of the TBS in the downlink direction. The only difference is that the parameter xOverhead which indicates a signaling overhead may be different for each direction.

Resource assignment in the time domain

5G NR uplink assignment needs to support great flexibility for allocation of physical resources in the time domain in order to support a multitude of application scenarios such as eMBB or URLLC. The procedure for resource assignment in the uplink direction is very similar to the downlink procedure as described in Resource assignment in the time domain, page 312. The control information DCI indicates a time domain resource assignment field. This time assignment is a row index to a table that provides further information like the slot offset K2, the start and length indicator value (SLIV) and the PUSCH mapping type A or B, indicating the DMRS symbol mapping (see Fig. 1-87, page 112). Unlike the slot offset K0 for the downlink assignment which can assume either the values 0 or 1, the slot offset K2 for the uplink assignment is influenced by the subcarrier spacing and an optional RRC parameter PUSCH-TimeDomainResourceAllocationList and can assume values from 0 to 32 in the current release. The dependency on the subcarrier spacing is introduced since for larger SCS, the number of slots per subframe is increased. The values in this table are indicated either by higher layer signaling or will be used based on default value definition. When RRC signals the timing information explicitly, the IE pusch-ConfigCommon or pusch-Config may contain an IE pusch-AllocationList that will define the rows of this allocation table and the DCI parameter will refer as a row index to that table. If the higher layers do not define these information elements, there are default value tables defined in TS 38.214. In such a case, the DCI parameter points to the row index in these default tables.

Resource assignment in the frequency domain

The frequency resource allocation for the PUSCH is scheduled via DCI control information on the PDCCH. As described in the section Resource assignment in the frequency domain, page 314 for the downlink allocation, there are two types of frequency allocation: type 0 and type 1. Allocation type 0 combines a certain number of resource blocks into a resource block group (RBG) and uses a bitmap to allocate frequency resources with RBG granularity. With this method, it would be possible to obtain a frequency distributed assignment with RBG size granularity. However, allocation type 0 is not allowed when transform precoding is activated. Allocation type 1 indicates to a scheduled UE a set of contiguously allocated, localized, non-interleaved resource blocks. If the DCI uses format 0_0 for scheduling frequency resources, type 1 is used. If the DCI uses format 0_1, the allocation type 0 or 1 is indicated by the most significant bit of the FrequencyDomainResource field within the DCI message, or it may be configured by the higher layer parameter resourceAllocation in the IE PUSCH-Config directly. This frequency allocation in 5G NR presents some important changes, unlike in EUTRA, where only frequency localized allocation on the uplink is allowed. In 5G NR, the frequency allocation can now be either localized or distributed. Consequently, a higher crest factor or PAPR should be supported by the UE power amplifier.

Uplink resource allocation type 0

Frequency resource allocation type 0 introduces the term resource block group (RBG), representing a set of consecutive virtual resource blocks. The size P of the RBG is given by Fig. 2-72. The RBG size is configured by the higher layer parameter rbg-Size contained in the IE PUSCH-Config indicating configuration 1 or 2 and the size of the bandwidth part. The allocation mechanism uses a bitmap where each bit indicates whether the corresponding RBG is scheduled or not. Thus, the granularity of frequency allocation is on an RBG size basis. Allocation type 0 is not allowed when transform precoding is activated. Note that depending on the configuration of the bandwidth part with start and size values, the first and last RBG may differ slightly from size P (see TS 38.214 for further details).

Bandwidth part size in #RBsConfiguration 1 set by IE ârbg-SizeâConfiguration 2 set by IE ârbg-Sizeâ
1â3624
37â7248
73â144816
145â2751616

Fig. 2-72 Nominal RBG size P for allocation type 0.

Fig. 2-73 below has an example with frequency allocation type 0. Assuming the BWP size is given by 48 PRB and that allocation type 0 with configuration 1 is activated by the higher layers, we can read the RBG size P as equal to 4 from Fig. 2-72. This results in a bitmap size of floor(BWP_size/P), and in our example 48/4 = 12 bits. Note that depending on the BWP size and the position, the first and/or the last RBG may not be of size P. The spectrum allocation can be contiguously or non-contiguously allocated depending on the bitmap settings with a granularity of RBG size.

Uplink resource allocation type 1

Allocation type 1 indicates to the scheduled UE a start value RB and a length of allocated RBs. To indicate these parameters, via DCI scheduling a so-called resource indication value (RIV) is given via the frequency domain scheduling info. The RIV parameter is calculated specific to the bandwidth part (see TS 38.214 or Fig. 2-62 for details). Unlike the downlink assignment, in uplink allocation type 1 the mapping from virtual to physical resource blocks is performed in a localized, non-interleaved way.

Uplink precoding, reference and sounding signals and UCI multiplexing

The uplink channel PUSCH is optionally precoded based on codebook selected precoding. The precoding matrix W is selected from a codebook based on the TPMI scheduling info received from the DCI. Other parameters influencing the codebook selection are the number of layers and antenna ports obtained from a higher layer. See 1.2.5.5 Antenna ports, precoding and quasi co-located Â­antennas, page 98 and TS 38.214 for further details on precoding. The PUSCH is accompanied by uplink DMRS signals for demodulation support and channel equalizing mechanisms. The DMRS allows highly flexible configuration (see 1.2.5.6 Physical signals in 5G NR, page 110 for further details on the parameters for DMRS generation). In addition to the DMRS, a UE may be configured to transmit SRS signals in additional frequency regions and in the time domain to allow the base station to perform channel estimation. These SRS make it possible to tackle the impact of a frequency selective channel by finding out the âbestâ frequency region using channel estimation methods. The SRS typically have a higher power spectral density than an intermittent PUSCH in case of sporadic data transmission and therefore enable the gNB to perform scheduling decisions and implement beamforming techniques. Note that there is no simultaneous transmission of PUSCH and PUCCH in the current release. If the UE has to send uplink control information (UCI) and this coincides in the time with a PUSCH transmission, the UCI information will be multiplexed into the PUSCH data stream (TS 38.300).

2.2.9 Uplink control information (UCI)

Like legacy mobile communications technologies, 5G NR also uses the concept of uplink control information feedback to either maintain the radio link or enhance scheduling decisions by the network. As is known, the radio channel is affected by physical radio effects such as multipath propagation, Doppler shift, inter-cell or adjacent channel interference, and time and frequency variant channels, to name only a few of the known effects. In addition, it is possible that the data connection fluctuates in response to QoS request. As described in 1.2 Physical access fundamentals, page 46 the 5G NR provides a very flexible air interface including technologies such as flexible subcarrier spacing, adaptive modulation and coding and bandwidth part configuration. In addition, we already mentioned that 5G NR is a radio network based on beamforming techniques. Base stations use a hardware configuration known as massive MIMO and the UE may also support beamforming techniques on the uplink. It is not our intention here to describe all the advantages of beamforming in relation to capacity improvements, path loss compensation and interference reduction, but one aspect is obvious: beamforming is wonderful, but it is even better to know the direction in which to beamform. Beamforming is a complex technology which requires mutual information from the UE and network through link measurements on the downlink and possibly also on the uplink (see 1.3 Beamforming fundamentals, page 169 for further details). Therefore, the UCI is extended from previous technologies to cover the beam status of the link. To support network scheduling decisions and beamforming methodology, the UE provides feedback in the form of quality reports to the network. The UCI information is carried either on the PUCCH or the PUSCH. The PUCCH provides multiple formats that are selected depending on the UCI content and quantity of UCI control information (see the section Physical uplink control channel (PUCCH), page 85 for more details). UCI information that is sent on the PUSCH is based on multiplexing UCI information within the higher layer data. In general, the UCI consists of the following parameters:

  • CSI feedback as channel status information
  • ACK/NACK for HARQ acknowledgments or non-acknowledgments
  • Scheduling request for obtaining additional uplink resources

Note that these three parameters are not necessarily transmitted all together in a single UCI. Depending on the situation, a single UCI may contain either CSI only, or ACK/ NACK only, or maybe CSI + ACK/NACK combined as an extract of the possible UCI combinations. For the sake of completeness, even if it is not reporting channel information, the UE assists the networkâs scheduling decision with optional transmission of sounding reference signals (SRS). They are necessary for two major reasons: The first is that the data connection in the 5G system is based on a transmission buffer. Whenever the buffer is filled with pending data, radio resources are requested, but when there is no data in the buffer, the radio interface may be unused for a certain time. Assuming some time variance on the radio channel or mobility of the UE, the network may trigger SRS signals on the uplink to perform channel estimation for expected future scheduling decisions.

The second reason is related to the power spectral density: If no UL data is sent, the UCI reports may not be sufficient in providing power spectral density that allows channel estimation and beamforming decisions. This becomes obvious if we understand that UCI reports are configurable but are active in connected mode only. In order to support the network with scheduling and beamforming decisions, there is (in addition to uplink channel information) also SRS transmission. For more details on SRS signal power, see the section Sounding reference signals (SRS) â power control, page 129.

On the other hand, we may have to understand the SRS as overhead that steals RF resources from the overall capacity in the uplink direction and consumes battery power for transmission. Thus, the SRS configuration is a meticulous setting where the network administrator has to carefully consider the options. The general model for uplink channel feedback is shown in Fig. 2-74.

Like other physical layer aspects, the uplink channel information also offers a high level of flexibility. The following section describes the content and configuration aspects in greater detail.

Scheduling requests

As introduced in 2.2.6 Uplink scheduling request and buffer status reporting, page 326, uplink data transfer is based on the concept of logical and transport channels plus a buffer that contains pending data. When there are uplink resources assigned, there is an inband reporting of the MAC layer buffer status (explained in Fig. 2-98, page 375) which the network can then consider when scheduling PUSCH.

On the other hand, whenever there is data pending in the MAC layer buffer and no UL resources are available during a connection, the UE may send scheduling requests on the PUCCH only.

HARQ feedback
