As described in 2.2.5 Hybrid automatic repeat request (HARQ) operation, page 318, downlink data reception must be acknowledged by sending HARQ feedback to the network. This HARQ feedback can either be sent on the PUCCH or the PUSCH when available. In the case where HARQ-ACK feedback is sent on the PUSCH and the size is 1 or 2 bits, the PUSCH data will be punctured. If the UCI information is larger, rate matching is applied. The section Channel coding for small block lengths, page 152 described the possibility of segmentation of a transport block into various code blocks. If this is activated, HARQ-ACK feedback is based on a codebook based feedback principle instead of a single feedback per transport block. If a UE is not provided with the higher layer parameter PDSCH-CodeBlockGroupTransmission in the PhysicalCellGroup-Config IE which explicitly configures transport block segmentation into code blocks, the UE generates one HARQ-ACK information bit per transport block. Segmentation into code blocks may lead to either a single or multiple HARQ-ACK bit feedback, but all these code blocks must belong to the same transport block for this particular HARQ process. The HARQ-ACK feedback is sent via so-called HARQ codebooks. They are configured by higher layer parameters. Further details on the HARQ codebook determination algorithm are given in TS 38.213. The HARQ codebook can either be semi-static or dynamic. There is the HARQ type 1 codebook for the semi-static case and the HARQ type 2 codebook for the dynamic case.

There is a further distinction depending on whether the HARQ codebooks are transferred on the PUSCH or the PUCCH. The parameter maxCodeBlockGroupsPerTransportBlock indicates the maximum number of code block groups (CBG) per transport block and has possible values of 2, 4, 6 or 8. In case spatial multiplexing with a higher rank is active so that two code words can be sent simultaneously, the maximum number of CBGs is restricted to either 2 or 4. In addition, the parameters harq-ACK-SpatialBundlingPUCCH or harq-ACK-SpatialBundlingPUSCH indicate whether spatial bundling of HARQ-ACK feedback is allowed or not. Spatial bundling of HARQ-ACK is described in TS 38.213 as follows: If an occasion for a candidate PDSCH reception can be in response to a PDCCH with DCI format 1_1 and if the higher layer parameter maxNrofCodeWordsScheduledByDCI indicates reception of two transport blocks, when the UE receives a PDSCH with one transport block, the HARQ-ACK information is associated with the first transport block and the UE generates an NACK for the second transport block if the higher layer parameter harq-ACK-SpatialBundlingPUCCH is not provided and generates HARQ-ACK information with a value of ACK for the second transport block if the higher layer parameter harq-ACK-SpatialBundlingPUCCH is provided.

Channel state information (CSI)

Channel state information (CSI) is an uplink feedback report about downlink perceived signal quality parameters. It consists of the following values:

  • Channel quality indicator (CQI) representing a quality indicator for the perceived downlink signal that has an impact on consecutive scheduling decisions on TBS and MCS selection
  • Precoding matrix indicator (PMI) influencing the precoding scheme for the downlink. Note that this does not represent an explicit command for the precoding scheme that must be applied in consecutive downlink transmission. Furthermore, it provides control information to support network precoding selection only. For details on precoding, see e.g. 1.2.5.5 Antenna ports, precoding and quasi co-located Â­antennas, page 98
  • CSI-RS resource indicator (CRI) assisting the beamforming scheduling decision by reporting the CSI-RS that has been detected as âbestâ. When assuming that the network has applied beamforming on those CSI-RS signals, it represents a method to identify the âbestâ beam
  • SS/PBCH block resource indicator (SSBRI) used to identify the SSB resource that is received by the UE
  • Layer indicator (LI) indicating the strongest layer in case of e.g. two code words reporting (SU-MIMO) or PMI matrix layer reporting
  • Rank indicator (RI) corresponding to the rank of the channel matrix for SU-MIMO or spatial multiplexing
  • L1-RSRP representing the layer 1 reference signal receiver power that is calculated based on CSI-RS and/or SS/PBCH block resources depending on the higher layer configuration. Main difference is that the SSB power level in downlink is commonly valid for all UEs within that particular cell area, while the CSI-RS may be UE specific.

Channel status reports in 5G NR support multiple purposes. Since the technology offers a very high level of flexibility, the complexity of channel status feedback is increased. The primary purpose of CSI feedback is support for scheduling decisions like adaptive modulation and coding, support for spatial multiplexing or SU-MIMO by providing feedback on the channel correlation status and to support beamforming techniques by providing information on the beam status and interference situations. These are only a few purposes of the CSI feedback mechanism and we can see that the general motivation of flexibility is also the baseline for CSI feedback. The CSI reports can be sent periodically, semi-persistently or aperiodically depending on the higher layer configuration. Such reports can be sent on either the PUCCH or PUSCH channel in the uplink direction. The CSI reports are controlled by the RRC configuration details which are CSI-ReportConfig, CSI-ResourceConfig and one or two trigger state lists. In a first simplified approach, the CSI report configuration describes what has to be measured and how it has to be reported. The CSI resource configuration describes where the UE has to perform measurements and with the trigger state list, the network can influence the CSI reporting. Each CSI report configuration is associated with a single downlink BWP and contains parameters such as the codebook configuration and subset restriction for PMI reporting, time-domain behavior for reporting aperiodically or periodically, frequency granularity by validating reports on either wideband or subband, and optional measurement restrictions. In addition, CSI reported quantities such as LI, L1-RSRP, CRI and SSBRI can be reported by the UE in a combined procedure. The CSI resource configuration provides a list of CSI-RS resources which are either NZP CSI-RS, CSI-IM and SS/PBCH blocks. Fig. 2-75 gives a brief overview of the CSI reporting configurations.

Regarding the timing behavior of CSI reporting and resources, we have said that CSI reporting itself can be aperiodic, periodic or semi-persistent, and also the CSI resources underlying the actual measurements can be aperiodic, periodic or semi-persistent. This leads to several combinations of CSI reporting and CSI resource configuration as shown in Fig. 2-76.

CSI-RS configurationPeriodic CSI reportingSemi-persistent CSI reportingAperiodic CSI reporting
Periodic CSI-RSNo dynamic triggering/activationPUCCH reporting â¶
activation command on MAC
PUSCH reporting â¶
triggering on DCI		Triggered by DCI
(additionally MAC activation posssible)
Semi-persistent CSI-RSNot supported
Aperiodic CSI-RSNot supportedNot supported

Fig. 2-76 CSI reporting and resource configuration â time behavior.
Time behavior of CSI-RS resources;   Time behavior of CSI-RS reporting

Note that the reports can be sent either on the PUCCH or PUSCH depending on the higher layer configuration. The MAC layer allows transmission of a so-called activation command that can be used in addition to DCI triggering of aperiodic CSI reports (see TS 38.321 for further details).

A serving cell is configured with a single RRC information element CSI-MeasConfig to indicate and provide information for CSI reporting. The CSI-MeasConfig element contains in general three major items: a CSI-ResourceConfig describing the resources where the measurements have to be performed, a CSI-ReportConfig describing further information on how the report should look, and a trigger state list associated with CSI-ReportConfig describing trigger states for either aperiodic or semi-persistent reporting.

CSI-ResourceConfig contains the description of RF resources like CSI-RS that can be either non-zero power, i.e. NZP-CSI-RS or zero power, i.e. ZP-CSI-RS and are used predominantly for UE-specific or beam-specific channel status measurements and optionally for interference measurements. In addition, the serving cell can configure additional SSBs to be used for channel status measurements on a cell-specific level.

CSI-ReportConfig describes further configuration details for how these measurement results should be reported, i.e. whether the reports should occur in an aperiodic, periodic or semi-persistent manner and in what quantity or under what time restriction they should occur. This is in addition to RF resource information about where they should be reported, i.e. PUCCH information. There is a possibility that CSI-MeasConfig for a serving cell may only contain CSI-RS ResourceConfig information which would represent a situation where the serving cell does not support beamforming and does not require CSI-RS based feedback from the UE. Fig. 2-77 describes the general structure of the CSI-MeasConfig information element.

A further detailed description is given in Fig. 2-78, describing the dependencies. A CSI-ReportConfig is linked to CSI-ResourceConfig elements. CSI-ResourceConfig typically contains resources for channel status and interference measurements. The CSI-RS, which are actively transmitted, are named as non-zero power NZP-CSI-RS and can be mapped onto resource elements. They can also be beamformed. Typically, these NZP-CSI-RS can now be used for either channel status reporting or for interference measurements. We can imagine a scenario where the serving cell uses these NZP-CSI-RS to discover a better âserving cellâ, but also to identify interfering cells. In addition to the NZP-CSI-RS which may be understood as UE-specific or beamformed, the serving cell can also request measurements on a more cell-specific resource which will be given by the SSB blocks as the CSI-SSB. Opposite to the NZP-CSI-RS, which indicate the reference signals that are transmitted, the serving cell can also configure resource elements that are used for zero-power reference signals (ZP-CSI-RS). The idea is that these resource elements will not be transmitted and thus they represent an occasion where the UE can perform measurements like power level RSSI that would permit the gNB to identify an interference situation. Unfortunately, the ZP-CSI-RS are very brief and may collide with the PDSCH resources of neighbor cells. Thus, the network may also configure NZP-CSI-RS on neighbor cells for interference measurements.

As an example of the CSI-RS reporting and resource configuration, we can consider the scenario shown in Fig. 2-79. The scenario illustrates a situation with two 5G NR cells, provided by two transmission points (TRP). Each TRP has set up three beams that contain the CSI-RS for channel status and interference measurements.

Assuming a UE with a connection to only one of those TRPs, two questions come up: first, considering some mobility and a serving cell change, which of the two TRPs (or more precisely, which of the beams) behaves as the âbest serverâ. The second question relates to the situation whether there is interference occurring between the two TRPs. The CSI reporting setting is associated with three resource settings. The CSI-RS resource(s) within resource setting 0 consisting of NZP-CSI-RS is for channel status measurements. The CSI-RS resource(s) within resource setting 1 consisting of ZP-CSI-RS and resource setting 2 consisting of NZP-CSI-RS are for interference measurements.

For resource setting 0, two NZP-CSI-RS resource sets are configured, where set 0-1 corresponds to the channel status measurements performed on three NZP-CSI-RS resources issued from TRP1 and set 0-2 corresponds to channel status measurements performed on three NZP-CSI-RS resources from TRP2, respectively. Each set contains three NZP-CSI-RS resources corresponding to three beamformed CSI-RS.

For resource setting 1, two ZP-CSI-RS resource sets are configured, where set 1-1 corresponds to two configured zero-power ZP-CSI-IM resources for TRP1, while set 1-2 corresponds to one zero-power ZP-CSI-IM resource for TRP2.

For resource setting 2, two NZP-CSI-RS resource sets are configured, where set 2-1 configured for TRP1 is associated with set 0-2 and used for interference measurements from TRP 2. Set 2-2 configured for TRP2 is associated with set 0-1 and used for interference measurements from TRP 1.

As already described, the CSI-RS reports can be aperiodic, periodic or semi-static. In addition, the higher layer configures whether these measurements have to be performed on wide or narrow subbands and in what quantity they have to be measured. Furthermore, beamforming can be UE-specific and the beams can be refined after a connection is established. Such beam refinement can be realized via precoding as described in 1.2.5.5 Antenna ports, precoding and quasi co-located Â­antennas, page 98. To support the network in precoding decisions, the UE reports a precoding matrix identifier (PMI). For further details on CSI reporting, refer to specification documents TS 38.214 et al.

2.2.10 Data flow through 5G NR protocol layers

Like all wireless communications networks, 5G NR also introduces a protocol structure that enables and maintains a data connection via the so-called user plane (UP). To control and supervise this data connection, the 5G NR system provides protocol layers belonging to the control plane (CP). Both protocol structures have been briefly introduced in 1.1.3 Access stratum protocol, page 21 and 1.1.4 Non-access stratum protocol, page 39. The section here focuses on the behavior of the user plane protocol layers.

Generally speaking, a protocol layer offers services and functions to higher layers and establishes a peer-to-peer connection to its peer layer. In addition, a protocol layer typically adds a protocol header to the received SDU to enable and support its function. An example of such a data flow is given in Fig. 2-80, assuming two connections. These connections are indicated as radio bearer 1 and 2 in the figure. We assume that the two radio bearers are transferring data as IP data packets to the SDAP protocol which is the highest RAN protocol layer. As an example of layer 2 behavior, two procedures are depicted: the concatenation functionality in the MAC layer and the segmentation functionality in the RLC layer. This chapter provides more details on these functions as well as the protocol header and various formats from a top to bottom perspective.

The general data flow through the user plane stratum is depicted in Fig. 2-81, indicating the various functional behaviors on each protocol layer. This example is from the downlink perspective. In the uplink direction, the difference is that only one of the depicted columns is present as there is only a one-to-one connection, while on the downlink we have a one-to-many connection. This figure must be considered in conjunction with the general introduction to the 5G NR protocol stratum (1.1.3.3 User plane protocol, page 27), but it describes a general and simplified view of the protocol stratum. Features like carrier aggregation and dual connectivity with split bearer mechanisms, which are possible in 5G NR, are not illustrated in the Fig. 2-81 [TS 38.300].

Service data adaptation protocol (SDAP)

The SDAP protocol has been introduced as a new protocol layer compared to the LTE user plane stratum. Its main responsibility is provisioning and maintenance of QoS flows coming from the core network to allow multiple service level agreements (SLA) within the subscription to a 5G system. 5G is a QoS driven technology which is expected to provide and guarantee data transfer according to a certain QoS policy. Details on QoS aspects are described in 2.2.2 End to end quality of service, page 285.

In the protocol structure, referring to the well-known OSI model, SDAP is the highest layer that belongs to the 5G NR system user plane structure. All higher layers such as IP, TCP and UDP can be considered as out of scope protocols. Thus, the introduction of the SDAP protocol can be simplified as the introduction of a end to end data pipe or tunnel that guarantees, supervises and maintains a certain QoS profile throughout the 5G system. SDAP is the protocol that is linked to the concept of QoS flows. In conjunction with the lower layers, it supports various service requests by provisioning multiple QoS related functions.

Briefly described in 1.1.3.3 User plane protocol, page 27, SDAP links a QoS flow ID to a certain QoS flow for the corresponding PDU session.

There is one SDAP entity for each PDU session. The main function of SDAP is to map QoS flows to data radio bearers (DRB). When the RRC protocol layer configures a radio bearer via RadioBearerConfig, it may include a list of DRBs to be added and each element in the list may be accompanied by SDAP-config information. As there are multiple connectivity scenarios to the 5G core (see 1.1.2.1 Connectivity scenarios, page 13), the SDAPconfig is mandatory for dual connectivity scenarios.

The SDAP-config contains the QFI to be used as the identifier of the QoS flow. It controls whether an SDAP header is to be present or not. The SDAP header is required only for reflective QoS. In the uplink direction, SDAP supports reflective QoS flow mapping to reduce signaling overhead. Reflective QoS mapping means the UE will apply the same QoS flow to uplink SDAP PDUs as it has seen on the downlink.

One of the configured DRBs is used as the default DRB and all QoS flows not explicitly identified will be mapped onto this default DRB. There is no additional control function offered by the SDAP layer. It offers user plane data transfer to higher layers and expects in-order delivery from lower layers.

To enable data transport, SDAP builds a data packet (SDAP PDU) and maps it on the respective DRB. The SDAP PDU can be with or without an attached header field.

Two header types exist: One is used for data transfer and the other for control. The control header only consists of an end-marker control PDU header that signals the end of the listed QFI data flow. The data PDU header field contains the QFI value and on the downlink, two fields RDI and RQI that control reflective QoS flow mapping. Fig. 2-82 describes the general behavior of the SDAP protocol entities. Further information on e.g. SDAP header fields can be found in TS 37.324.

Packet data convergence protocol (PDCP)

The PDCP layer provides data transfer services to higher layers. In the protocol structure, the PDCP layer is either connected to the user plane (UP) or to the control plane (CP). Thus, it provides data transport services for both data and control. This data transfer service is based on the introduction of the term radio bearer that can be further subdivided into a data radio bearer (DRB) or a signaling radio bearer (SRB). A radio bearer can be simplified as a data transfer channel for one PDU session that is linked to a certain QoS flow. The data transfer service provided by the PDCP layer is accompanied by additional services such as sequence numbering, ciphering and integrity protection, duplication and dispatching mechanisms to support dual connectivity scenarios and selection of the transfer modes AM, UM or TM by the RLC layer. This RLC mode selection has, of course, an impact on the QoS of the data bearer, i.e. priority for either throughput and latency or reliability with an additional ARQ mechanism. For each UE, the NG-RAN establishes at least one data radio bearer together with the PDU session offering one QoS flow. It is possible to subsequently establish additional DRBs with different QoS flows for the same PDU session or, of course, additional DRBs for additional PDU sessions. For a brief overview of the functions provided by the PDCP layer, see 1.1.3.3 User plane protocol, page 27. This section provides further details.

The PDCP layer combines data arriving from the control and user plane with regards to its lower layers and provides data transport plus additional functions to its higher layers RRC for the CP stratum or SDAP for the UP stratum. It receives data via radio bearers, further categorized as either DRB or SRB, and maps them onto RLC channels, connected to the different RLC modes AM, UM or TM. Thus, the PDCP layer is involved for data using radio bearers that will be mapped onto either DTCH or DCCH logical channels. General control information such as the system information broadcast or common control using the SRB0 is not associated with a PDCP entity. Compared with the EUTRA PDCP layer, the NR PDCP layer provides similar functions, but there are a few marginal differences. For example, PDCP in NR supports dual connectivity since it supports split or non-split radio bearer characteristics.

Each radio bearer except SRB0 is associated with one PDCP entity and each PDCP entity is associated with one, two or four RLC entities depending on the radio bearer characteristic, which can be unidirectional, bidirectional UL/DL and split/non-split in case of dual connectivity. For non-split bearers, each PDCP entity is associated with one UM RLC entity for unidirectional data transfer, two UM RLC entities (one for each direction), or one AM RLC entity. For split bearers, each PDCP entity is associated with two UM RLC entities (for the same direction), four UM RLC entities (two for each direction), or two AM RLC entities (for the same direction).

The main services of the PDCP layer (Fig. 2-83) are:

  • Transfer of user plane and control plane data (for each DRB and SRB, there is one PDCP entity)
  • Header compression, ROHC mechanism supporting various methods defined via different RFC standards. The header compression is not applicable to the SDAP header and the SDAP control PDU if included in the PDCP SDU
  • Security mechanisms: ciphering and integrity protection
  • Routing function to support dual connectivity
  • Packet duplication

These main services are also the main functions of the PDCP layer. In addition, the PDCP layer supports duplicate handling for data packets, sequence numbering (important in relation to handovers), routing for split bearer operations in DC mode, and a timer-based discard function for lost packets. A PDCP entity can be established, re-established and released depending on requests from upper layers. TS 38.323 provides further information on such operations. As one difference compared to LTE PDCP operation, the NR PDCP layer supports the possibility of data duplication, e.g. if configured by the higher layer pdcp-Duplication parameter contained in the RRC message PDCP-Config, the transmitting entity will duplicate the PDCP data PDU and deliver it to both associated RLC entities. See Fig. 1-14, page 32 indicating the different radio bearer types. In case of a split bearer type, the PDCP layer dispatches between the primary and secondary RLC entity on either the master or secondary cell. On the receiving end, in case duplication is enabled, the PDCP layer is in close contact with the RLC layer and may provide information about discarding of an already received PDU. The main objective is to support reliability in URLLC scenarios. The lower layers have to provide either dual connectivity or carrier aggregation functionality on the radio link. Another option is support for split bearer: Here, the RRC assigns one RLC entity to be the primary RLC entity. A higher layer threshold for the uplink direction UL-DataSplitThreshold sets a limit up to which the PDUs have to be sent over the primary RLC. When this threshold is passed, the UE may use either the primary or secondary RLC entity. Thus, the split bearer option behaves like an overflow avoidance mechanism in simplified terms. The sequence numbering mechanism is needed to guarantee lossless packet transfer, especially in handover situations or DC situations when MCG or SCG activation or deactivation occur. In addition, the sequence number may support in-order delivery, but note that an RRC parameter outOfOrderDelivery may force the receiving entity to not consider in-order delivery of PDUs.

The sequence number can have two possible lengths (12 or 18 bits), configured via pdcp-SN-Size separately for UL and DL, except for SRB. Here, the SN is always set to the 12-bit length. This sequence number is used as one input to the ciphering and integrity protection algorithms and thus the length is considered to be too short for implementation of acceptable security mechanisms. Increasing the SN would cause excessive overhead. For this reason, the PDCP layer introduces a second sequential value: the hyper frame number (HFN). The SN is incremented in an inner loop from 0 to 2PDCP_SN_size. Whenever the upper boundary is reached, the HFN is incremented by one (Fig. 2-103, page 384).

This resulting sequence number consisting of two parts, the SN within the PDU and the HFN, is used to calculate the value COUNT, which is used as an input parameter for ciphering and deciphering by both PDCP peer entities. The PDCP layer supports the security mechanisms of ciphering and integrity protection. Ciphering prevents eavesdropping of communications, while integrity protection digitally signs the message to prevent an attacker impersonating the sender (âman in the middleâ). For SRB, both ciphering and integrity protection are mandatory, while for DRB they can be configured by the RRC parameters integrityProtection and cipheringDisabled. To avoid buffer overflow at the transmitting entity, a timer discardTimer ranging from 10 ms to 1500 ms is set by higher layers. This timer can be set to infinity. As a trade-off between latency and reliability, the receiving entity provides a reordering window buffer to PDUs to be placed in sequential order and runs a timer t-Reordering with values ranging from 0 ms to 2750 ms (or infinity in case of SRB) that is used to identify lost PDUs. The PDCP layer provides two kind of PDUs: One is called the data PDU and is used to convey data received from upper layers, i.e. either user plane data via DRB or control plane data via SRB. The other PDU is called the control PDU and has two use cases: Submission of a status report acknowledging the received data PDUs from the receiving entity, and delivery of feedback to ROHC as âinterspersedâ ROHC feedback. The status report is triggered via higher layers, e.g. RRC-reconfiguration in handover scenarios, and guarantees lossless data transfer, especially for acknowledged mode DRBs. The status report PDU used for AM bearer types contains two major control fields: A mandatory indicator first missing counter (FMC) pointing to the counter value of the first missing PDU within a reordering window, and an optional bitmap field, selectively indicating additional lost PDUs. To support such reporting, the receiving entity uses two state variables: The first one RX_NEXT points to the next sequence number to be expected, and the second one RX_DELIV indicates the first SDU that was not yet delivered to higher layers but is still expected. Within a status report, the FMC state variable is typically set with the value of RX_DELIV. In case the counter of RX_DELIV is lower than RX_NEXT, an optional bitmap is included in the status report marking all sequence numbers of SDUs that are considered as lost. The packet header formats for both types (data and control PDU) are given in Fig. 2-84 and Fig. 2-85. For further details on 5G NR security aspects, see 2.2.12 Data security, page 384.

Radio link control protocol (RLC)

The RLC protocol layer enables a peer-to-peer connection between the RLC entity in the UE and the RLC entity in the gNB DU for transfer of RLC PDUs that can either be data PDUs or control PDUs. The RLC offers three possible transfer modes via its RLC entities: acknowledged mode (AM), unacknowledged mode (UM) and transparent mode (TM). Transparent mode is used for common and broadcast control channels, and acknowledged mode for dedicated control channels. User traffic can either select UM or AM, depending on the general QoS flow settings. In a vertical orientation, the RLC layer offers data transfer functions to the PDCP and RRC layers and uses the transfer function of the underlying MAC layer. In general, it performs a mapping of SDUs received via RLC channels onto PDUs mapped onto logical channels (see also Fig. 1-9, page 22). The size of the SDU can be variable in all three modes. In UM and AM mode, the RLC SDU may be segmented and transferred via multiple RLC PDUs, which are byte-aligned. There is one major difference between the behavior of the RLC protocol in LTE vs. NR that is depicted in Fig. 2-86 and concerns the aspects of segmentation and concatenation. In LTE, the RLC layer could either segment a larger SDU into smaller segments to create a PDU, or there is the possibility of concatenating smaller SDUs into a larger PDU size. This offers the flexibility of creating PDUs of variable sizes. To enable preprocessing on both the MAC and RLC layer, it was decided for the 5G NR RLC behavior to only allow segmentation of RLC SDUs into PDUs. Such preprocessing steps are e.g. channel coding operations before the final assembly of a PDU, the configuration of the transport block size or the definition of the protocol header fields before the final assembly. This decision helps to support latency aspects, especially for URLLC services. Preprocessing allows, for example, the RLC entity to receive a higher layer PDCP SDU even if no MAC resources are yet available and store it in a buffer as the pending PDU (already prepared with valid headers and sequence numbers).

Transparent mode (TM) entity in the RLC layer

The TM entity is used solely to transfer data from the logical control channel for broadcasting system information and paging, BCCH, PCCH or UL/DL CCCH. This data is characterized by a transport format known a priori or a constant data rate. Thus, the TM entity cannot be used for user data traffic conveyed via the DTCH logical channel. As a specific transfer characteristic, the TM entity does not segment the RLC SDU and does not attach a RLC header. This TM mode is feasible, since the information via logical control channels involves higher layer control messages that should not be split via segmentation and may have a constant length. In addition, the content information is given by the logical channel itself, i.e. BCCH only contains system information, thus no additional protocol header information is needed. There is no acknowledgement for the TM entity as we may understand a kind of acknowledgement given by the application itself, i.e. a missing RRCConnectonSetup message following a random access request that is not properly received by the gNB will lead to retransmission of the PRACH sequence by the UE.

The general transfer model for the RLC TM entity is given in Fig. 2-87 (TS 38.322).

Unacknowledged mode (UM) entity in the RLC layer

The UM entity is used solely for user plane data transfer via UL/DL DTCH logical channels. It represents a method for user traffic with a lower QoS flow priority for reliability but greater focus on latency aspects. A major characteristic of the UM entity is the possibility for data segmentation allowing variable data throughput and adaptation to capacity provided by lower layers. In comparison to EUTRAN, 5G NR RLC UM only supports segmentation of RLC SDUs into RLC PDUs. Meanwhile, EUTRAN supports segmentation and concatenation. This is primarily due to latency aspects for URLLC since the entire transmission of one RLC SDU, or the transfer of a segment within one RLC PDU, avoids waiting times at the receiving entity due to concatenation and uses a kind of FIFO register principle. When notified of a transmission opportunity by the lower layer, the transmitting UM RLC entity must segment the RLC SDUs, if necessary, so that the corresponding UM data (UMD PDU), with possibly updated RLC headers, fit within the total size of the RLC PDU(s) indicated by the lower layer. The receiving RLC entity will reassemble the received RLC SDUs from the RLC PDUs provided by the MAC layer and deliver them to the higher layer. If an RLC SDU cannot be reassembled due to the loss of RLC PDUs on the lower layers, the RLC PDU will be discarded. In unacknowledged mode, the transfer function model is given by Fig. 2-88 (TS 38.322):

To support data transfer, the RLC UM entity attaches three possible header types to the RLC SDU depending on the higher layer configuration and whether segmentation is enabled or not. The parameters for the RLC UM header are:

  • Segmentation info (SI): A 2-bit field that indicates whether the RLC PDU contains the entire RLC SDU, the first or last segment of the RLC SDU, or neither the first nor the last segment
  • Sequence number (SN) of the corresponding RLC SDU: This can have 6 or 12 bits depending on the RRC layer IE sn_FieldLength. For UMD, the sequence number is incremented for every segmented RLC SDU. Note that an RLC PDU that contains the entire RLC SDU does not contain a sequence number SN in its header
  • Segment offset (SO): A 16-bit field indicating the position of the RLC SDU segment in bytes within the original RLC SDU. Based on this parameter, reassembly of the segmented RLC SDU is guaranteed to occur in the correct order

An RLC header contains the sequence number (SN) field only when the RLC SDU is segmented. This represents a minor difference compared to the LTE RLC layer since there is no reordering performed in NR RLC UM mode. It does not contain the segment offset (SO) field if the first RLC SDU segment is contained in the current UMD PDU.

With the header types for RLC UM, certain differences compared to EUTRAN are introduced on the RLC layer, i.e. the header no longer contains a length indicator field that was available in EUTRAN for indicating various concatenated RLC SDUs within one RLC PDU. In addition, the frame indicator field is no longer present and has been replaced by a segment information field. Since there is no concatenation mechanism in the NR RLC entity, this length indicator field is now obsolete. If the UMD SDU fits completely into a UMD PDU, there is no sequence number attached and the receiving entity will deliver it to the higher layers immediately as it is unacknowledged mode. For data transfer operation in RLC UM mode, several counters, state variables and timers are defined in TS 38.322 to guarantee that the UM functions can perform reassembly and discarding of RLC PDUs. The segmented SDUs are counted by a sequence number (SN) that is incremented by the transmitting entity following the last UMD SDU segment. First, there is a reassembly window defined as a constant given by the value UM_Window_Size, which can assume a value of 32 if SN has a length of 6 bits or 2048 if SN has a length of 12 bits. The upper bound of the reassembly window is set by a counter RX_Next_Highest which is incremented if a RLC PDU with a sequence number (SN) greater than RX-Next_Highest is received. As a kind of next expected SN that has to be reassembled and delivered to higher layers, the counter RX_Next_Reassembly points to the SN which is lowest among the undelivered RLC SDUs. Thus, any SN that falls in the window between RX_Next_Highest and RX_Next_Reassambly will be placed in the reception buffer of the receiving RLC UM entity. To enable the removal or discarding of RLC PDUs that are not received by lower layers, the timer t_Reassembly (configurable by the RRC layer) serves as a kind of maximum wait time for pending RLC PDUs. This timer operates in conjunction with a pointer RX_Time_Trigger, indicating the SN that started the t_Reassembly timer. Typically, RX_Time_Trigger has the value of RX_Next_Highest and will be updated when t-Reassembly expires or when counter RX_Next_Reassembly falls below RX_Next_Highest. When the timer t-Reassembly expires, the counter RX_Next_Reassembly will be set to the value of RX_Time_Trigger and all RLC PDUs with lower sequence numbers will be discarded and considered as lost. Fig. 2-90 provides an overview of these state variables:

Acknowledged mode (AM) entity in the RLC layer

The AM entity within the RLC layer provides data transfer to higher layers including error correction functionality due to its inherited ARQ mechanism. Transmitted data is buffered and retransmitted if necessary. Note that this ARQ operation resides on top of the HARQ operation performed by the MAC and PHY lower layers and thus represents a second level of error correction at the expense of latency aspects. Thus, the connection management must balance the trade-off between latency and reliability. Data transport services offered by the AM entity are valid for the logical channels DTCH and DCCH only. Thus, the dedicated control channel can be considered as inheriting a QoS flow that is focused more on reliability. Meanwhile, user traffic has the option of either AM or UM mode depending on the general QoS flow settings for this particular PDU session. Like UM mode, the AM entity offers segmentation services for SDUs to create PDUs with the size indicated by the lower layers, but concatenation is once again not possible (as was the case in the LTE RLC entity). In addition to supporting the data flow, the AM entity provides a control mechanism based on the definition of control packets (RLC STATUS PDU) that control the acknowledged data flow. Note that RLC control PDUs have a higher priority than RLC AMD PDUs if there is a conflict in the transmission buffer. The general model for the RLC AM entity is given in Fig. 2-91 (TS 38.322). The transmission and retransmission mechanism must be aligned with the segmentation mechanism to avoid the risk of losing data segments. Imagine a PDU is transmitted for the first time and therefore buffered. Due to a negative acknowledgement, it has to be retransmitted, but in the meantime the RLC size indicated by the lower layer is no longer the same. In such a case, the transmitting RLC may have to resegment the SDU. The receiving end monitors based on the sequence number for possible duplicate reception of PDUs and discards them if relevant. It monitors for possible loss of pending PDUs and triggers retransmission based on the ARQ mechanism. However, upon reaching the maximum number of retransmissions with no success, it informs the higher layer of the loss of data.

To support data flow in RLC AM mode, a header is attached to each RLC AMD PDU that may contain different information fields and use different formats. The information fields used in the AM PDU header are similar to those for the UMD PDU, but with a few additional information fields.

  • Data or control discriminator (D/C): A 1-bit field that discriminates whether the current PDU is an AMD PDU or a STATUS PDU for control purposes
  • Polling bit (P): A 1-bit field that is used by the transmitting entity to request a STATUS report (if P = 1) from its receiving peer entity for the purpose of data acknowledgement
  • Segmentation info (SI): A 2-bit field that indicates whether the RLC PDU contains the entire RLC SDU, the first or last segment of the RLC SDU, or neither the first nor the last segment
  • Sequence number (SN) of the corresponding RLC SDU: This can have 12 or 18 bits depending of the RRC layer IE sn_FieldLength. For AMD, the sequence number is incremented for every RLC SDU
  • Segment offset (SO): A 16-bit field indicating the position of the RLC SDU segment in bytes within the original RLC SDU. Based on this parameter, reassembly of the segmented RLC SDU is guaranteed to occur in the correct order

The total length of the RLC AM header is either 2 or 3 bytes.

The AM RLC entity protocol header fields are slightly different compared to the LTE RLC header fields. Since no concatenation of data packets is allowed in AM RLC, the protocol header no longer requires a length indicator field. Moreover, there is no need for a resegmentation flag, which is only necessary if during retransmission, a lower layer may have changed the transportation block size. Every AM SDU is counted with a sequence number (SN). For data transfer operation in RLC AM mode, several counters, state variables and timers are defined in TS 38.322 to support the AM functions of ARQ feedback and retransmission, reassembly and discarding of RLC PDUs. The segmented SDUs will be counted by a sequence number (SN) that is mapped by the transmitting entity to the same SN as the RLC SDU. These sequence numbers are the basis for ARQ operation. First, there is a transmit and receive window defined as a constant given by the value AM_Window_Size, which can assume a value of 2048 if SN has a length of 12 bits or 131072 if SN has a length of 18 bits. The lower bound on the transmit window is a counter TX_Next_Ack that points to the last SN of the acknowledged SDUs. An upper window bound is given by TX_Next_Ack + AM-Window-Size. A current counter TX_Next indicates the next upcoming sequence number for transmission. At the receiving end, the RX window is limited at the lower bound by a counter RX_Next, which is a state variable that holds the value of the last RLC SDU that was completely received in-sequence. The upper bound is given by RX_Next + AM_Window-Size. Certain counters and state variables are used by the receiver to operate the ARQ feedback mechanism (see also TS 38.322 and Fig. 2-93 for further details). The principle of considering an SDU as not received properly is not based on a cyclic redundancy check (CRC), as is the case on the lower layers. Instead, it is based on a timer operation. The receiver uses a timer t-Reassembly to detect the loss of RLC PDUs on the lower layers. Its value is signaled via the RRC IE RLC-config and can range from 0 ms to 200 ms. The setting of this reassembly timer represents a trade-off between the aspects of latency and reliability, i.e. whether the receiver should wait longer for pending packets or signal the loss to higher layers as soon as possible. The counter variable RX_Next_Status_Trigger is a pointer to the SN that triggered the t-Reassembly timer.

The ARQ mechanism is based on feedback and optional retransmission, but how does this operation work in detail? One very simple mechanism could involve automatic ACK/NACK feedback for every delivered data packet, but this would lead to very high signaling overhead. Thus, 5G NR introduces the concept of TX and RX windows and the status report triggering mechanism. First, the possible number of retransmissions is configurable by the higher layer value maxRetxThreshold, ranging from 1 to a maximum of 32. The negative acknowledgement in a STATUS PDU can either be valid for an entire RLC SDU or for an RLC SDU segment. Like in UM mode, the retransmission can also be resegmented if the size given by the lower layer has changed between initial transmission and retransmission. The transmitting end can trigger a feedback Â­STATUS PDU by setting the polling bit in the RLC AMD header to 1. The prerequisites for setting the poll bit to 1 are explained in TS 38.322. Such situations are e.g. the transmission buffer becoming empty, representing the termination of a PDU connection. Other reasons for polling are the higher layer configuration parameters pollPDU and pollByte, representing the maximum amount of either bytes or PDUs that can be sent within a polling interval. In addition to the opportunity for polling bit transmission, there is also the opportunity for retransmitting the polling request based on a timer value t-PollRetransmit, given by higher layers. If an AMD SDU is received with a sequence number having either a value lower than RX_Highest_Status or higher than the upper bound of the RX window and the polling bit is activated, a STATUS PDU will be generated; otherwise it will be deferred. In addition to the state variable operations, there is a higher layer timer t-StatusProhibit that can prohibit transmission of STATUS PDU and thus restrict the amount of signaling overhead.

The STATUS PDU may contain several bit fields for acknowledging either a sequence number of an SDU, or negatively acknowledging a certain single SDU or multiple SDUs, or a negatively acknowledging a segment or segments within a SDU. Moreover, it may indicate a sequence of consecutive SDUs that should be reported as negatively received via NACK. The structure of the STATUS PDU header field is given in Fig. 2-94. Its values are:

  • Data or control discriminator (D/C): A 1-bit field that discriminates whether the prevailing PDU is an AMD PDU or a STATUS PDU for control purposes
  • Control PDU type (CPT) indicating the type of RLC control header. In the current release of the specification, there is only one type (STATUS PDU) that is defined. Thus, this field can be seen as a future extension
  • Acknowledgement SN (ACK_SN). All SDUs up to but not including this number are considered as acknowledged. Exceptions are those SDUs that are explicitly indicated as NACK with the same STATUS PDU
  • Extension bit 1 (E1) indicating whether or not a set of NACK_SN, E1, E2 and E3 follows
  • Negative acknowledgement SN (NACK_SN) indicating the SN of the RLC SDU that has been detected as lost or erroneous
  • Extension bit 2 (E2) to indicate whether an optional SOstart and SOend follows this field
  • Extension bit 3 (E3) is used in case of negative acknowledgement of a consecutive sequence of SDUs. This extension bit indicates the presence of a NACK range field following the current field
  • SO start (SOstart) and SO end (SOend) indicate the position of the RLC SDU portion that has been detected as lost. Together with the E3 bit, the SO sequence can span multiple SDUs to indicate non-acknowledgements
  • NACK range representing a number of consecutively lost RLC SDUs, starting from NACK_SN in that field

The RLC layer cooperates with the underlying MAC layer on the data quantity calculation, which is used especially for buffer status reporting situations. Such pending data includes e.g. pending RLC SDUs or SDU segments, RLC PDUs pending for initial transmission and for retransmission as well as previously triggered STATUS PDU reports.

Medium access control (MAC) protocol

The name medium access control neatly describes the purpose and use cases for this protocol layer. MAC can be considered as the gateway to the physical layer. It offers data transmission services to a higher layer by mapping logical channels to transport channels and by applying additional data transfer functions such as channel prioritization, multiplexing or inband measurement reporting. Moreover, it supports resource allocation. In addition, the MAC layer executes a number of MAC procedures such as random access, inband reporting of BSR or PH, DRX operation and UL/DL data transfer, to name a few examples. These procedures, services and functions are explained in this chapter. Further information on the MAC layer in general can be found in TS 38.321. As a primordial service of the MAC layer, one may consider the mapping of logical channels, describing what type of content is transferred to transport channels owning a transport profile or how the data is transferred. The mapping is explained in Fig. 1-10, page 23, indicating the transport channels that are handled by one MAC entity. A structural description of a MAC entity is given in Fig. 2-95 in the form of a brief overview of the functions and services provided by the MAC layer. If the UE has an active SCG, it will have two MAC entities: one for SCG and one for MCG.

The general functions of the MAC layer are direction-dependent and are given as:

  • Mapping between logical channels and transport channels
  • Multiplexing and demultiplexing of MAC SDUs to or from logical channels. Multiplexing takes place in the uplink direction and demultiplexing in the downlink direction
  • Inband reporting of scheduling information such as BSR or PH in the uplink direction
  • Bidirectional HARQ operation as error correction (see 2.2.5 Hybrid automatic repeat request (HARQ) operation, page 318 for details on the HARQ procedure)
  • Prioritization of logical channels in the uplink direction

The MAC layer in 5G NR not only offers functions and services to higher layers as shown above, but also provides a wide range of procedures to support the functions along with additional control and connection-related methods. The next section will give an overview of these MAC procedures. See TS 38.321 for a further description.

Random access procedure

The purpose of the random access procedure is to initiate a signaling radio bearer (SRB) connection using the transport channel RACH and physical channel PRACH. The random access procedure can either be initiated by higher layers known as PDCCH order in e.g. handover situations, or it can be triggered by the MAC entity itself in case that higher layers initiate a mobile originated data transfer. In addition, there are a few RRC events such as other system information requests that may also initiate the random access procedure. The responsibility of the MAC entity for the random access procedure is the configuration of a list of parameters such as selection of the correct PRACH from a signaled configuration index, the power control parameters for initial power control, or the parameters for downlink signal detection and measurements such as rsrp-ThresholdSSB identifying the âbestâ SSB for random access transmission. In coordination with higher layer signaling like the PRACH configuration obtained via SIB broadcast, the MAC entity selects the correct PRACH preamble and radio resource for the initial transmission. A detailed description of the random access procedure in 5G NR is given in 2.1.4 Random access procedure in 5G NR, page 250, and Physical random access channel (PRACH) â power control, page 130.

Uplink time alignment procedures

Radio waves propagate at the speed of light (approx. 3.3 Âµs per kilometer). Depending on the distance between the UE and gNB, this causes a propagation delay Tprop. Typically, a UE does not know the distance to the base station. Instead, it synchronizes to the received time reference provided by physical signals such as PSS, SSS or TRS. Thus, without any interaction, the uplink signal arriving at the base station receiver is delayed by 2 Ã Tprop. Knowing the numbers of the 5G numerologies and assuming a cell size of hundreds of meters or even kilometers, a non-compensated propagation delay could cause interferences to other users. The basic idea behind compensating for the propagation delay involves the definition of a time by which the UE advances its uplink transmission timing compared to the reference time that the UE acquires from reception of synchronization signals. This time is known as the timing advance value. The responsibility of the MAC entity is to maintain this timing advance at a valid level via inband signaling using MAC control elements. Since 5G NR supports either carrier aggregation or dual connectivity, there may be multiple uplink transmissions controlled in terms of the time alignment. This lead already in LTE to the definition of a timing advance group (TAG), containing timing advance (TA) values for primary or secondary cells. The general principle of the timing advance is depicted in Fig. 2-96, showing the time alignment between the uplink and downlink. There is first a higher layer signaling parameter n-TimingAdvanceOffset that is duplex scheme and frequency range dependent (FR1 or 2 / FDD or TDD) and given by higher layers as either 0, 25600 or 39936 units that will be multiplied by Tc. TS 38.133 specifies some rules on how to obtain the offset if it is not signaled via higher layers. Via a relative timing command TA, received within a MAC control PDU, the gNB can now control the proper arrival of all uplink signals to be aligned. The TA value is SCS dependent and based on the symbol time Tc as shown in Fig. 1-40, page 63. Using this value, the gNB can delay or advance the uplink transmission in relative steps with the granularity dependent on the SCS as well. The procedure described in Fig. 2-96 represents the case when a radio connection has been established. An exception exists for the initial access procedure, where there is just one RF signal, the PRACH preamble that is not timing advance controlled. Thus, its structure typically contains a guard time to prevent collisions with subsequent signals. See Physical random access channel (PRACH), page 89 for further details on PRACH preambles. The validity of the timing alignment is controlled via an RRC timer timeAlignmentTimer that can assume values from 500 ms to 10240 ms (or even infinity). In case this timer expires without a previous update, the UE has to halt its radio transmission in the uplink direction.

DL-SCH data transfer

One essential procedure for the MAC layer is clearly the transfer of data via the DL SCH transport channel within an overall activated PDU session. The responsibility of the MAC entity is to support such data transfer via features like DL assignment, HARQ operation and data PDU disassembly and demultiplexing. As described in 2.2.3 DL resource assignment, page 295, the network primarily uses three identifiers to indicate the proper receiver for a downlink data packet: C-RNTI for dynamic scheduled data, temporary C-RNTI for initial access scheduling of DL-SCH channels containing higher layer signaling, and CS-RNTI for semi-persistent scheduling of data. For the sake of completeness, there is also MCS-C-RNTI for scheduling modulation scheme restricted data to one UE. In addition to the identifier for the packet addressee RNTI, there is a second signaling parameter NDI that indicates whether the received data packet is received initially or whether it corresponds to a retransmission. The latter is especially important for soft combining of the data before the error correction procedure starts (see also [Ref. 18] for a description of soft combining and NDI). As a method for error correction that was previously introduced in HSPA and LTE, 5G NR also supports the concept of HARQ, a feedback loop including retransmission of data packets with varying coding schemes to allow incremental redundancy. Further details on HARQ operation in 5G NR are given in 2.2.5 Hybrid automatic repeat request (HARQ) operation, page 318. Note that 5G NR also supports a bundling operation for the TTI, indicated via pdsch-AggregationFactor as one of the values 1 (default), 2,4 or 8 within PDSCH-config. If TTI bundling is enabled, all bundled TTI packets belong to the same HARQ process. A final subprocedure that is very important within the DL-SCH data transfer procedure is the ability to assemble, disassemble and multiplex/demultiplex different data packets and logical channels. As described in the RLC description Radio link control protocol (RLC), page 356 and Fig. 2-80, the NR RLC entity (unlike the LTE RLC entity) does not support data concatenation. As a consequence, the MAC entity is responsible for transport format selection. Depending on the applicable TBS, the MAC layer will construct one MAC PDU by mapping different MAC SDUs onto it. One MAC SDU is given as a higher layer RLC PDU including optional padding and thus the scheduled data rate can be obtained. The general principle of downlink PDU format generation is depicted in the upper part of Fig. 2-97. Seen from left to right, the PDU generation process starts with a first header field containing the MAC control information length, logical channel ID (LCID) and a format field indicating the length of the length field. First, the MAC PDU contains a fixed sized control element (CE). A second variable sized control element is included followed by the MAC SDU for higher layer data transfer. The length field L in each subheader and the format indicator F allow derivation of the number of bits per SDU and thus the disassembly of the MAC PDU into its SDU in case they are assembled together. In general, there is a structure in which the first MAC control elements are included in the resulting PDU and then data PDUs will be added. The LCID field either indicates what type of logical channel corresponds to the concatenated SDU or what type of MAC control element it is. We should not interpret the LCID field as a description of the logical channel type as described in 1.1.3.1 Logical, transport and physical channels, page 22. Furthermore, it is a numerical identifier to allow multiplexing of various logical channels and thus fulfill certain prioritization aspects. Refer to TS 38.321 for a detailed list of LCID values referring to the logical channel or MAC CE. There is one important difference worth mentioning between the MAC PDU structure in 5G NR compared to LTE. While in LTE, the MAC PDU starts first with all the control elements and subheaders (see TS 36.321 or [Ref. 30] for further information), the 5G NR MAC PDU places a subheader at the beginning of each MAC SDU or subPDU as shown in the Fig. 2-97, page 372. This allows concatenation of RLC PDUs on the MAC layer since, as previously discussed, the RLC layer does not perform concatenation. In addition, the subheader in front of each subPDU allows parallel processing on the physical and MAC layers to improve the latency. Another difference resulting from this placement of the control subheader directly with the subPDU is the omission of the extension flag bit E that was needed in LTE to indicate the control subheader length.

UL-SCH data transfer

The procedures for uplink data transfer operate similar to the downlink Â­DL-SCH data transfer such as data multiplexing, HARQ process operation and radio resource assignment. The allocation of uplink resources can be handled in three ways: either dynamic scheduling of resources via DCI scheduling (2.2.7 UL grant reception or UL assignment, page 329), resource allocation in a random access response (RAR) message (2.1.4 Random access procedure in 5G NR, page 250), or configured as semi-persistent scheduling (2.2.11 Dynamic, semi-persistent and grant-free scheduling, page 382). Like on the downlink, on the uplink there may also be several HARQ processes running concurrently and the NDI bit is used to indicate whether the prevailing data packet is sent for the first time or has to be considered as a retransmission of a previous packet transmission. There is one marginal difference between the mapping of logical channels onto MAC PDUs on the uplink compared to the downlink. On the downlink, it is up to the network to select which MAC SDUs related to each logical channel should be included in the MAC PDU, but on the uplink, the RRC can have an influence through the definition of priority policies. The RRC IE LogicalChannelConfig controls the scheduling of uplink data by signaling three parameters for each logical channel per MAC entity:

Logical channel prioritization (LCP) parameters

  • Priority of logical channels with respect to one other (range: 1 to 16), where an increasing priority value indicates a lower priority level
  • prioritisedBitRate (PBR), which sets the prioritized bit rate for this particular logical channel in kbps throughput. Values range from 0 kbps to 65 536 kbps (or even infinity). This can be understood as the data rate that will be provided to one logical channel of higher priority before another logical channel of lower priority gets data resources
  • bucketSizeDuration (BSD), which sets the bucket size duration. Values range from 5 ms to 1000 ms. The BSD is basically used to set the maximum amount of pending data allowed for a logical channel with respect to the prioritization checks. It has to be understood as a maximum length of time the logical channel can use the provided data resources by sending PBR data. The more data a logical channel has, the higher its priority tends to be, but it cannot exceed the value given by prioritized bit rate Ã bucket size duration, e.g. 100 kbps Ã 1 second = 100 kbits. This keeps a logical channel experiencing a very large burst of data from taking over the transmission and blocking out a lower rate channel, thus risking its âstarvationâ. The UE permanently maintains an internal state variable for each logical channel that can be considered as a priority pointer to the logical channel that benefits from the provided transport resources in decreasing order of priority. Note that the logical channel priority decreases with this state variable in order to prevent a single logical channel from hogging all the resources

There are additional RRC configuration parameters controlling the LCP procedure such as the allowed SCS list, maximum PUSCH duration or allowed serving cells, which are description parameters for logical channel configuration, controlled via RRC. Besides prioritization of the logical channels used for data transfer with the above parameters, TS 38.321 specifies a relative priority order for the logical channels and MAC CE, e.g. UL-CCCH data has higher priority than UL-DTCH.

The uplink MAC PDU has a slightly different construction compared to the downlink MAC PDU as shown in Fig. 2-97. The major difference is that the uplink control information via MAC subPDU including control elements is placed after the MAC subPDU containing data SDUs. The reason for this can be seen in the content of the MAC CE like BSR or PH reporting that typically requires some reflection on the latest UE status before transmission. The placement of control elements after the data subPDUs allows parallel processing on the transmitting end and leaves more time for reflection on the status when generating the complete MAC PDU. At the gNB receiving end, the placement of a subheader directly in front of each subPDU and the placement of the MAC CE at the end also allows some parallelization of the data processing. Based on the length indicator fields, the gNB receiver can immediately identify the position of the MAC CE sub-PDU within the overall MAC PDU and thus the data processing of MAC subPDUs with data and subPDUs with control information can run in parallel [Ref. 31].

Buffer status reporting

The MAC layer on the uplink supports UL-SCH data transfer using inband control information sent via the MAC CE or separately using the physical control channel (PUCCH). This uplink control information can be a combination of: a request for additional UL data resources via the transmission of a scheduling request, a report on the still pending data quantity given as a buffer status report and information about the transmit power reserves (power headroom). The scheduling request (SR) allows the UE to request UL-SCH resources for data transmission (see 2.2.6 Uplink scheduling request and buffer status reporting, page 326 for a detailed description of the SR). The MAC entity in an end-user device determines the amount of UL data waiting to be sent on a logical channel (see TS 38.321 for calculation details). This pending data amount is reported to the network via MAC CE inband reporting of buffer status reports (BSR), which can be regular BSR reports, periodic BSR reports or padding BSR reports. They are configured by the RRC elements BSR-Config and Logical-ChannelConfig. The BSR configuration parameters include:

  • periodicBSR-Timer: A timer used for periodic BSR reporting interval definition
  • retxBSR-Timer sets a timer for retransmission of the BSR. It is restarted upon reception of a grant for uplink transmission and can be seen as a kind of persistency indicator on the uplink for UL-SCH data transfer
  • logicalChannelSR-DelayTimerApplied indicating whether a delay timer is applied for the transmission of SR
  • logicalChannelSR-DelayTimer indicates whether to apply the delay timer for SR transmission for this logical channel
  • logicalChannelSR-Mask is a Boolean parameter to control SR triggering in case of semi-persistent scheduling instead of BSR
  • logicalChannelGroup allowing the possibility of grouping logical channels for control info overhead reduction. The maximum number of LCGs is eight in the current release of the specification

The main trigger for BSR reporting includes cases such as data arriving on the MAC layer from a logical channel with higher priority than the current one, none of the logical channels containing any available data, expiry of the retransmission BSR timer, and expiry of the periodic BSR timer. There are two types of BSR CE reports: a short BSR and a long BSR. The long BSR allows reporting of pending data for all relevant logical channel groups, while the short BSR only reports one logical channel. There is the possibility to truncate the BSR if needed. The structure of the BSR CE format is shown in Fig. 2-98, indicating the LCG ID field for the short BSR or LCG indicator flag for the long BSR, along with a buffer size field containing an integer number referring to a table in TS 38.321 with the buffer size.

Power headroom reporting

In cooperation with the physical layer, the MAC entity in the UE sends power headroom reports to the gNB. These reports help the scheduler within the gNB to influence the power control mechanism, explained in Power allocation for the uplink, page 123, and consequently achieve a better SNR at its receiver for scheduling a better suited MCS. TS 38.321 specifies three different power headroom reporting (PHR) types:

Type 1 power headroom: The difference between the nominal UE maximum transmit power and the estimated power for UL-SCH transmission per activated serving cell. Type 1 PHR is valid for PUSCH transmission occasion

Type 2 power headroom: The difference between the nominal UE maximum transmit power and the estimated power for UL-SCH and PUCCH transmission on SpCell of the other MAC entity (i.e. E-UTRA MAC entity in EN-DC case only)

Type 3 power headroom: The difference between the nominal UE maximum transmit power and the estimated power for SRS transmission per activated serving cell. Type 3 PHR is valid for SRS transmission occasion

The power headroom reporting is controlled via RRC, e.g. with the IE Â­PHR-Config (TS 38.331):

  • phr-PeriodicTimer for the periodic transmission of PHR
  • phr-ProhibitTimer to specify time intervals between PHR reports to avoid an unnecessary amount of signaling information
  • phr-Tx-PowerFactorChange defines an optional trigger for the PHR report that is activated if the downlink path loss of a cell that operates as the path loss reference has changed more than this factor
  • phr-Type2OtherCell is a Boolean variable that is used in situations with dual connectivity, especially when two uplink resources are assigned. If set to true, the UE must report a PHR type 2 for the SpCell of the other MAC entity or for the PUCCH SCells of this MAC entity
  • phr-ModeOtherCG is a Boolean variable used in dual connectivity situations to control the reports to be real or virtual. The specification TS 38.331 describes this variable as: âIndicates the mode (i.e. real or virtual) used for the PHR of the activated cells that are part of the other cell group (i.e. MCG or SCG), when DC is configured. If the UE is configured with only one cell group (no DC), it ignores the fieldâ
  • multiplePHR indicates if power headroom should be reported using the single entry PHR MAC control element or multiple entry PHR MAC control element. This is relevant if dual connectivity is activated

Power headroom report transmission is triggered by several situations specified in TS 38.321. For example, PHR may be triggered by a path loss change of the path loss reference cell by more than phr-Tx-PowerFactorChange, periodic PHR reports triggered by expiration of phr-PeriodicTimer, activation of the SCell in dual connectivity scenarios, or the addition of the PSCell. The PHR CE in the MAC layer is preceded by a subheader containing the LCID to indicate the control element type. Calculation of the power headroom is based on the equation for uplink power control (see Fig. 1-96, page 124) plus the current nominal maximum power Pcmax. As the value of Pcmax may be restricted by the cell, it is obvious that the PHR report will also include the underlying Pcmax for the PHR calculation. Fig. 2-99 describes the two possible formats: single PHR entry for single cell operation or multiple entry PHR for dual connectivity or carrier aggregation scenarios.

PCH and BCH reception

Like in legacy mobile communications technologies, the 5G system uses the concept of paging channels to initiate a mobile terminated data session. The MAC layer supports this paging operation by decoding the information received on the transport channel PCH and mapping it onto the logical channel PCCH for higher layer evaluation.

Assignments for PCH on the physical layer are indicated via DCI scheduling using the P-RNTI identifier. In addition, the MAC layer supports reception of the master information block received via the BCH transport channel. Note that the BCH transport channel is mapped onto the physical channel PBCH which is part of the SSB block. Details on BCH reception using SSB are described in 2.1.2.1 Other fundamental properties of synchronization signal blocks (SSBs), page 237.

Discontinuous reception (DRX)

Discontinuous reception is a well known method of power saving during periods of low activity. While in the RRC_CONNECTED state, the UE permanently monitors the PDCCH for scheduled reception of information such as data packets or control information. The MAC layer can be configured via RRC for a DRX period where the UE does not need to monitor the PDCCH and thus enters a kind of sleep mode to save energy. The general principle of DRX mode is depicted in Fig. 2-100 and configuration details are described in TS 38.321. For the sake of simplicity, certain details of the DRX concept are omitted here. Like in LTE, there are two DRX cycle lengths in 5G NR: a short DRX cycle and a long DRX cycle. The idea here is that the short DRX cycle is started in combination with the last packet arriving for an ongoing connection since it is likely for the connection to be resumed or for âdelayedâ packets to arrive. For example, in a typical web browsing scenario, after downloading a file containing a webpage, it is likely that the human user will interact by clicking on another link and thus trigger another data transfer. Such behavior is targeted by the short DRX cycle length. The long DRX cycle starts after a longer period of inactivity or when activated via the MAC CE. DRX is configured by a higher layer and is either activated via a timer that expires or via MAC control elements that use the LCID field to send this control info.

The higher layer information element DRX-config contains the following parameters that configure the DRX operating mode including timers and cycle length.

DRX configuration parameters by RRC:

  • drx-onDurationTimer is the duration (1 ms to 1600 ms) during which the UE monitors the PDCCH at the beginning of a DRX cycle
  • drx-SlotOffset, the delay in slots (0 to 31) before starting the drx-onDurationTimer, is needed in 5G due to the introduction of flexible scheduling in the time domain and the concept of mini-slot allocation. This is unlike LTE where the TTI scheduling is always 1 ms
  • drx-InactivityTimer is the duration (0 ms to 2560 ms) for actively monitoring the PDCCH by the UE after PDCCH scheduling of a new UL or DL transmission
  • drx-RetransmissionTimerDL (per DL HARQ process) defines the maximum duration until a DL retransmission is received and thus forces the UE to monitor PDCCH scheduling messages for the retransmission indication
  • drx-RetransmissionTimerUL (per UL HARQ process) defines the maximum duration until a grant for UL retransmission is received and thus forces the UE to monitor PDCCH scheduling
  • drx-LongCycleStartOffset is a parameter that configures both, the duration of the the long DRX cycle and the offset of the DRX cycle start. If a short DRX cycle is configured, the duration of the long DRX cycle should be a multiple of the drx-ShortCycle value. The parameter drx-StartOffset defines the subframe where the long and short DRX cycle starts
  • drx-ShortCycle defines the duration (2 ms to 640 ms) of the short DRX cycle, consisting of an ON period and an OFF period. Note that the configuration of a short DRX cycle is optional
  • drx-ShortCycleTimer sets the duration the UE must follow the short DRX cycle, i.e. it defines the boundary between the short and long DRX cycle length. The drx-ShortCycleTimer is given as a unit of 1 to 16, where one unit corresponds to the duration of the drx-ShortCycle
  • drx-HARQ-RTT-TimerDL (per DL HARQ process) defines the minimum duration before a DL assignment for HARQ retransmission is expected by the MAC entity
  • drx-HARQ-RTT-TimerUL (per UL HARQ process) defines the minimum duration before a UL HARQ retransmission grant is expected by the MAC entity. The drx-HARQ-RTT-Timer for uplink and downlink can have a duration of 0 to 56 symbols of the BWP where the transport block was received

Further details on the conditions indicating how DRX is activated and the value ranges for the above DRX parameters are given in TS 38.321 and TS 38.331. To symbolically explain the concept of the DRX cycles and times, Fig. 2-101 provides a general overview of the DRX configuration. Note that this is a symbolic figure without a detailed description of scheduling timing, which would otherwise make the figure overly complex.

Transmission and reception without dynamic scheduling

This procedure in the MAC entity refers to the possibility for semi-persistent and grant-free scheduling in 5G NR. This is also called type 1 or type 2 allocation. Chapter 2.2.11 Dynamic, semi-persistent and grant-free scheduling, page 382 provides more details.

Activation/deactivation of SCells and SUL operation

As introduced in 1.1.3.4 Radio bearers in dual connectivity, page 31, 5G NR supports carrier aggregation. As a consequence, this would require that a secondary cell (SCell) is either activated and requires its own MAC entity or is deactivated. This procedure configures the MAC entity for purposes on the SCell such as PDCCH monitoring, SRS transmission, CSI reporting and PUCCH. The concept of carrier aggregation follows the 3GPP Release 10 introduction of carrier aggregation with LTE-Advanced that consists of two major steps involving secondary carrier activations. The first step is the RRC Reconfiguration message that configures general information on the additional component carriers. After this reconfiguration is complete, the MAC entity is used to activate or deactivate them quickly. The MAC CE that activates or deactivates them is given as a bitmap of either one or four octets since a maximum of 16 component carriers can be activated in 5G NR. The secondary uplink that was introduced in 1.2 Physical access fundamentals, page 46 is not identical to carrier aggregation, but it works in a similar manner. It allows the definition of two uplink carriers which are not used simultaneously (as would be the case in carrier aggregation scenarios). The SUL carrier is configured as a complement and operates based on a either/or decision. Scheduled via DCI, the MAC entity transmits the uplink data on either the normal UL carrier or the supplementary UL carrier.

Activation/deactivation of PDCP duplication

As introduced in the section detailing the PDCP layer (Packet data convergence protocol (PDCP), page 352), 5G NR offers the possibility to duplicate PDCP packets, thereby increasing the overall reliability by introducing redundant data transfer. It may be implemented by either RRC signaling or via the MAC CE. This MAC CE is to be seen as a 1-octet bitmap where each bit represents an index to one specific DRB identity among those DRBs that have been configured with duplication. If this particular bit is set to one, the corresponding DRB duplicates all packets. PDCP duplicate deactivation operates in reverse, i.e. the corresponding bit will be set to zero.

MAC reconfiguration

A higher layer may request reconfiguration of the MAC layer, e.g. in dual connectivity when the MCG changes, which involves restarting timers, applying new counter values and immediate application of higher layer parameters.

MAC reset

TS 38.331 contains details on triggering a MAC reset, which could be related to a RRC connection setup failure, a handover from another RAN, or a SCell removal, to name a few possibilities. A MAC reset would stop several timers in the MAC entity and lead to resetting counters and flushing data buffers. See TS 38.321 for further details.

BWP operation

The bandwidth part operation for the MAC entity is directly linked to the physical layer BWP operations described in 1.4 Bandwidth part fundamentals, page 182. The MAC entity is configured together with its lower physical layer for a certain BWP in the uplink and downlink direction. This procedure describes operations of the MAC entity such as possible BWPs for PRACH transmission, PDCCH monitoring, CSI reporting, SRS transmission, DL-SCH reception and UL-SCH transmission, to name a few examples.

Beam failure detection and recovery procedure

For details on this MAC procedure in conjunction with beamforming and mobility, see 2.3.1.3 Beam failure detection and recovery, page 392.

MAC control elements

In addition to the above described data transfer and procedures, the MAC layer provides many control mechanisms by defining several MAC control elements that are sent inband. Many of these control elements activate or deactivate procedures that are performed in conjunction with the physical layer. For the sake of simplicity, only a brief introduction is presented here (see TS 38.321 for further details).

  • Activation/deactivation of semi-persistent CSI-RS/CSI-IM resource set: The network may activate and deactivate the configured semi-persistent CSI-RS/CSI-IM resource sets of a serving cell by sending the SP CSI-RS / CSI-IM resource set activation/deactivation MAC CE. These CSI-RS and CSI-IM resources are used for channel status reporting and interference measurements that are fed back via UCI reporting as described in 2.2.9 Uplink control information (UCI), page 340
  • Aperiodic CSI trigger state subselection should serve as an example of how the MAC layer cooperates with the physical layer in relation to measurement reporting. It is possible to configure the UE with a list of CSI aperiodic trigger states, each of them containing a radio resource description where the UE has to perform measurements and conditions when the UE should report aperiodically. The network may select among the configured aperiodic CSI trigger states of a serving cell by sending the aperiodic CSI trigger state subselection MAC CE
  • Activation/deactivation of semi-persistent CSI reporting on PUCCH: As described in 2.2.9 Uplink control information (UCI), page 340, UE reports can be periodic, aperiodic or semi-persistent configured by RRC. Via the MAC layer, the network may activate and deactivate the configured semi-persistent CSI reporting on the PUCCH of a serving cell by sending the SP CSI reporting on the PUCCH activation/deactivation MAC
