  • Activation/deactivation of semi-persistent SRS: As described in 1.2.5.6 Physical signals in 5G NR, page 110, the UE is allowed to send sounding reference signals enabling the gNB to perform channel estimation. These SRS transmissions may be semi-persistent and the details are configured via the RRC layer. The MAC layer may activate and deactivate the configured semi-persistent SRS resource sets of a serving cell by sending the SP SRS activation/deactivation MAC CE
  • Recommended bit rate is to be understood as control information associated with the data flow, indicating to the receiving entity the data rate that the gNB recommends in the downlink direction and how the UE MAC entity is recommended to transmit in the uplink direction. Clearly, there are conditions that apply, such as a possible definition of a timer bitRateQueryProhibitTimer that prohibits the data rate for a certain logical channel, and the scheduled resources must be adequate for the recommended data rate

2.2.11 Dynamic, semi-persistent and grant-free scheduling

There are several types of data transmission depending on what kind of services are requesting it. If the UE or network need sporadic data transmission, than we talk about dynamic scheduling. The assumption here is that the transmission buffer contains pending data. This triggers dynamic allocation of radio resources via DCI based scheduling in the UL and/or DL direction. In the UL direction, the UE can request the assignment of UL resources with the transmission of a scheduling request (SR) or by provisioning a buffer status report (BSR). In response to this request, the gNB sends one or more UL grant assignments to allocate a radio resource for the requested capacity. In the same way, the gNB might dynamically assign a DL resource to receive DL data on the PDSCH. These procedures for dynamic scheduling (like those known from EUTRAN) were described previously in 2.2.3 DL resource assignment, page 295 and 2.2.7 UL grant reception or UL assignment, page 329.

In case the UE requires constant data for periodic transmission, e.g. for video or voice services, then the procedure refers to semi-persistent scheduling (SPS). In 5G NR, it was decided that SPS may have two forms (SPS type 1 and SPS type 2) and can be configured using the IE SPS-Config.

SPS type 1 corresponds to âgrant-free schedulingâ. This means that configuration is handled in a semi-static manner via RRC and is automatically activated. The UE may proceed to send on the uplink without waiting for an explicit activation.

SPS type 2 corresponds to an SPS like in LTE. This means the configuration must be explicitly activated via the DCI.

Grant-free scheduling using SPS type 1 is configured per UE and BWP and can be configured in a semi-static manner via RRC configuration. The advantage of this configured SPS scheduling is that no extra radio resource activation procedures are required and the UE can transmit data as soon as it is pending in the transmission buffer.

In this manner, it reduces the additional message flow that would have been required otherwise for dynamic scheduling. This applies on the UL. The typical use case involves sporadic data that must be transmitted with low latency such as in the case of URLLC. The scheduled resources remain available for the UE for the whole connection time or until the higher layer triggers a reconfiguration.

In contrast, SPS type 2 is configured by the network through RRCReconfiguration when the type of service requires periodic transmission of medium-sized packets. To avoid the control signaling associated with dynamic scheduling but still not block any resources, the network makes a dynamic decision using the PDCCH DCI message containing CS-RNTI (see also Radio network temporary identifier (RNTI), page 298) to enable UL semi-persistent scheduling type 2, which then needs to be deactivated via additional messages. Moreover, to avoid wasting resources when the data transfer has been completed, the gNB can explicitly deactivate SPS.

During SPS, the link configuration remains fixed for each allocation: RB assignments, modulation and coding scheme, etc. As a result, if the radio link conditions change, a new allocation must be sent. In addition, any incremental redundancy (HARQ subsequent transmissions) is scheduled separately using dynamic scheduling.

2.2.12 Data security

The overall security architecture is discussed in 1.1.7 Security architecture, page 44 and the initialization of security parameters is illustrated in Fig. 2-8. Security mechanisms are based on authentication, encryption and integrity protection. As one major difference compared to LTE, integrity protection can also be applied to user plane data. The protocol layer involved in certain security mechanisms such as ciphering and integrity protection is the PDCP layer, which is described in the section Packet data convergence protocol (PDCP), page 352.

After initial security configuration, the transmission between the UE and gNB can be encrypted and integrity protected both on signaling data (SRB) and on user data (DRB) based on configuration of a single logical channel. Ciphering and integrity protections are optionally configured except for RRC signaling or the C-plane, for which integrity protection is always configured. For user data, it is possible to enable integrity or/and encryption per DRB. The network can enforce integrity protection on a specific DRB and therefore all PDUs belonging to this DRB must have integrity enabled. Further information is provided in the context of user plane security enforcement in the 3GPP specification TS 23.502.

The integrity protection and ciphering algorithm is common for signaling radio bearers SRB1 and SRB2. When not configured with any kind of DC, the ciphering and integrity protection algorithm is common for all radio bearers (i.e. SRB1, SRB2 and DRBs). All DRBs related to the same PDU session have the same security configuration. Neither integrity protection nor ciphering applies for SRB0, as this signaling bearer is the initial one established before a security context between the UE and network is realized. An additional security level is achieved on a per packet basis. In fact, generation of a key for integrity and ciphering depends not only on a shared key derived from a symmetric secret key based algorithm, but also on the bearer ID, direction and a counter value COUNT. The general principle of security key derivation and dependencies is shown in Fig. 2-103. Regarding the protocol layers that are responsible for security aspects, the main protocol layer that is involved is the PDCP layer. Note that the PDCP layer is part of the 5G system protocol stack, so there is no end to end data encryption supplied by 5G NR. The PDCP parameter COUNT is initialized by the RRC security mode command. It is not allowed to use the same COUNT value more than one time for a given radio bearer. Therefore, COUNT is calculated depending on the PDCP packet sequence number and the current hyper frame number (HFN) representing a longer timer running to provide a higher level of security. This means that especially when data transmission is running over a long time and the SN needs to wrap around, the HFN is increased to make sure the COUNT will not be repeated. Summarizing the security aspects, we can describe 5G NR as a communications system that supports security aspects such as ciphering, authentication and integrity protection between the two entities UE and 5GC. Note that any security mechanisms on protocol layers higher than the PDCP layer or in networks external to the 5G system are optional and are outside the scope of the 5G system description.

2.3 Overall Mobility

The overall design of the 5G system (5GS) contains several interconnected modules that aim to allow the UE to move seamlessly from one coverage area to another (Fig. 2-104).

Starting from the bottom part, we see that the concept of a transmission and reception point (TRP) was introduced for deployment reasons. To ensure that even at higher frequencies and with narrow directional beam transmission a cell will cover a larger cell area, a single TRP may transmit several beams and more TRPs can also be introduced.TRP is a TX/RX unit that can have a large number of TX/RX antenna elements to generate directional beams. An example scenario is an apartment with multiple rooms where each room has a transmitter. When the UE moves within a cell, it transits between beams on the same TRP and between beams on different TRPs to keep the connection. For the purpose of UE mobility, the UE sees a transition between directional beams, and therefore the TRP architecture is transparent in most cases to the UE (see further discussion in 2.3.2 RRM mobility procedure, page 395).

In a wider area, multiple base stations are deployed and each may cover one or more cells. A cell is identified with a cell ID and a procedure for inter-cell mobility is required. Depending on whether the gNBs operate the cell on the same or different carrier frequencies, we speak of intra-frequency or inter-frequency cell mobility.

Furthermore, a large area might be covered partly by new technology such as NR. Therefore, continuity is required in the handover procedure from NR to the legacy technology. In 3GPP Release 15, EUTRA is the only RAT which guarantees service continuity from 5G NR, both in the case where EUTRA is connected to 5GC (intra-system mobility) and where EUTRA is connected to EPC system (inter-system mobility). Mobility between these two RATs and between two gNBs is controlled by the higher protocol layers. Control of the mobility procedure is handled within the RRC protocol layer or the 5GC (AMF) (see 2.3.2 RRM mobility procedure, page 395).

2.3.1 Beam mobility procedure

Beamforming is based on narrow directional transmission and reception. The steps for a UE and NodeB to establish a suitable beam pair link are shown in Fig. 2-105.

The base station broadcasts common cell information such as synchronization signals (SS) and system information throughout the cell at regular time intervals and over multiple beams (known as network beam sweeping). See 1.3.2 Support for beamforming in 5G NR, page 173 for more details. The same information is repeated over time and spatially multiplexed to make sure that every UE within the cell area can receive the signal.

When a UE wants to access the system, it begins by measuring several beam-based received synchronization signal blocks (SSB) identified by an SS-Index and selecting a specific beam based on the strongest received beam power (see 2.1.2 5G NR signal quality measurements and reporting, page 237 for details).

For initial uplink access (random access), the UE uses the selected beam (SSB index) for the first uplink message (Msg1, preamble) to the base station. The opportunities in time and frequency for transmission of the first uplink message (PRACH resource) depend on the selected SS block index (Fig. 1-147, page 177), which is specified in the system information by the gNB.

The UE may also repeat the same transmission over time over different beams to reach the base station with better reliability (UE beam sweeping). The UE informs the network about the best beam implicitly by selecting a specific PRACH resource. Upon reception of the first uplink signal, the network adjusts the transmission to the specific selected beam for successive downlink messages (Msg2/4). In the same way, the UE responds in uplink using the same selected beam (Msg3).

One typical scenario for the use of beam sweeping is fixed wireless access (FWA). During the setup phase, base stations and customer premises equipment (CPE) installed at home are set up. Once the connection between nodes is established, very efficient spatial transmission can be achieved with beam forming.

Once random access is completed and a connection is established, communications between the UE and network is based on a dedicated directional beam for successive data and control messages.

In case of mobility, both the UE and gNBs need to adjust the direction of the beams on the uplink and downlink, respectively. These procedures are defined as beam switching (see 1.3.2 Support for beamforming in 5G NR, page 173 for more details). Beam switching only applies in connected mode and does not require explicit RRC signaling to be triggered. The physical layer is in charge of performing the measurements (based on specific reference signals) and the MAC layer collects the results. A higher layer like RRC is not required to know which beam is being used at a given point in time. Therefore, this procedure is also known as âmobility without RRC involvementâ.

In case of mobility, the UE may detect a failure in the connection. Failure detection is a continuous process. The physical layer measures the status of the current link, monitors the neighbor beams and reports the result to the upper layer. If the upper layer detects a link failure, the UE is required to initiate recovery of the link by selecting a new strongest beam and initiating random access (see 2.3.1.3 Beam failure detection and recovery, page 392 for details).

Typical cm-/mm-wave deployment scenarios that apply beamforming include high-capacity, small cell deployments or industrial applications (Industry 4.0). In such cases, the UE may encounter fast fading and blockage due to obstacles, thereby necessitating a beam failure and beam recovery procedure.

The process of beam mobility requires continuous measurement of reference signals transmitted both by the gNB and UE. Fig. 2-106 provides an overview of the reference signals used for each direction.

 Idle UE (i.e. initial access)Connected UE (beam mobility and failure detection)
DownlinkSSB (PSS, SSS)SSB (PSS, SSS) and CSI-RS
UplinkNoneSRS

Fig. 2-106 Reference signals involved in the beam mobility procedure.

2.3.1.1 Beam mobility on the downlink

Deployment at cm-/mm-wave frequencies requires beamforming antennas to compensate for the high path loss. When the UE moves within the cell area, the fast channel variation requires switching between beams. In case of beam correspondence, and especially in the case of TDD where identical channel conditions are expected on the DL and UL, the UE performs beam switching based on a DL measurement in order to select a beam pair. Beam mobility on the downlink requires less energy consumption at the UE end, but it can lead to worse beam management performance compared to a combined scenario with UL beam switching.

Beam mobility on the downlink is a connected mode procedure based on reference signals transmitted by the gNB. The network configures the measurement dedicated to each specific UE (see 2.3.3 Mobility measurement, page 401) via RRC reconfiguration including csi-MeasConfig. The UE physical layer is requested to perform measurements on the DL reference signals (CSI-RS/SS). The UE provides a measurement report (see 2.2.9 Uplink control information (UCI), page 340) for channel state information reference signals (CSI-RS), for synchronization signals (SS), or for both. Note that CSI-RS may have a higher time/frequency periodicity compared to that of SS blocks and therefore more precise measurements can be performed.

The measurements are performed in a slot interval and a corresponding value of RSRP is calculated, which has a span from â140 dBm to â44 dBm with a 1 dB step size.

Each measured signal is identified as a unique index (CSI-RS resources indicator CRI or SS-Index). Several resource sets for CSI-RS or SSB can be configured and depending on csi-MeasConfig, several resource report configurations are possible for the serving beam and neighbor beams. UE reports are aperiodic, periodic or semi-persistent.

The network is informed of the current measurement results and can automatically adjust downlink transmission of the control and data channels (PDCCH and PDSCH) based on the best beam measured by the UE.

Note that SSB-based beam management can only be configured for the BWP which overlaps with the CellDefining-SSB (see 2.4.1.1 Cell-defining SSB, page 409). For a BWP that does not overlap with the CD-SSB as specified in TS 38.300, beams can only be configured based on CSI-RS.

2.3.1.2 Beam mobility on the UL

Usually, beam transmission on the UL and DL assumes beam correspondence, i.e. selection and measurement of a beam on the downlink also suffice to define the UL transmission direction.

If beam correspondence is not supported by the UE, beam management procedures should also be performed on the UL with link adaptation. In this case, the network must measure specific reference signals (SRS) sent from the UE to evaluate the UL. The network may also request beam switching on the UL for load balancing and to force reconfiguration of the UE's UL beam.

The procedure requires configuration of SRS transmission by the network which can involve several neighbor beams within the UE specific maximum number of supported SRS. Each SRS is identified by an SRS reference index (SRI). Afterwards, the UE performs SRS transmission with UE beam sweeping. This allows the gNB to perform several measurements in different UE UL directions. The base station must notify the UE of the specific beam to be used on the UL via the physical layer control channel (e.g. PDCCH with DCI 0_1 with SRI).

The UE may soon begin transmission on the UL (PUCCH and PUSCH) on the specific beam, which in the normal case is considered to be basically co-located with the SRS signal (see 1.2.5 General description of the physical layer, page 73).

For beam management, SRS measurement reporting requires a short periodicity or event-triggered transmission (i.e. a threshold between two neighbor beams) due to the fact that in case of mobility, the condition of the channel may fluctuate rapidly.

2.3.1.3 Beam failure detection and recovery

Beam failure detection can be performed either through measurement of CSI-RS or SS or both. Beam failure detection is a similar procedure to radio link failure. In other words, it requires physical layer measurement of the status of the link and reporting of these values to higher layers for evaluation. Beam failure detection in case of cm- and mm-wave deployments will occur more often since UE mobility and obstacles can cause fast degradation of the RF signal.

The procedure begins with configuration of a detection resource, i.e. a sequence of different resources that can be used for beam failure detection. The measured resources are identified by an index as shown in Fig. 2-109. Multiple resources can be configured. The network must configure the measurement dedicated to the specific UE in the active downlink bandwidth part. In case the active BWP of the UE does not contain the SSB (CellDefining-SSB), the network should not configure measurements on the synchronization signal.

ParameterValueExplanation
DetectionResourceSequence of SSB-IndexIndex of SSB block to measure
 Sequence of CSI-RS-IndexIndex of CSI-RS to measure
BeamFailureInstanceMaxCount This field determines after how many beam failure events the UE triggers beam failure recovery
BeamFailureDetectionTimer Timer for beam failure detection as multiple of reference signal period

Fig. 2-109 Parameters for beam failure detection.

For the detection configuration, the network also configures a timer (beamFailureDetectionTimer) as a period in which the MAC layer will count the number of reported âbeam failure instancesâ delivered from the physical layer. If the number of instances delivered is higher than the value of max count (BeamFailureInstanceMaxCount) during the timer, the MAC layer declares âbeam failure detectionâ and starts a âbeam failure recovery procedureâ. The physical layer reports a beam failure detection event on the configured detection resource set if the value of L1-RSRP is lower than a threshold Q (see TS 38.215 and TS 38.213 for details). The periodicity of the report is the maximum between 2 ms and the shortest detection resource periodicity.

If beam failure recovery is triggered, the UE needs to establish a connection using random access. Random access due to beam failure recovery uses specific resources on the UL. There is a dedicated configuration for each UE, for the PCell and SCell, and for the normal and supplementary uplink. The reason is that the UE wants to recover from beam failure as soon as possible and therefore the UE first uses contention-free random access with the beam failure recovery PRACH resources. The UE is configured with a candidate beam Fig. 2-111 resource list (CandidateBeamRSList) for failure recovery, which is basically a subset of beams to measure and perform PRACH selection. Here again, the network restricts the number of measurements that the UE needs to perform for selection of the uplink beam for the first random access in order to speed up the recovery time. Moreover, a threshold is configured that the UE uses to select the best candidate beam from the network-configured list.

Beam failure recovery also has a timer (beamFailureRecoveryTimer) that is initialized upon the first beam failure detection event and reset only when beam failure recovery is terminated with a successfully acknowledged random access. The timer represents the maximum period that the UE will attempt to recover from beam failure (using a specific beam failure recovery random access resource). After the timer expires, the UE must repeat the measurement and establish a connection using contention-based random access.

If the UE starts beam failure recovery, then it must move to the UL BWP where PRACH resources are available. Consequently, it also moves to the DL BWP to receive the control information in the DL (Msg2). The CORESET and search space for downlink information are set in the parameter recoverySearchSpaceId.

Random access for beam failure recovery is one of the two prioritized reasons for random access. For this case and the handover case, a specific power ramping and a backoff indicator sequence are dedicated to this procedure.

Parameter nameParameter valueDescription
CandidateBeamRSListSSB-IndexIndex of SSB block to measure
 CSI-RS-IndexIndex of CSI-RS to measure
rsrp-ThresholdSSBIntegerL1-RSRP threshold used for determining whether a candidate beam may be used by the UE to attempt contention-free random access to recover from beam failure
recoverySearchSpaceIdSearch space IDSearch space to use for BFR RAR.
beamFailureRecoveryTimer Timer for beam failure recovery. Upon expiration of the timer the UE does not use CFRA for BFR. Value in ms.
ra-PrioritizationpowerRampingStepHighPriorityPower ramping step applied for prioritized random access procedure.
 scalingFactorBIScaling factor for the backoff indicator (BI) for the prioritized random access procedure.

Fig. 2-111 Parameters for beam failure recovery.

One of the IMT Vision for 2020 ITU requirements is 0 ms interruption time during the handover procedure. The interruption time is defined as the shortest time duration supported by the system during which a UE cannot exchange user plane packets with any base station during mobility transitions. The mobility interruption time includes the time required to execute any radio access network procedure, radio resource control signaling protocol or other message exchanges between the user equipment and the radio access network.

In case of beam mobility when moving within the same cell, the transmit-receive beam pair of the UE may need to be changed. The procedure includes the gNB configuring different beams for this UE at different slots to be measured. It ensures that the UE is able to measure the neighbor beam before switching actually occurs and to quickly transmit the beam allocation for the DL transmission. Therefore, DL data packet transmission is maintained during beam pair switching.

For UL data transmission, the PUSCH is sent using the beam configured with the SRS resource indicator (SRI) by the gNB. Before the actual transition occurs, the gNB configures several SRS UL transmissions to be transmitted by the UE. This allows the gNB to continuously perform measurements and to choose an appropriate gNB-side beam for UL data reception. Therefore, UL data packet transmission is maintained during beam pair switching in different slots.

Based on the above analysis, UE can always exchange user plane packets with the gNB during beam mobility transitions. Therefore, 0 ms mobility interruption time is achieved by NR for this scenario as discussed in TR 37.910. A further study is being carried out by 3GPP for reliability issues in high frequency range.

2.3.2 RRM mobility procedure

The purpose of radio resource management (RRM) is to support UE mobility over network cells and at the same time to guarantee load balancing for multiple UEs accessing the network. Mobility can occur in RRC_IDLE state or RRC_INACTIVE with cell reselection and in RRC_CONNECTED state with intra-RAT and inter-RAT handover.

Cell reselection is a UE-triggered procedure that does not involve the network. In this case, the UE uses the reselection configuration received via the system information (SIB2). The reselection configuration consists of a list of neighbor cells along with measurement parameters for both the serving cell and neighbor cells.

The UE measures the RSRP/RSRQ for each frequency configured and ranks the different frequencies based on these values. For the case of frequencies within same band (intra-frequency), the values are ranked based on the measurement results while for inter-band frequencies, the ranking is also based on the frequency priority.

After the reselection criteria are fulfilled, the UE camps on the new selected cell. In case of idle mode, this does not involve any change of the last serving gNB, while in case of inactive mode, the target gNB triggers an Xn interface message (Fig. 1-6, page 17) to retrieve the last saved UE context and possibly also to activate data forwarding as specified in TS 38.304. The main steps in cell reselection are depicted in Fig. 2-112.

In connected mode, the UE will be redirected to another cell by the gNB. We thus define this procedure as network-based mobility. The RRC protocol layer is responsible for controlling the mobility within NR and in the case of inter-RAT, between NR and LTE.

Moreover, we distinguish whether mobility is performed inter-gNB without involvement of 5GC (Xn mobility) or inter-gNB with involvement of 5GC (NG mobility). In the first case, the serving and target gNB exchange information only through the Xn Interface, while in the latter case the AMF in 5GC is also involved in the mobility signaling (see Fig. 2-104). For details on intra-RAT mobility, see 2.3.2.1 Intra-RAT mobility, page 396 and 2.3.2.2 Mobility parameters, page 399.

The handover mechanism is also used in dual connectivity to reconfigure the PDCP when the EUTRA needs to change the PDCP from LTE PDCP to NR PDCP and vice versa. Reestablishment of the PDCP connection can be achieved with or without a security key change. For further details on security during mobility, see 2.3.4 Mobility security, page 405.

2.3.2.1 Intra-RAT mobility

Connected mode mobility consists of three phases:

  • Thepreparation phase where the UE is required to perform and report measurements on serving and neighbor cells based on the measurement configuration provided by the gNB. The source and target gNB exchange a handover message for the purpose of providing the UE capability and UE configuration information to the target gNB
  • Theexecution phase where the source gNB triggers the handover to the UE using the RRCReconfiguration message and the UE detaches from the source gNB and attaches to the target gNB
  • The completion phase where the UE confirms the handover procedure and data forwarding is applied

The different phases are illustrated in Fig. 2-113. Each phase consists of several messages as described below.

  1. Using the UE RRCReconfiguration message, the source gNB provides the UE measurement parameters and measurement report configuration to be performed (see 2.3.3 Mobility measurement, page 401 for details)
  2. The UE performs the measurement on the configured frequencies
  3. The UE reports according to the measurement configuration
  4. The source gNB decides to hand over the UE based on the measurement report and RRM information (i.e. cell load balancing)
  5. The source gNB initiates handover and sends HandoverPreparationInformation over the Xn interface. The purpose is to provide needed information about the current UE configuration to the target gNB to issue the handover (see 2.3.2.2 Mobility parameters, page 399 for details)
  6. The target gNB first verifies whether it can accept the connection of the UE. This depends on parameters such as the QoS required by each PDU which influences the allocation of resources on the target cell. Moreover, slice-aware admission control must be performed if slice information is sent to the target gNB. If the PDU sessions are associated with non-supported slices in the target gNB, it must reject such PDU sessions
  7. The target gNB provides an RRC container for the UE RRCReconfiguration as part of the handover acknowledgement
  8. The source gNB forwards to the UE the RRCReconfiguration message including the handover command. The RRCReconfiguration (ReconfigurationWithSync) message includes information required to access the target cell such as the SSB frequency, random access configuration and system information. It may also include a new RNTI which is used to uniquely identify the UE during random access on the new cell (see 2.3.2.2 Mobility parameters, page 399 for details). After reception of the RRC reconfiguration for handover, the UE will detach from the source cell
  9. The SN STATUS TRANSFER message will be sent from the source gNB to inform the target gNB about each radio bearer currently on the source cell as well as the PDCP packet sequence number (SN) for the DL and UL. All data coming from the network must be buffered by the target gNB until the UE completes the connection
  10. The UE synchronizes to the target cell and issues the random access with dedicated RACH resources as received by the previous handover command
  11. The UE completes the RRC handover procedure by sending the RRCReconfigurationComplete message to the target gNB
  12. The UE transfers data to the target gNB
  13. The data path is switched (path switch request) on the downlink and uplink in 5GC between the source gNB and target gNB. The 5GC UPF sends one or more âend markerâ packets on the old path to the source gNB per PDU session/tunnel and then can release any U-plane/TNL resources towards the source gNB

The core network 5GC is also involved in the inter-gNB mobility procedure for the final data bearer data routing at the end of the handover procedure.

Data forwarding, in-sequence delivery and duplication avoidance at handover can be guaranteed if the target gNB uses the same DRB configuration as the source gNB. In case of error the RRC connection re-establishment procedure to the source gNB is used for recovering from the handover failure.

2.3.2.2 Mobility parameters

The parameters required during the handover procedure are listed and explained in the following tables for the HandoverPreparationInformation message (from source gNB to target gNB) and for the HandoverCommand message (from target gNB to source gNB).

Handover preparation informationDescription
UE capability RATThis is a list of UE radio access capabilities for each supported RAT (for current release NR or EUTRA).
This is required by the target gNB to create a UE-specific RRCReconfiguration message to send in the subsequent HandoverCommand message.
Source gNB configuration
â¶ Bearer configuration		Configuration of currently established SRB and DRB in the source gNB.
This container is used for RRC reconfiguration of the UE by the Â­target cell. For each established radio bearer (RB), this includes Â­information such as the RB identity, PDCP configuration (i.e. security) and RLC configuration.
Moreover, the SDAP configuration indicates if the bearer is associated with the eps-bearerIdentity (when connected to EPC) or SDAP layer (when connected to 5GC). In the latter case, the mapping between the radio bearer and QoS flow is also indicated.
The PDU session related information includes the slice information (if supported) and QoS flow level QoS profile(s).
Moreover, security algorithms for integrity and ciphering are provided.
Source gNB configuration
â¶ Configuration of SCG		This is the optional configuration in case of dual connectivity.
The handover command can be used also in case of mobility during DC and in particular when the master node is moved to another target gNB which requires information on the secondary node associated with the source gNB.
Source gNB configuration
â¶ Measurement configuration		Configuration of the measurement to be performed.
RRM configuration
â¶ MeasResultList		Here, the list of measurement results is provided for the serving cell and the neighbor cells, e.g. the SSB frequency or CSI-RS frequency in the form of the ARFCN used and the measurement results in terms of the RSRP or RSRQ.
Here, there is also target cell beam-related information like the SSB/CSI-RS index.
The target gNB can also detect the currently preferred beam from the UE measurements.
AS contextConfiguration restriction for multi-RAT dual connectivity.
This includes restrictions on the frequency combination allowed for MCG and SCG.
In addition, there is re-establishment information required in case of handover failure to enable the UE to re-establish on the source gNB.

Fig. 2-114 Parameters in the HandoverPreparationInformation message.

Handover command (RRCReconfigurationWithSync)Description
Dedicated SI informationThe UE is not required to retrieve system information on the new cell apart from the SSB for initial synchronization. Therefore, this information is delivered dedicated to the UE.
Random access configurationThe random access resources depend on the SSB or CSI-RS index that the UE wants to use for random access to the target cell.
Here, either the UE repeats the measurement performed before the handover command or reuses the same measurement results which can also be provided in the handover command.
The access information to the target cell may include beam-specific information (if available).

Fig. 2-115 Parameters in the HandoverCommand message.

2.3.2.3 Inter-RAT mobility

In inter-RAT mobility, NR only supports LTE as an alternative RAT in 3GPP Release 15. This does not prevent the UE in idle mode from performing reselection on other RATs (GSM, UTRA). In connected mode, two inter-RAT mobility scenarios are possible: involvement of 5GC (intra-system) or EPC core (inter-system) as shown in Fig. 2-116.

In case of inter-RAT, UE capabilities for different RATs are also provided in the mobility command.

The transitions between the RRC states of the UE in case of inter-RAT mobility have been depicted in Fig. 2-117. Moreover, the transition from one state is based on signaling procedures. The UE remains in the RRC_CONNECTED state in case of a connected mode handover between EUTRA and NR. If the mobility procedure does not succeed, the UE requires a re-establishment procedure on the previously connected RAT.

2.3.3 Mobility measurement

2.3.3.1 Measurement overview

The UE performs measurements either in idle mode for cell reselection or in connected mode for handovers. Measurements can be on an intra- and inter-frequency basis. In addition, measurements can apply to NR or in case of inter-RAT, to EUTRA.

If the UE is in idle mode, the measurements, for example, for idle reselection are based on SS signals whose configuration is fixed in the cell and broadcast via the system information (SIB2, SIB3, SIB4) as specified in TS 38.304. If the UE is connected, it performs the measurement based on the CSI-RS or SS signals. CSI-RS configurations are dedicated for each UE (UE dedicated RRCReconfiguration message with measConfig). In this chapter, we concentrate on the measurement configuration for RRM connected mode mobility.

The gNB configures the type of measurements in a measurement object (i.e. the frequency or beam) and the type of report (i.e. the periodicity). The UE is requested to report the measurement information in a periodic or event-triggered manner. In the latter case, the network configures triggering events to report measurements (A1, A2, â¦) based on comparison of the received power for serving cells (PCell) and neighbor cells. Some typical events defined for mobility measurement are listed in Fig. 2-118.

EventDescription
A1Serving becomes better than threshold
A2Serving becomes worse than threshold
A3Neighbor becomes offset better than SpCell
A4Neighbor becomes better than threshold
A5SpCell becomes worse than threshold1 and neighbor/SCell becomes better than threshold2
A6Neighbor becomes offset better than SCell
B1Inter-RAT neighbor becomes better than threshold
B2PCell becomes worse than threshold1 and inter-RAT neighbor becomes better than threshold2

Fig. 2-118 Events for handover measurements.

The network configures a measurement report consisting of multiple configurations:

  • Measurement object, i.e. the frequency and reference signal to be measured
  • Measurement report configuration (periodicity, events, format, filtering parameters)

In NR, especially in the FR2 range, the network configures measurements based on beams. For proper evaluation of reception, the UE first reports the cell quality which averages all measurements among the beams.

Besides the cell quality, the network may require beam-specific information. The beam represents the direction of transmission and the UE receives reference signals (SS-Block with PSS and SSS or CSI-RS) in that specific direction. Specific beam reports are based on the beam index. The beam index is encoded in signals such as SS-Block and CSI-RS. One measurement object corresponds to one SSB index or CSI-RS index and the UE considers different SSBs / CSI-RS indices as different measurement objects.

The UE measures the quality of the signal with different metrics such as RSRP, RSRQ or SINR. For overall cell quality and specific beam reporting, the UE must perform a large number of beam measurements (K) and subsequently filter the results both on the physical layer (L1 filtering; see TS 38.133) and on a higher layer (L3 filtering; see TS 38.331) to smooth the measurement results. The reporting quantities (X) can be the same as the trigger quantity or combinations of quantities, e.g. RSRP and RSRQ, RSRP and SINR, etc.

2.3.3.2 Measurement scenarios

Measurements for mobility can be performed based on the SSB (idle mode/inactive or connected mode) or CSI-RS (connected mode). Several scenarios are possible depending on the location in the frequency range of the target cell. An offset is also applied to avoid frequent reselections when the UE is on the cell border between two frequencies.

There are different RRM measurement scenarios depending on the location of the SSB and CSI-RS to be measured :

  • SSB-based intra-frequency measurement
    A measurement is defined as an SSB-based intra-frequency measurement if the center frequency of the SSB of the serving cell and the center frequency of the SSB of the neighbor cell are the same and the subcarrier spacing of the two SSBs is also the same
  • SSB-based inter-frequency measurement
    A measurement is defined as an SSB-based inter-frequency measurement if the center frequency of the SSB of the serving cell and the center frequency of the SSB of the neighbor cell are different or the subcarrier spacing of the two SSBs is different. An example is shown in Fig. 2-121
  • CSI-RS based intra-frequency measurement
    A measurement is defined as a CSI-RS based intra-frequency measurement if the bandwidth of the CSI-RS resource on the neighbor cell configured for measurement is within the bandwidth of the CSI-RS resource on the serving cell configured for measurement and the subcarrier spacing of the two Â­CSI-RS resources is the same
  • CSI-RS based inter-frequency measurement
    A measurement is defined as a CSI-RS based inter-frequency measurement if the bandwidth of the CSI-RS resource on the neighbor cell configured for measurement is not within the bandwidth of the CSI-RS resource on the serving cell configured for measurement or the subcarrier spacing of the two Â­CSI-RS resources is different

In addition, a time period must be defined where the UE can make these measurements especially on different frequency bands. This time is provided by either a so-called measurement gap or a measurement window (see 2.1.2.2 Provisioning of the measurement configuration to the end-user device, page 243). During the measurement period, the UE is not required to receive or transmit on the serving frequency.

The network may need to configure measurement gaps to the UE for inter-frequency measurements. This allows the UE to retune from its serving cell to some other frequency to perform measurements. The need for measurement gaps depends on the frequencies where the UE is measuring and the RF capabilities of the UE as specified in TS 38.306. The basic requirement is that the UE must switch its frequency of transmission. A big difference between NR and LTE is support for two measurement gaps per UE in NR. One measurement gap is used for cells with carrier frequencies in FR1 and another measurement gap for cells with carrier frequencies in FR2.

2.3.4 Mobility security

The overall security architecture is explained in 1.1.7 Security architecture, page 44 and initialization of security parameters is covered in 2.4.8 Security mode setup, page 425.

The UE connections to the gNB on the DL and UL can be encrypted and integrity-protected. Therefore, AS keys are required for encryption for the user plane (UPenc) and RRC connections (control plane RRC connections, RRCenc). Keys are also required for integrity for the user plane and RRC connections (UPint, RRCint) as shown in Fig. 2-122.

For security reasons, all of the AS security parameters must be updated during UE mobility between different gNBs or inter-system handover (EPC to/from 5GC; see Fig. 2-116). In particular, when the UE moves from RRC_IDLE to RRC_CONNECTED, AS keys must be generated on the gNB AS level. When the UE moves from CONNECTED to IDLE, the gNB and UE need to remove all AS keys, but keys are maintained only on the 5GC AMF. During an RRC_CONNECTED handover, the security key can be kept in case of intra-gNB handover, but must be refreshed in case of inter-gNB handover. The integrity and ciphering algorithms as well as the AS keys (KgNB, KRRCint, KRRCenc, KUPint and KUPenc) are changed with the command âReconfiguration with Syncâ including the parameter masterKeyUpdate.

On handover, a new KgNB that will be used between the UE and the target gNB (known as KgNB; see Fig. 2-122) is derived from either the currently active KgNB (horizontal derivation) or from the two parameters next hop (NH) and next hop chaining counter (NCC) (vertical derivation).

If KgNB is derived from the currently active KgNB, this is indicated to the UE with an NCC that does not increase.

If KgNB is derived from the NH parameter, this is indicated to the UE with an increased NCC. Based on such a key derivation, a gNB with knowledge of a KgNB, shared with a UE, is unable to compute any previous KgNB that has been used between the same UE and a previous gNB, therefore providing backward security. Similarly, a gNB with knowledge of a KgNB, shared with a UE, is unable to predict any future KgNB that will be used between the same UE and another gNB after n or more handovers (since NH parameters are only computable by the UE and the AMF). NH is further bound to the target PCI and its frequency ARFCN-DL before it is taken for use as the KgNB in the target gNB.

Moreover, a key refresh is also possible for KgNB, KRRCenc, KRRCint, KUPenc and KUPint and can be initiated by the gNB when a maximum number of data packets is transmitted (PDCP COUNTs) on same radio bearer identity and with the same KgNB.

Key reprogramming is also possible for the KgNB, KRRCenc, KRRCint, KUPenc and KUPint. It can be initiated by the AMF when a new 5G AS security context, different from the current, is to be activated.

2.4 Overall access procedure for SA mode

Chapter 2.1 Overall access procedure for NSA mode, page 219 examined the fundamentals of the access procedure for non-standalone mode. At certain points, references were made to the standalone (SA) access principle. This chapter will provide all of the details needed to understand the initial access procedure for this mode. The fundamental difference is that SA uses the contention based random access (CBRA) procedure and therefore has to acquire the relevant system information (SIB1). Accessing this information requires acquisition of the MIB and decoding of its content. This is only possible while detecting and identifying the synchronization signal blocks (SSB). However, no information is provided by the network in standalone mode to find the frequencies where the SSBs are transmitted. Like in LTE, the UE starts the entire procedure by scanning the preferred frequency bands, trying to identify the SSB(s). The following sections describe each individual step starting with SSB detection.

2.4.1 Identifying SSBs in standalone mode

In non-standalone (NSA) mode or more detailed EN-DC mode, the UE receives the exact frequency location of the synchronization signal blocks (SSB) via dedicated RRC signaling over the established LTE connection. For standalone (SA) mode, the UE starts scanning the supported 5G NR frequency bands in the priority order, based on e.g. information stored on the USIM, for SSBs.

As stated in 2.1.2.2 Provisioning of the measurement configuration to the end-user device, page 243, 5G NR allows much finer granularity to position the signal in the frequency domain than LTE. The granularity is dependent on the deployment frequency range (see Fig. 2-15). Second, the transmission periodicity of the SSBs is by default far less frequent then in LTE. During the initial access procedure, a UE assumes this to be 20 ms. This results in a longer scanning time due to the periodicity and higher granularity for placing a 5G NR carrier. For this reason, an additional frequency raster has been defined by 3GPP's working group RAN4 as the global synchronization channel number(s) (GSCN). This raster is defined per deployment frequency range (first column in Fig. 2-123) and further specified per frequency band, where, dependent on the utilized subcarrier spacing for the SSB, a different step size (1 or 2) is used.

Frequency rangeSS block frequency position SSREF  GSCNRange of GSCN
0 to 3000 MHzN â 1200 kHz + M â 50 kHz,
N = 1:2499, M {1, 3, 5}		3 â N + (M â 3) / 22 to 7498
3000 to 24250 MHz3000 MHz + N â 1.44 MHz
N = 0:14756		7499 + N7499 to 22255
24250 to 100000 MHz24250.08 MHz + N â 17.28 MHz22256 + N22256 to 26639

Fig. 2-123 GSCN parameters for the global frequency raster.

Fig. 2-124 shows an example for the synchronization and carrier raster using frequency band n78 and assuming 30 kHz is used as the raster frequency (FRaster; see TS 38.101), resulting in a step size of two between NR-ARFCN. Obviously, certain reference frequencies (FREF) for the carrier raster align with the synchronization reference frequencies (SSREF) of the synchronization raster.

A 5G NR device, supporting standalone mode, would now scan its supported frequency bands, following the synchronization raster, trying to identify SSBs transmitted on these frequencies. The UE will perform the same signal quality measurements on a detected SSB like in non-standalone mode. These measurements are SS-RSRP, SS-RSRQ and SS-SINR (TS 38.215).

2.4.1.1 Cell-defining SSB

SSBs are not only important for initial synchronization on the downlink, but can also be used by an end-user device for channel estimation. Therefore, there can be multiple occasions throughout the channel bandwidth, in particular within the configured bandwidth parts, where SSBs are transmitted. Not all of these SSB transmissions indicate further broadcasting of system information (RMSI, OSI) in the particular bandwidth part where they are transmitted. Fig. 2-125 shows an example of a configuration where multiple SSBs are transmitted in different frequency positions. Only SSB1 and SSB4 indicate to transmit the remaining minimum system information (RMSI) such as SIB1, which is required by the UE to perform the random access procedure.

The question is how does the UE determine if the detected SSB is transmitted in a bandwidth part that also transmits additional system information?

The parameter kSSB informs the UE if a so-called Type0-PDCCH common search space is present and transmitted in the bandwidth part where the SSB is transmitted. This type of search space is used to transmit downlink control information to the UE in order to indicate the time and frequency resources that carry the remaining minimum system information (RMSI, i.e. SIB1). To indicate the presence of a Type0-PDCCH common search space, kSSB â¤ 23 for frequency range 1 (FR1) and kSSB â¤ 11 for frequency range 2 (FR2). kSSB is broadcast as part of the master information block (MIB) and is accessible by the UE after decoding the MIB. If the value of kSSB is greater than 23 for FR1 or 11 for FR2, then additional mechanisms are applied to guide the UE to SSBs transmitted in a bandwidth part providing a Type0-PDCCH common search space. For FR1, if 24 â¤ kSSB â¤ 29 (FR2: 12 â¤ kSSB â¤ 13), then the UE can find another SSB transmitted at frequency position NGSCNReference + NGSCNOffsett. NGSCNReference represents the GSCN where the SSB was detected, whereas NGSCNOffsett defines an offset to this GSCN based on the value of pdcch-ConfigSIB1. This information is provided as part of the MIB. Fig. 2-126 gives a list of potential offsets for FR1, while the parameter for FR2 can be found in TS 38.213, Table 13-17. As an example, we will assume the UE has detected SSB 3 in Fig. 2-125 at GSCN 7846 (see Fig. 2-124). When decoding the MIB, the UE determines that kSSB = 24. This tells the UE that this bandwidth part where SSB 3 is transmitted has no Type0-PDCCH common search space. The GSCN offset range is within 1 to 256. If the eight bits defining the pdcch-ConfigSIB1 are set, for example, to 11001100, then this would correspond to the number 204 (decimal). The resulting GSCN offset would be 205 and thus the UE would tune its receiver to GSCN 8051 and detect SSB 4. GSCN 8051 corresponds to a synchronization signal reference frequency (SSREF) of 3794.88 MHz. According to TS 38.101-1, Table 5.4.3.3-1, it is the last GSCN applicable for frequency band n78.

kSSB  pdcch-ConfigSIB1  NGSNCOffset  
240, 1, â¦, 2551, 2, â¦, 256
250, 1, â¦, 255257, 258, â¦, 512
260, 1, â¦, 255513, 514, â¦, 768
270, 1, â¦, 255â1, â2, â¦, â256
280, 1, â¦, 255â257, â258, â¦, â512
290, 1, â¦, 255â513, â514, â¦, â768
300, 1, â¦, 255Reserved

Fig. 2-126 Mapping between the combination of kSSB, pdcch-ConfigSIB1 and GSCN offset for FR1.

2.4.2 Access system information block type 1 (SIB1)

2.4.2.1 Scheduling configuration for SIB1

After the UE has identified the SSB within the bandwidth part that provides a Type0-PDCCH common search space, it uses the information provided with pdcch-ConfigSIB1 to identify the frequency and time resources where the related CORESET is transmitted. As mentioned earlier, this information is coded with eight bits. The UE uses first the four most significant bits and then the least significant bits. Each of these two four-bit combinations points to an index in one of multiple tables defined in TS 38.213. The UE identifies the correct table based on the subcarrier spacing used for the synchronization signal blocks and the subcarrier spacing used for transmission of the control channel (PDCCH) and data channel (PDSCH). The latter is identified by the UE from the parameter subCarrierSpacingCommon broadcast with the MIB. Sticking to the example with frequency band n78 and thus FR1, this value would be set to either 15 kHz or 30 kHz. We will assume it is 30 kHz. The subcarrier spacing for SSBs for band n78 is defined as 30 kHz using mapping pattern C and the minimum channel bandwidth for the band is 10 MHz [TS 38.101-1].

Based on the described settings, the following two tables are applicable to interpret the bitmap used for pdcch-ConfigSIB1. Fig. 2-127 defines the frequency and time resources used for the control set. Using the earlier example, the first four most significant bits of pdcch-ConfigSIB1 are 1100, corresponding to index 12. Therefore, the control resource set occupies 48 resource blocks and an offset of 16 resource blocks. The CORESET occupies one OFDM symbol in the time domain.

IndexSS/PBCH block and control resource set multiplex patternNumber of RBs for CORESETNumber of symbols
NsymbCORESET		Offset (RB)
012420
11
22
33
44
530
61
72
83
94
1048112
1114
1216
13212
1414
1516

Fig. 2-127 Set of resource blocks and slot symbols of control resource set for Type0-PDCCH search space when {SS/PBCH block, PDCCH} subcarrier spacing is {30, 30} kHz for frequency bands with minimum channel bandwidth of 5 MHz or 10 MHz.

The above configuration can, of course, only be applicable if the channel bandwidth provides this number of resource blocks. For a subcarrier spacing of 30 kHz, a channel bandwidth of 100 MHz (273 RB) is supported. The above configuration would require a channel bandwidth of at least 25 MHz (65 RB).

The second step is to determine at which point in time to monitor the downlink at the provided frequency and time resource. This information is generally provided by a second table. In the example, Fig. 2-128 is applicable.

IndexONumber of search space sets per slotMFirst symbol index
00110
1021/2{0, if i is even}, {NsymbCORESET, if i is odd}
22110
3221/2{0, if i is even}, {NsymbCORESET, if i is odd}
45110
5521/2{0, if i is even}, {NsymbCORESET, if i is odd}
67110
7721/2{0, if i is even}, { NsymbCORESET, if i is odd}
80120
95120
100111
110112
122111
132112
145111
155112

Fig. 2-128 Parameters for PDCCH monitoring occasions for Type0-PDCCH common search space â SS/PBCH block and control resource set multiplexing pattern 1 and FR1.

Assuming the least significant bits of pdcch-ConfigSIB1 are set to 1100, index 12 in Fig. 2-128 applies and sets O to a value of 2 and M to 1. The values O and M impact the system frame number as well as the slot number for which the UE would start monitoring the downlink at the defined frequency and time resources for two consecutive slots starting from the slot n0. Slot n0 is determined based on the SSB index i (e.g. i = 0) as n0 = (O Â· 2Î¼ + â£i Â· Mâ¦) mod Nslotframe, Î¼. O and M are known due to the signaled index and Âµ is given due to the subcarrier with Âµ = 1. The factor Nslotframe, Î¼is also subcarrier dependent as it defines the number of slots per radio frame. In the example with 30 kHz subcarrier spacing, this would result in 20 slots per 10 ms radio frame. Based on the above parameterization, n0 is 4. Now, the question is in which radio frame to start. The corresponding system frame number SFNC is determined based on â£(O Â· 2Î¼â£i Â· Mâ¦)/Nslotframe, Î¼â¦mod 2 either resulting in 0 or 1. For the example, the result of this modulo operation is 0 and thus any SFN satisfying SFNC mod 2 = 0 is monitored for the Type0-PDCCH common search space starting with slot n0 for two consecutive slots.

2.4.2.2 Scheduling information for SIB1

The UE monitors the identified Type0-PDCCH common search space now for downlink control information (DCI) format 1_0 where the cyclic redundancy check (CRC) is scrambled with the system information radio network temporary identifier (SI-RNTI). Fig. 2-129 provides a complete overview of the RNTI values used in 5G NR (TS 38.321).

Value (hexadecimal)Radio network temporary identifier (RNTI)
0000N/A
0001 â FFEFRA-RNTI, Temporary C-RNTI, C-RNTI, MCS-C-RNTI, CS-RNTI, TPC-PUCCH- RNTI, TPC-PUSCH-RNTI, Â­TPC-SRS-RNTI, INT-RNTI, SFI-RNTI, and SP-CSI-RNTI
FFF0 â FFFDReserved
FFFEP-RNTI
FFFFSI-RNTI

Fig. 2-129 RNTI values used in 5G NR.

DCI format 1_0 was already discussed in 2.1 Overall access procedure for NSA mode, page 219. The first set of information (frequency and time domain assignment, mapping of virtual resource blocks to physical resource blocks and determination of the modulation and coding scheme) is the same. For more details, see DCI format 1_0, page 264. The difference in content for DCI format 1_0 when used to schedule resources that carry the random access response and in the present case with scheduling resources that carry system information is that the format provides the following additional information:

  • Redundancy version [2 bits]
  • System information indicator [1 bit]
  • Reserved bits [15 bits]

The system information indicator bit is set to 0 for the case in which the scheduled PDSCH carries SIB1. If it is set to 1, it indicates that the PDSCH carries system information (SI) messages. This is relevant since the cell sends other system information (OSI) either periodically as a broadcast or on demand only in which case a UE has to request transmission of additional system information. This information â broadcasting of additional system information or transmission on demand â is defined in SIB1.

2.4.2.3 Content of SIB1

Upon decoding the DCI, the UE knows which frequency and time resources to access in order to identify the resource blocks that carry the PDSCH carrying SIB1. The transmission periodicity for SIB1 is defined as 160 ms. However, the repetition periodicity is variable. For the selected parameterization in the example above with SSB and CORESET multiplex pattern 1, the repetition periodicity is set to 20 ms (TS 38.331).

The PDSCH is generally LDPC coded (see introduction in 5G NR channel coding for data, page 145). After demodulation and decoding of the PDSCH, the UE has access to the information broadcast with SIB1. Its content is listed in the following:

  • Cell selection information (cellSelectionInfo)
  • Cell access related information (CellAccessRelatedInfo)
  • Connection estimation failure control information (ConnEstFailureControl)
  • Information on sending system information (SI) (SI-SchedulingInfo)
  • Configuration of the serving cell (ServingCellConfigCommonSIB)
  • Support for IMS emergency support and support for eCall over IMS
  • UE timers and constants (UE-TimersAndConstants)
  • Information related to unified access control (UAC; see TS 38.331, 5.3.14 for details)

The required information for the UE to continue with the initial access procedure in standalone mode is covered in configuration of the serving cell and signaled as ServingCellConfigCommonSIB (Fig. 2-130). The information the UE requires to perform the random access procedure in standalone mode is highlighted in blue.

2.4.3 Random access procedure in standalone mode

Selection of the RACH preamble and frequency and time resources for Â­preamble transmission

In non-standalone mode, the end-user device is signaled which RACH resource and preamble to use to perform the random access procedure. For standalone mode, applying contention-based random access (CBRA) the UE has to select a preamble and identify the frequency and time resources on the uplink to transmit the preamble based on the results of the signal quality measurements carried out on the detected SSBs.

Generation of the random access preamble follows the same concept as described for non-standalone mode based on the settings and values provided in RACH-Config-Common and RACH-ConfigGeneric. The latter also provides the prach-ConfigurationIndex and thus the UE knows what preamble format to use as well as in which subframes of a radio frame (SFN) it is allowed to transmit the preamble and how many RACH occasions are applicable. For all details, refer to chapter When to transmit the random access preamble?, page 253.

As in NSA mode, in SA mode the UE also uses the threshold (rsrp-ThresholdSSB) definition provided by RACH-ConfigCommon to identify the SSB it should consider for selecting the associated random access preamble. The difference between NSA and SA is how the UE selects the preamble and identifies the occasion where it can transmit the selected preamble.

For SA according to TS 38.213, the UE is provided with a number N of SSB blocks that are associated with one RACH occasion and a number R of contention-based preambles mapped to each SSB. These two numbers are provided to the UE within RACH-ConfigCommon as ssb-perRACH-OccasionAndCB-PreamblesPerSSB. This is a two-fold information element. First, it takes one of eight different values for N as N = â, Â¼, Â½, 1, 2, 4, 8 or 16. We will use the same configuration index for PRACH (133) as in the earlier example for NSA. This index defines six RACH occasions(RO). We will set N to â. That means one SSB is associated with eight consecutive RACH occasions. Furthermore, if msg1-FDM is set to four, the first two ROs are associated with the SSB with index #0. SSB index #1 is associated with the following two ROs (RO#2, RO#3).

Depending on the value of N, there are different values for R (see TS 38.331). The first four possible values of N allow 16 different values for R with a standard step size of four, starting at n4, n8, â¦, etc. If N = 2, R can assume one of eight different values with n4, n8, â¦, n32. If N is four, eight or sixteen, the values of R are either in the range from 1 to 16, 1 to 8 or 1 to 4, respectively. When N is set to â, then the range of values for R is defined as n4, n8, n12, â¦, n56, n60, n64. For R = n8, it means 8 preambles out of a total of 64 preambles are associated with one SSB, starting with index 0. In other words, preambles 0 to 7 are associated with SSB index #0, preambles 8 to 15 are associated with SSB index #1, and so forth.

Based on the threshold and measurement results, the UE may have a number of SSBs available to choose from. It selects randomly but with equal probability. Based on the selected SSB, the UE knows the index and can determine the pool of preambles (e.g. 8) to choose from and what ROs are associated with this SSB index. In the same manner, the UE selects one of the possible preambles and RACH occasions randomly, but with equal probability and transmits the preamble on the uplink to the network.

2.4.4 Random access response in standalone mode

The network will acknowledge reception of the random access preamble in the same manner as in the non-standalone mode case by transmitting Msg.2, the random access response, on the downlink to the end-user device. The entire procedure is identical to execution of the procedure in non-standalone mode. The information on the configuration of the control channel (PDCCH) is provided as part of ServingCellConfigCommonSIB in SIB1 and thus the UE knows which frequency and time resources to monitor for the PDCCH carrying a DCI format 1_0 for which the CRC is scrambled with RA-RNTI. The DCI provides the frequency and time resource information on which RB carries the random access response. For more details, see 2.1.4.2 Reception of the random access response, page 262.

2.4.5 Sending Setup request in the uplink

Fig. 2-39 in Content of the random access response, page 270 gives an overview of the structure of the random access response message and its content. The information provided is used in the same way as in NSA mode. Further details such as usage of the received uplink scheduling grant to transmit Msg3 on PUSCH towards the network are explained in the following sections.

2.4.5.1 RAPID and random access response for standalone mode

Assuming the network is able to accommodate the UE based on its previously sent preamble, it would send a random access preamble ID (RAPID) and associated random access response (RAR). The UE compares the received RAPID with the sequence it had selected as the preamble. If both match, the reception of the random access response is considered successful. Following the RAPID is the RAR which provides the UE with several pieces of information such as the timing advance, uplink scheduling grant and UE identity. Their meaning is explained in the following sections.

Timing advance

The concept of timing advance is applied in non-standalone mode as it is in standalone mode. For relevant details on its meaning and purpose, see Content of the random access response, page 270.

Uplink scheduling grant

A brief summary of the purpose of the uplink scheduling grant is available in Content of the random access response, page 270. A more detailed explanation is given hereafter.

The 27 bits provided with the uplink scheduling grant in the random access response message (highlighted in orange in Fig. 2-39, page 271) are used as shown in Fig. 2-132.

RAR grant fieldNumber of bits
Frequency hopping flag1
Msg3 PUSCH frequency resource allocation14
Msg3 PUSCH time resource allocation4
MCS4
TPC command for Msg3 PUSCH3
CSI request1

Fig. 2-132 Random access response grant content field size.

Frequency hopping and frequency resource allocation

Before the UE prepares for its first uplink transmission, it has to determine which transmission scheme to use to transmit Msg3 on the PUSCH. The RRC parameter Msg3-transformPrecoder, received with RACH-ConfigCommon, determines whether the UE should use CP-OFDM as the transmission scheme or SC-FDMA (= transform precoding enabled; for details, see DFT-s-OFDMA signal generation, page 166). This has certain implications for the interpretation of the bits sent with the uplink scheduling grant in the random access response message as described in the following paragraphs.

The first bit of the uplink scheduling grant informs the UE whether frequency hopping for Msg3 PUSCH transmission is enabled or not. If the bit is set to zero, no hopping is applied and if it is set to one, frequency hopping is activated.

The next 14 bits provide the frequency resource allocation to the UE. How these bits are interpreted depends on whether frequency hopping is enabled or not. If it is enabled, the first one or two bits, NUL,hop, are used to determine the frequency offset between the first and second hop. Whether it is one or two bits depends on the size of the bandwidth part (BWP) that Msg3 is transmitted on. If the BWP is less than 50 RB, then it is only one bit. If the active bandwidth part is more than 50 RB, then it is two bits according to Fig. 2-133. The overall bit settings determine whether the gap between the two hops is half the bandwidth part size or a quarter of the bandwidth part size.

Number of PRB in active UL BWPValue of NUL, hop hopping bitsFrequency offset for 2nd hop
NBWPsize < 500â£NBWPsize /2â¦
1â£NBWPsize /4â¦
NBWPsize â¥ 5000â£NBWPsize /2â¦
01â£NBWPsize /4â¦
10â â£NBWPsize /4â¦
11Reserved

Fig. 2-133 Frequency offset for second hop for Msg3 PUSCH transmission with frequency hopping.

The resource block assignment for Msg3 PUSCH transmission is based on resource allocation type 1. Accordingly, resource blocks are assigned by means of a resource indication value (RIV). The RIV value is based on a starting resource block (RBStart) and number of allocated resource blocks (LRB) impacted by the size of the bandwidth part where Msg3 is transmitted. How is the RIV calculated?

Again, the frequency allocation information is given in the uplink scheduling grant with 14 bits, where 1 or 2 are used for the hopping information. How the remaining bits are processed depends on the size of the actual bandwidth part. If the bandwidth part size is less than 180 RB, then the bits within the frequency allocation field (remember: 14 bits minus 1 or 2 bits) are truncated according to â¡log2(NBWPsize â (NBWPsize + 1)/2)â¤. We will assume the bandwidth part where Msg3 PUSCH should be transmitted has a size of 60 RB. That means the bandwidth part occupies more than 50 RBs and thus two bits are used for frequency hopping information, but it is less than 180 RB, in which case the entire field is truncated to its 11 least significant bits. These 11 bits are then processed like DCI format 0_0 (see TS 38.212, section 7.3.1.1.1 and TS 38.214). If the bandwidth part is larger than 180 RB, the number of bits for frequency allocation is determined based on inserting â¡log2(NBWPsize â (NBWPsize + 1)/2)â¤ â14 bits set to zero, right after the hopping bit(s) NUL,hop.

In both cases, the number of bits translates into RIV (decimal), which ultimately provides a number of continuously allocated resource blocks (LRB) and a start resource block (RBstart) according to TS 38.214, section 6.1.2.2.2.

Fig. 2-134 shows how the UE uses RBStart as the first resource block for the first hop (i = 0) and how it calculates the starting resource block for the second hop (i = 1) based on the offset parameter and the bandwidth part size. The offset parameter (RBoffset) is shown in Fig. 2-133.

Allocation of time domain resources for Msg3 PUSCH transmission

The next information, coded within four bits, is the time resource allocation. Identical to the downlink direction, these bits provide a value m that points to a row index m+1 in an allocated table for PUSCH. For PUSCH transmission scheduled by the random access response, there are two options depending on the information whether the higher layer setting pusch-TimeDomainAllocationList is included in the common configuration for the PUSCH (pusch-ConfigCommon). This information element provides the setting for parameter K2 (0 to 32), the PUSCH mapping type (type A, type B), start symbol for PUSCH transmission and how many symbols are allocated for PUSCH transmission (= length). As on the downlink, the PUSCH mapping type (A, B) defines the starting point for the PUSCH transmission either as the start of the slot (type A) or the start of the PUSCH transmission within the slot (type B). If the information element is not provided, the following default table is applied (see Fig. 2-135).

Row indexPUSCH mapping typeK2SL
1Aj014
212
310
4B2
54
68
76
8Aj + 1014
912
1010
11j + 214
1212
1310
14Bj86
15Aj + 3014
1610

Fig. 2-135 Default PUSCH time domain resource allocation A for normal CP.

The parameter j is subcarrier spacing dependent (ÂµPUSCH) and its possible values are shown in Fig. 2-136. The table also lists the subcarrier spacing specific slot delay Î that needs to be applied in addition to K2 for Msg3 PUSCH transmission.

  ÂµPUSCH  jÎ
012
113
224
336

Fig. 2-136 Definition of parameters j and Î for PUSCH transmission depending on the subcarrier spacing.

We will now consider an example assuming the subcarrier spacing of the bandwidth part the Msg3 PUSCH transmission is scheduled for is equal to 30 kHz (Âµ = 1). In this case, j = 1 and Î = 3. We will further assume that the four bits in the uplink scheduling grant in the random access response point to row index 7 in Fig. 2-135, which sets the PUSCH mapping type to type B. The slot offset factor K2 is equal to j. The start symbol S for the PUSCH transmission is symbol #4 and the length L is set to six symbols. The slot offset for a Msg3 PUSCH transmission is also based on the subcarrier spacings used by the BWP where the PUSCH is transmitted. Further the numerology used by the BWP that the PDCCH and PDSCH is transmitted, that carried the RAR. In this example, both BWPs used 30 kHz (Âµ = 1) and thus the slot offset from receiving the random access response to the slot that can be used to transmit the Msg3 PUSCH is four slots as shown in Fig. 2-137.

The graphic is based on the assumption that the higher layer parameter dmrs-Additional-Position is not signaled by the network, in which case the UE assumes this to be position 2 (pos.2). That results in an additional symbol (l) being used for PUSCH DMRS. Since row index 7 for PUSCH time allocation dictates PUSCH mapping type B, the first symbol (l0) within the slot carries PUSCH DMRS according to TS 38.211, section 6.4.1.1.3. The second symbol for PUSCH DMRS is relative to the start of the PUSCH transmission and occupies the 6th symbol within the slot (see table 6.4.1.1.3-3 in TS 38.211). No hopping is enabled and only single symbol DMRS are transmitted.

Modulation and coding scheme

The modulation and coding scheme that must be used by the UE to transmit Msg3 is coded in four bits. This means that only the first 16 indexes of an MCS table for PUSCH are applicable and the UE does not use 64QAM or 256QAM as a modulation scheme for Msg3 PUSCH transmission. Depending on whether transform precoding is enabled or not, the UE has to apply a different table to decide on the modulation and coding scheme. If transform precoding is enabled, the UE uses table 6.1.4.1-1 in TS 38.214, and otherwise table 5.1.3.1-3.

Msg3 transmit power

The uplink scheduling grant reserves three bits for transmit power control (TPC) which informs the end-user device to adjust its transmit power based on the power used to transmit the random access preamble in a range from â6 dB to +8 dB. The eight possible values to increase or decrease the transmit power are shown in Fig. 2-138.

TPC commandValue in dB
0â6
1â4
2â2
30
42
54
66
78

Fig. 2-138 TPC command for Msg3 PUSCH transmission.

CSI request

The last bit in the uplink grant is reserved for the channel state information (CSI) request. It determines if the UE should send an aperiodic CSI report. This is only applicable for non-contention based random access. For contention-based random access, like in this example, this bit field is treated as reserved.

Initial device identity

Before the end-user device starts transmitting on the PUSCH, it needs one more piece of information so the network can identify its transmission and acknowledge it correctly in the corresponding downlink transmission for contention resolution. This step matters if the UE was already connected to the network (RRC_CONNECTED, RRC_INACTIVE) and an identity was already assigned by the network. A UE performing the initial random access procedure has not yet had an RRC connection. Therefore, the network assigns a temporary identity to the UE known as the temporary cellular radio network identifier (TC-RNTI). This identity is 16 bits long and can be in the range 0001 to FFEF (hex). It is used by the UE to initialize the scrambling sequence generator (cinit) to scramble the information transmitted on the PUSCH (Fig. 2-139).

cinit = nRNTI â 215 + nID

Fig. 2-139 Initialization of the scrambling sequence generator.

nRNTI corresponds to the TC-RNTI, whereas nID is either configured by the higher layer parameter dataScramblingIdentityPUSCH and in the range of {0, 1, â¦, 1023}, or corresponds to the physical cell identity (PCI, NcellID).

2.4.5.2 Actual content of Msg3

With all the above information, the end-user device is now able to use the scheduled uplink resources to transmit its Msg3 on the PUSCH. With Msg3, the UE sends RRCSetupRequest to the network and initiates the initial attach procedure towards the 5G core network. For details on RRC connection establishment and the initial attach procedure to the 5G core network, including activation of security, see 2.4.7 RRC connection establishment, page 424.

2.4.6 Contention resolution

Upon transmission of Msg3, the MAC layer at the UE starts the Â­ra-ContentionResolutionTimer. The value of the contention resolution timer is provided with RACH-ConfigCommon. After starting the timer, the UE begins monitoring the PDCCH for DCI format 1_0 with the CRC scrambled with the corresponding TC-RNTI. Type1-PDCCH common search space is used for transmission of this downlink scheduling grant, and thus the same rules apply as for monitoring and reception of the random access response. Upon reception of the PDSCH, the timer is stopped. If the decoded MAC PDU contains a contention resolution identity (48 bits) that matches the CCCH SDU transmitted in Msg3, the contention resolution is considered successful. Furthermore, the C-RNTI is set to the previously temporary identity and the random access procedure is considered to be successfully executed.

In response to PDSCH reception, the UE transmits an HARQ-ACK on the PUCCH. The PUCCH transmission is on the same initial bandwidth part as the Msg3 PUSCH transmission.

2.4.7 RRC connection establishment

RRC connection establishment starts with the UE sending an RRCSetupRequestas a Msg3 PUSCH transmission to the network. The corresponding response from the network is transmission of the RRCSetup message or RRCRejectmessage. The connection setup message is acknowledged by the UE by sending an RRCSetupComplete message back to the network (Fig. 2-140).

With the setup request, the UE will send a two-part identity (ng-5G-S-TMSI-Part1, randomValue) and its establishment cause, which in this case is mobile originated signaling (mo-Signalling). The two identities each have 39 bits.

2.4.8 Security mode setup

The overall security architecture is explained in 1.1.7 Security architecture, page 44. Initialization of security during initial access is depicted in Fig. 2-141. The security setups consist of four main steps: generation of security key, mutual authentication of UE and network, initialization of NAS security, initialization of AS security.

Generation of security key

Security key generation is the procedure for creating keying material that can be used between the UE and serving network (SN) in subsequent security procedures. This procedure is based on a shared key (K) which is stored permanently both on the UE USIM module and the ARPF/UDM in 5GC.

After RRC connection establishment is completed, the UE can send the first UL message (UL data transfer) which contains the NAS registration request. In this message, the UE identifies itself with SUPI or 5G-GUTI. A subscription permanent identifier (SUPI) must be allocated to each subscriber in the 5G system and provisioned in the 5GC component UDM and UE USIM. The SUPI can have a backward-compatible format with LTE/EPC IMSI or alternatively a network access identifier (NAI) format.

Based on the UE identifier and UE security capabilities, the AMF/SEAF in 5GC selects the security algorithms for authentication and requests generation of the authentication vectors from ARPF based on the shared key K. The overall security key chain is explained in Fig. 2-142.

The security chain is based on the 5G authentication mechanism known as EAP-AKA, i.e. the extensible authentication protocol (EAP) combined with the authentication and key agreement (AKA). The UE and serving network must support two variants of EAP-AKA: EAP-AKA' and 5G-AKA. 5G-AKA enhances EPS AKA [TS 33.501] by providing the home network with proof of successful authentication of the UE from the visited network.

SQN and RAND are sequential and random input parameters to the security crypto function that generates the values for the expected response (XRES), an authentication token (AUTN) and the ciphering key and integrity key (CK, IK). See the TS 33.501 annex for details.

Additional encryption and integrity keys (KNAS, KgNB) are also generated for ciphering the control and data message during NAS and AS communication and mobility keys (KgNB*) as explained in 2.3.4 Mobility security, page 405.
