KNAS and KgNB depends from previously generated in SEAF and AMF. In fact the security generation includes several steps performed in different modules to increase the security encapsulation.

Authentication of UE and 5GC

After key generation, the authentication phase is triggered by the core network (Fig. 2-141). During the NAS authentication request, the AMF forwards authentication parameters directly to the gNB, which sends these parameters over the established RRC connection using the downlink information transfer message to the UE. This message is typically used to carry any type of NAS information between the UE and AMF. After receiving the authentication request from the network, the UE also performs generation of the keys and sends the calculated RESponse (RES) back to the network using the authentication response message. Then, the AMF compares the RES and local XRES and thus authenticates the UE.

Activation of NAS security

The NAS security setup now runs to ensure secure delivery of NAS messages between the network and UE. Until now, the message exchange was not secure.

In this step, the AMF selects a ciphering and integrity algorithm that is supported by the UE. By sending the NAS security mode command, the AMF informs the UE about the selected algorithms. The UE calculates both NAS security keys and performs an integrity check on the security mode command, assuming that the keys are calculated properly once the security check is passed. At this moment, communications between the UE and network is ciphered and integrity protected.

Security protection is applied per PDU session.

Activation of AS security

After NAS signaling encryption and integrity are enabled, the network can start the AS security procedure. The AS applies four different security keys: one for integrity protection of RRC signaling (KRRCint), one for ciphering of RRC signaling (KRRCenc), one for integrity protection of user data (KUPint) and one for ciphering of user data (KUPenc). All four AS keys are derived from the KgNB key. The KgNB is based on the KAMF key (as specified in [TS 33.501]).

The AMF will initiate the security context setup to inform the gNB about the algorithms for encryption and security which are selected from the UE capabilities and which will be used for the current connection with the UE. The gNB will then generate the AS keys as shown in Fig. 2-141 and initiate the RRC security command to the UE to indicate the start of security transmission. The UE will generate the same keys and respond with an encrypted security mode complete message.

After AS security is enabled, the control message at the AS level will be encrypted and integrity protected. Moreover, the user plane message on the AS level will be secured per data bearer connection as explained in 2.2.12 Data security, page 384.

2.4.9 PDU session establishment and network slicing Â­selection

In order to support the diversity of the 5G core network, the network allows network elements to be tuned to serve a specific service such as mobile broadband, ultra-reliable low latency communications or massive IoT. A set of network elements which together are targeted at a certain service is known as a network slice.

A network slice is defined within a PLMN and includes the following:

  • Core network control and user plane network functions
  • NG radio access network or N3IWF to non-3GPP access network
  • The slices are identified by their single network slice selection assistance information (S-NSSAI). An S-NSSAI is composed of the following:
    • A slice/service type (SST) referring to the expected network slice behavior in terms of features and services
    • A slice differentiator (SD), which is optional information that complements the slice/service type (s) to differentiate among multiple network slices of the same slice/service type

Depending on operational requirements, a network may offer the same services on more than one slice, typically aimed at different customer groups. In such cases, the SST for these slices would be the same while different SDs would help identify the slices.

Some SST values have been standardized so that global interoperability for slicing can be supported in roaming use cases more efficiently for the most commonly used slice/service types.

Slice/service typeSST valueCharacteristics.
eMBB1Slice suitable for the handling of 5G enhanced mobile broadband
URLLC2Slice suitable for the handling of ultra-reliable low latency communications
MIoT3Slice suitable for the handling of massive IoT

Fig. 2-143 3GPP TS 23.501 Table 5.15.2.2-1 (standardized SST values).

Based on the subscription, at most eight S-NSSAIs can be marked as default S-NSSAIs. This information would be maintained by the network for its subscribers. If the UE does not send any valid S-NSSAI to the network in a registration request message, the network is expected to serve the UE with a default S-NSSAI or a related network slice instance.

2.4.9.1 Slice selection procedure

UEs registering with the 5G core have an option to register with one or more slices. The UE can request slices of interest by including the requested NSSAI (which is a set of up to eight S-NSSAIs) in the registration request. Depending on the network support and subscription parameters, the network may accept the registration for all, some or none of the requested S-NSSAIs. This is conveyed back in a registration accept (if registration for at least one S-NSSAI was successful) or in a registration reject message (if not successful for any S-NSSAI).

The UE may request registration without including NSSAI in the registration request. In this case, the network assigns it default slice(s) based on the subscription parameters and the assigned slice(s) are conveyed in a registration accept message.

The UE, however, will normally have a configured NSSAI based on the UE type and information associated with the network provider. The UE uses this to include the information about the requested NSSAI in the registration request.

The network may also include information about the allowed NSSAI, which can be used by the UE to request a new registration to a slice that it may not have considered earlier. The network may update the configured NSSAI by including it in registration accept.

2.4.9.2 PDU session establishment

Once the UE has registered, it is allowed to create a PDU session with each slice with which the registration was successful. A PDU session is required in order to obtain resources for user data transmission.

A PDU session could be of type IPv4, IPv6, IPv4v6 (collectively referred to as the IP type), Ethernet or unstructured.

A PDU session with the IP type would assign the UE an IP address and enable it to transfer IP data.

The Ethernet PDU session type can support specific behavior related to carrying Ethernet frames.

The unstructured PDU session type may use different point-to-point tunneling techniques to deliver the data to the destination in the data network.

Each PDU session assigns the UE a default QoS flow. Based on the user data transfer requirements, a UE or network can request to add more QoS flows to a PDU session by requesting to modify the PDU session.

During mobility, a PDU session can be continued in several ways. To serve different requirements, three types of session and service continuity (SSC) have been devised which can be requested during PDU session establishment by setting the session and service continuity mode to one of the three types.

2.4.9.3 Session and service continuity

Support for session and service continuity enables the 5G core network to satisfy various session continuity requirements based on the UE and application types.

  • SSC mode 1: The network preserves the connectivity service provided to the UE. For the IP type of PDU session, the IP address is preserved
  • SSC mode 2: The network may release the connectivity service delivered to the UE and release the corresponding PDU session. For the IP type of PDU session, the network may release the IP address that had been allocated to the UE
  • SSC mode 3: Changes to the user plane can be visible to the UE, while the network ensures that the UE suffers no loss of connectivity. A connection through a new PDU session anchor point is established before the previous connection is terminated in order to provide better service continuity. For the IP type of PDU session, the IP address is not preserved in this mode when the PDU session anchor changes

2.4.9.4 SSC mode selection

In a UE, when an application requests data transmission, it may indicate the required SSC mode based on application-specific requirements. However, if it does not include this information, the UE will perform SSC mode selection based on the SSC mode selection policy. The operator would provision the UE with an SSC mode selection policy which includes one or more SSC mode selection rules which can be used by the UE to determine the type of SSC mode required. The policy may include a default SSC mode selection policy rule that matches all applications of the UE.

When an application triggers data transmission, if the UE already has an established PDU session that matches the SSC mode required for the application, the UE would route the data for the application to this PDU session unless other conditions prohibit the use of this PDU session for the application. If the UE does not have a PDU session that can be used, it requests a new PDU session with the required SSC mode.
